TALK.START.PARA: —I point out to the Minister, in case he has not had time to sort out his thoughts on the matter, that the figures which I have put down of course do not differentiate between sales under contracts written in each of those years and contracts which were written at an earlier time. Those figures are simply not available to us. But the basic point which I think the table does establish quite clearly is that one cannot in a circumstance where Australian uranium is sold on long-term contracts and where only 10 per cent of the world trade is conducted on the basis of the spot market rely on the spot market prices as a reasonable indicator of the price which can be obtained for Australian uranium now or in the future.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to make a number of other points about comments which have been made by the Minister for Resources and Energy with respect to the marketing of Australian uranium. Once again, as recently as yesterday, we had a repetition by the Minister of the suggestion that there is a very limited market. The Government has assessed the market for uranium and it has decided that it can all be met from one mine-namely, Roxby Downs-and that is the end of the matter; that the market has been met so there is no economic reason--

TALK.START.PARA: —One additional mine.

—I am sorry, there will be one additional mine. As far as the Government is concerned that is the end of the matter and there is no room, therefore, for any other producer. That argument of course completely ignores the fact that the amount of uranium that will be sold by Australia is in part a function of what can be sold by those who are able to produce it and who are able to get out in the world market and to arrange sales. It is quite clear that those who seek to exercise the rights to mine which they have obtained after their exploration for uranium are confident that they have the ability to go out and to claim some part of the improving world market for uranium. As recently as last Friday the Chairman of Pancontinental Mining Ltd, Mr Tony Grey, in his company's annual report said that Pancontinental had reached an advanced stage in negotiating contracts with overseas utilities that would have covered a considerable portion of Jabiluka's base load.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition simply does not accept that the Government can, with precision, say that there is a fixed market for Australian uranium, it is of the order of 3 ,000 additional tonnes per annum, and that can be met by Roxby Downs, therefore no other mines should be approved. There is, I think, a role for business in this area. There is a role for salesmanship and for entrepreneural ability which does not come within the province of government. Those people who are willing to invest money to produce uranium in the confident expectation they can sell it will, I think, be very unimpressed by Senator Walsh's desire to choose which mine should be allowed to produce uranium and, additionally, by his view that the market is totally fixed according to some estimate either of Senator Walsh or of his Department. There is room for a greater share to be taken by Australia if companies based in Australia are given the opportunity to expand, to go out and to make sales.

I wish to raise other matters which I have held off mentioning because I wish to raise them while Senator Walsh is present in the Committee. No doubt the Minister wants to respond to matters which were raised yesterday, therefore I will stop now to allow him to respond to the matters raised yesterday and the matters raised so far this morning.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: — Yesterday the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Chaney) raised the problem of explorers who have found gas for which there is clearly no commercial market in the foreseeable future yet there is, Senator Chaney argued, some moral obligation to provide some security of tenure for explorers who have found gas under those circumstances. The Government is, of course, aware of that problem of security of tenure over gas discovered by explorers but for which there is no apparent commercial market in the foreseeable future. We have paid some attention to that and one of the matters which is currently under consideration is that those companies be given longer term security to retain at least a part of the exploration permit areas within which those discoveries have been made. But, as yet, no firm decisions have been made.

SPEECH.PARA: Regarding the other matters on the wholesale and retail prices of petrol on which I sought a response from other departments, it has just been brought to my notice that the Prices Surveillance Authority is intended to absorb the Petroleum Products Pricing Authority. It is expected that the new Authority will , in relation to petroleum products, operate in broadly the same way as the previous PPPA; that is, the emphasis would be on wholesale rather than retail prices. It is expected that the Authority, in exercising its powers, will have regard to the need for persons who supply goods or services to achieve a level of profitability sufficient to enable them to obtain an adequate level of investment and employment. Aspects of the Bill are currently under consideration in consultation with the business community. It is expected that the Bill will be introduced in the present session. I note that in the advice that I have been given, or the advice that the other departments supplied so far, there is no reference to the legal powers of the Commonwealth over the retail pricing of petrol, but as I understand it-and this is subject to confirmation-the powers of the Commonwealth in that area are very limited indeed.

I turn to the matters that Senator Chaney has raised this morning. Whilst I cannot say off the top of my head whether the figures that he has presented in the table incorporated in Hansard tally precisely with those which are available to the Government-at least to the extent with which I am familiar with them, which is the fairly recent past-they are broadly consistent with the figures available to the Government. He makes the point, correctly, that there is a significant difference between the prices at which at least Australian uranium has actually been sold over the last couple of years and the spot price. But from that, he seems to have drawn the conclusion that the prices being secured for existing contracts could be obtained for new contracts. I do not believe that his claim is soundly based in that respect.

I am not sure of the degree to which this information can be released. It is held within the Department of Trade anyway, of course, and not within the Department of Resources and Energy. The Department of Trade holds the precise details of the pricing review arrangements within existing contracts, contracts such as that which was negotiated by Pancontinental Mining Ltd in 1982 and contracts which have been negotiated by another producer more recently. I will see what detail the Minister for Trade (Mr Lionel Bowen) believes can be made available on that question without breaching commercial confidentialities. But I remind Senator Chaney that it was for that very reason-that is, that the provisions within any contract for price revision were to be taken into account- that they will be taken into account by this Government and, indeed, were taken into account by the previous Government. It was for that reason, as has been confirmed, if not directly by Mr Anthony certainly by a spokesman from his office, such confirmation being published in the Australian some months ago and not denied by Mr Anthony, that when that Pancontinental/Central Electricity Generating Board contract was put before Mr Anthony last year he declined to approve it because the pricing arrangements, not necessarily for the first year but for subsequent years, were considered by the previous Government to be unsatisfactory.

Senator Chaney has advanced the argument that the potential market for Australian uranium could be increased if greater sales efforts were made and such efforts were made by a greater number of producers. That is a belief which, I suppose, anyone could hold. There is no objective evidence to support that belief. He went very close to arguing the principle, the absolute position, that government ought to leave such decisions entirely in the hands of private business. With respect to sugar, for example, it could be argued that more Australian sugar could be sold if there were not a monopoly marketer; that if a group of potential sugar producers were to establish an integrated sugar producing industry and be permitted to attempt to sell that product outside the existing monopoly marketing arrangements, the total sales of Australian sugar could be increased. Indeed, in that case that could well happen.

The point is that Governments do not allow that to happen. If someone in Queensland decides to grow sugar cane on unassigned land, it will be commandeered by the Sugar Marketing Board for $1 a tonne. Thus, although it might be quite legitimate to raise that argument in a theoretical forum or a philosophical political discussion, it is not an argument which is applicable to the Australian economy or the way it has been managed in very many areas over very many decades by either Labor or non-Labor governments. If the Opposition is seriously advancing the proposition that there ought to be no government interference whatsoever, the absolute position, in determining who can produce or sell any commodity, I suggest that it direct its attention to the sugar marketing arrangements and publicly oppose them.

The Government is not infallible in the judgments it has made about the commercial demand for Australian uranium. Nobody's judgment is infallible, but the material upon which those judgments have been made is not solely material supplied by or estimates made by the various Australian Government departments which are included. I refer again to the estimate which, I think, could reasonably be called the best estimate on movements in stockpiles of uranium. It was made by Mr Townsend of the British Central Electricity Generating Board and was published recently. Mr Townsend said that in his judgment the production from any new mine would not be needed on the world market until 1995. Under the decision made by the Government yesterday, the two existing mines may continue in production and Roxby Downs may commence subject to the partners or to the participating companies judging it to be a commercially viable proposition. In the judgment of the Government, the supplies from the two existing mines plus Roxby Downs are capable of filling the gap in the commercial market for Australian uranium well into some time between 1995 and 2000.

We also see Roxby Downs and Jabiluka as being competitive or, if one likes to extend that, Roxby Downs and Yeelirrie was also being competitive. Given an existing, and for some time into the future, continuing high level of unemployment, the net economic benefits to the nation from Roxby Downs-I do not think this would be seriously disputed-are considerably in excess of the net economic benefits which could be gained from either of the alternatives I have mentioned or some others I could mention. I do not think that is sensibly arguable. What could be disputed and what could be sensibly argued, because it entails much more doubtful judgments, is the assessment that Roxby Downs is competitive with or mutually exclusive to those other two prospects, Jabiluka and Yeelirrie. In the judgment of the Government, that is the situation.

An additional problem regarding Jabiluka, which I believe is generally well known, is that both the Ranger mine and probably more so the Jabiluka deposit are in a very environmentally sensitive area. While attempts are being made to monitor carefully the environmental effect of the mining at Ranger, that has not been under way for a very long period and there are valid grounds, I believe, for caution before making final judgments that there have been no adverse environmental effects in the Kakadu area and the Alligator Rivers wetlands. I think it would be premature to conclude unequivocally that there are no undesirable environmental effects. That is an additional reason for caution in regard to Jabiluka because if it is established at some time in the future that the mining at Ranger has significant and damaging environmental effects, then those effects are almost certain to be increased susbstantially if another mine is operating in the same area. For all the reasons which I have gone through today and yesterday, the Government has made the policy decision it has.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to follow up a number of points made by the Minister for Resources and Energy in his response. I noted his reply with respect to the petroleum pricing arrangements that the Government intends to put into place, and I ask him to pursue further the question of overlap with State bodies because I do think that is a significant problem for industry and one which the Minister himself, on reflection, would agree does represent an unnecessarily complex approach even if one assumes that this sort of price control is necessary and desirable. I ask him to consider the problem of the dual jurisdiction of State and Commonwealth bodies, whether it be in regard to the new Commonwealth body or the old, and the various mechanisms which have been put in place by the States.

SPEECH.PARA: As far as prices are concerned, I would also welcome his following up the suggestion which he made that he would check to see what non-confidential information could be made available with respect to the proposal by Pancontinental Mining Ltd that it should write new contracts and the sorts of prices which have been obtained under the contracts which have been approved by the Government for the existing mines. Indeed, I would welcome any information which would throw some light on a debate which I think is developing some substantial mythology of its own. To enable us to put some of that mythology to rest, I ask the Minister to consider providing additional information-that is, information over and above the matter of the recent contracts written by Energy Resources of Australia Ltd and the contracts Pancontinental believes that it could enter into if it had Government permission. I ask the Minister to obtain for me some information. All of these questions are subject to the Opposition's acknowledgment that there can be questions of commercial confidentiality, which certainly led the previous Government, as I understand it, not to release the floor price which it had established, although in fact Senator Walsh has broken with that precedent. I do not seek information which is commercially confidential and which would damage companies, but I will put the requests in forms which cover perhaps the obtaining of more precise information and then more generalised information.

I ask the Minister to find out: For each contract for the sale of uranium approved by the Commonwealth Government since January 1981, what was the difference in dollars between the approved contract price and the prevailing spot price of uranium at the time of the signing of the contracts? I ask for the difference in price and also whether in each case the difference in the spot price was higher or lower than the contract price, although I am confident that in each case the contract price will have been higher than the spot price. If that sort of detail is not available for commercial reasons, can the Minister find out what the average difference was in the prices weighted by the amount of uranium sold in each contract? What was the largest and smallest difference between the prevailing spot price and the approved contract price? In each case was the spot price higher or lower than the contract price? Were there any sales of Australian uranium made on the spot market during that period, that is, since January 1981, or indeed in any other period? If so, how much was sold on that market? What was the volume of Australian uranium sold in new contracts approved in each of the calander years from 1978 to 1982 and so far this year? What was the volume of Australian uranium supplied under contracts in each of the calendar years from 1978 to 1982 inclusive and so far this year? I ask for that detail to be obtained because this is a matter of considerable public interest. It is obviously a matter of great interest within the Australian Labor Party. It is a matter on which there have been a lot of assertions by the Minister and other people. I think that sort of information will enable all of us to make more informed judgments.

The Minister in his reply suggested that I had nearly argued-I am glad that he did not spend too much time covering all the things that I nearly argued as against the things that I did argue-that the matter of selling uranium should be left entirely in the hands of business. I would certainly agree that there had been a tradition in Australia for some interference with the free market in the sale of commodities which are produced in this country. However, there is a fairly significant difference between uranium and sugar. For example, there is the International Sugar Agreement, which covers a great deal of the world trade in sugar. Australia is a party to that agreement. I would agree with the Minister that there is very little of the free market in the arrangements which apply to the sugar industry in Australia. That is a matter which is of some concern in Senator Walsh's and my own State, where there is interest in establishing a new sugar industry which would have to be incorporated into those very highly structured arrangements.

The world market for uranium is not like that. The world market for uranium in one which has much more of the free market about it. There is an improvement to the market in sight; certainly, an improvement is generally predicted. There are new sales to be made in the 1990s. There are Australian businessman who believe they can obtain a share of that market. Pancontinental is a very public member of that group. I think it is a very false parallel to draw this analogy with the sugar industry. I would suggest to the Minister that here is a case where the extent to which Australia benefits from an expanded world trade in uranium for peaceful purposes will in part be a function of the extent to which miners are permitted to get out there and be part of the market.

I do not think that Senator Walsh would deny that Canada and South Africa have benefited very considerably from the very cautious approach which has been adopted by governments in Australia, including the Government of which I was a part, to the sale and export of uranium. The very careful approach which was adopted with respect to caring about environmental and Aboriginal issues-very great consideration has been given to the Aboriginal communities involved-non- proliferation, the requirement of bilateral safeguards and so on has enabled countries with a much less restrictive approach to get out there and claim a share of the market. I have met very few Canadians who are not deeply grateful to Australian governments for their attitudes to uranium, because they feel it has been of great benefit to their country. If we adopt restrictive policies, policies which are as restrictive as those adopted by the ALP yesterday, I would confidently assert in contradistinction to the Minister that that will diminish the share of the world trade which Australia may enjoy.

That brings me to a point which Senator Walsh emphasised both yesterday and today in justifying the Roxby Downs decision. Senator Walsh has laid very great emphasis on the comparative advantages of Roxby in terms of the creation of employment. He points out that the nature of the mine is such that a greater number of Australians will be employed by Roxby than perhaps by other mines which, because of a different configuration and mix of minerals at location and so on, might produce the same amount of uranium at a higher profit but with less employment. I suppose in Australia in 1983 all of us would be concerned to see the creation of employment. Undoubtedly the greatest problem facing Australia at present is that by early next year it is anticipated by some that one-third of Australia's youth will be unemployed. That is not something which any of us can regard with equanimity. Therefore, the employment question is very significant.

Senator Walsh's emphasis on employment, however, makes curious the Press statement which he issued also I think yesterday on the Government's attitude to uranium enrichment. If this Government is really concerned about ensuring that Australia's extractive industries, to use a term which is perhaps used in a pejorative sense about Australian mines and their failure to provide the levels of employment which might be wanted--

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not used in a pejorative sense by me.

—No, but the Minister understands the argument. People say that the industries do not provide the sort of employment that is required. Obviously there is very great interest in seeing our mining industry develop in a way in which there is more downstream processing, more employment in Australia, more value added in Australia and so on. However, if that is the case, why is it that the Government is blocking the uranium enrichment study? Senator Walsh, in his Press statement, said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Government has decided it does not wish to facilitate or be otherwise involved with the UEGA study. The Government does not propose to intervene in the study, but notes its completion would require UEGA to have access to classified information attracting international nuclear non-proliferation restrictions. The Government is not prepared to enter into relevant arguments with the relevant foreign Governments to enable such information to be passed to UEGA. Whether UEGA is prepared to continue with the study in these circumstances is a matter for decision by the companies involved.

I think that is a very polite way of saying that the group really might as well give up. If we go back to April, at the time this Government was elected, we find that the uranium enrichment group put on ice its plans for the examination of a billion dollar uranium enrichment plan because of its then uncertainty over the Federal Government's approach to the nuclear industry. That was done pending clarification of the Government's uranium policy and pending further discussion. I think the group took a very reasonable view that it was fair to give the Government a chance to get its policy in order. However, the fact of the matter is that now that the Government has had that chance and has gone through all of this travail over its uranium policy, it has decided to stymie the prospect which Australia had-and I do not put it any higher than that-of getting into uranium enrichment, which would have added value to Australian exports and which would, no doubt, have also created additional employment.

It seems to me that the decision announced yesterday by Senator Walsh is utterly inconsistent with the reasons which he put forward as to why Roxby was to be preferred over other potential uranium mines in Australia. It seems to me to be a decision which is devoid of principle. It seems to me to be part of the trade-off which has gone on within the Government Party to get, I suppose, a third of the way to a sensible policy for the development of Australia's uranium resources. I ask the Minister to explain why it is that this mere study of whether or not Australia could enrich its ores-in other words, upgrade them effectively, add value to them, increase the return to Australia and increase employment in Australia-is being stymied? What reason of principle is involved? What are the environmental, economic and safeguard reasons? What interest is being served by that negative approach on the part of the Government? It seems to me to be utterly inconsistent with what Senator Walsh has been telling us is the reason for accepting Roxby Downs. I believe it puts in doubt the reasons behind it and buttresses the Opposition's view that in fact the Roxby decision is one that is dictated by the politics of the situation, by the involvement by the Bannon Government and by its dependence upon that particular project for its continued success. Again we have a decision which is based not on principle but upon political horse trading which is now being dressed up in economic clothes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should like to follow on from what Senator Chaney has just said. As a Minister, I had first-hand experience of the whole of that range. I remind the Senate that on Monday the Hawke Government, through the mechanism of its Caucus, made decisions upon uranium marketing-truly, by a majority, with 45 per cent dissenting and truly with the Sword of Damocles, in the form of a national conference hanging over it . But emerging from that decision were two things: That marketing could go ahead in a certain specified way and that there was an interest in choosing those areas that created the most employment. The Minister for Resources and Energy ( Senator Walsh) has repeated since, firstly, that there is a limited market in the world for uranium and that therefore we must ration the mines, and, secondly , that we must choose those that would have the highest employability. I want to remind the Senate what this test means because, frankly, if that is to apply, it is an absolutely compelling reason not to cancel the Uranium Enrichment Group of Australia, not to phase out the uranium enrichment research at the Australian Atomic Energy Commission, but rather to do the very reverse.

SPEECH.PARA: I had a little to do with the origination of UEGA and its journey through life. I remind the Senate of UEGA's progressive findings and of their various acceptance by the Government. The first question, which touched on the market- and this is a very sensitive area-was, if there were a uranium enrichment plant in Australia, would there be prospectively a market for uranium enrichment as distinct from yellowcake. The report of the commercial experts said yes, after 1990 there would be prospectively a world market for enriched uranium from Australia. Of course, 1990 would provide a useful lead time in which to get the industry established. The second question was whether Australia could, technically and otherwise, have such an industry. The answer was yes, we could cope with it. The answer to the third question, as to what kind of technology should be adopted-gaseous diffusion, chemical exchange or centrifuge-was that the centrifuge principle ought to be adopted. The answer to the fourth question, as to which centrifuge-big or small, the American type or the European multinational enrichment plant type-should be used, was quite clearly that the Urenco type was to be preferred.

As Minister-and I do not talk from secondhand knowledge on this matter-I had direct talks with a number of world governments and industries regarding the prospective market for enriched uranium. I had discussions with Urenco. I had discussions with European governments, with the French Government, with the Japanese Government and with industries. The situation emerging was that there was a very great likelihood that Australia could enter into a co-partnership with Urenco which might have one or both of two characteristics: First of all, that Australia might share with Urenco in Urenco's existing markets for enriched uranium; secondly, that Japan, which was toying with setting up its own enrichment industry, would look favourably upon an arrangement to buy enriched uranium from Australia if in fact some arrangement could be made. The key was to tie the technology and the market together. Having decided on the Urenco type of technology, the next phase for UEGA-and this is significant to Senator Chaney's argument-was for it to proceed to establish world markets. Having established that there would be a wider need for enrichment after 1990, that yes, we could do it, that yes the centrifuge process was right and yes the Urenco technique was right, the question was how we could clinch together the technology and the markets. It is a very significant thing indeed that, at the very time the Government is arguing that of course if there were more markets it would let more contracts, it is stopping the very study which would prove up more markets for Australia. Why would it stop a study which had a great prospect indeed of finding some co-partnership with the wider markets of Urenco throughout Europe? Why would it stop a study that would provide opportunities to get a wider market for enriched uranium in Japan? These are incontrovertible facts. They lie within the history of the Department and of the Government. That effort has been stopped. It was quite clear that the Government, under the pretext of being short of money-nonsense when it says now that it will have money left over from funds for unemployment benefits-phased out uranium enrichment. Of course, everybody at the Atomic Energy Commission knew why this was done. It was to be palliative, the giving of a toffee apple to the Left-saying to Caucus: 'Here is a toffee apple for you. We will cut this out'. How could the Government contemplate taking such an action?

It will be noticed that the decision on Monday had nothing to do with any dangers presented by the uranium industry. In fact, the very reverse applied. To allow Roxby Downs to go forward, to allow new contracts for Energy Resources of Australia Ltd in the uranium province in Arnhem Land was of course an admission, as the Fox Commission said many years ago, that the mining and milling of uranium is a perfectly normal industry. But, of course, what the Government ought to know is that safer still, in terms of radioactivity, of environment and of ecology, is the uranium enrichment industry. Quite contrary to the belief of the propagandists, there is less radioactivity, virtually none, associated with an enrichment plant than there is with the mine at Jabiru or anywhere else. The fact is that enrichment is a chemical process in two stages, the first being the process of taking the ore, combining it with fluorine gas and getting the uranium hexafluoride. That is a chemical process with no radioactivity involved. The second process is trying to separate U235 from U238, using their different atomic weights, by spinning them around. That industry has been proven the world over to be environmentally safe and healthy and proven also to be labour intensive. It is the very kind of labour intensive industry that this country wants because a reasonably high technology is involved. To get some idea of the nature of a uranium enrichment plant in terms of cascades of the centrifuge, I say that we could have upwards of half a million or more centrifuges of this kind, shape and size, all with their own individual electric motors, all with their own operations and all with a high technology. But what has happened? Because of this hotchpotch, because Australia is not governed in the interests of the community, because decisions are made on the basis of a compromise in the civil war between the Left and the Right inside the Australian Labor Party-last Monday's decision represented simply a pause in that civil war-a palliative is to be given to the Left. I could not think of a more inappropriate time to say to UEGA, 'You must stop; you will not have access to the sensitive data', than right at a time when the Minister and his Government are arguing, by inference, that if there were wider markets they would permit more mines to open. I take it that is so. I am fascinated by the Minister. The Minister, in debate on 3 November in response to Senator Chipp, said:
It can be argued that the effect of Australia's withdrawal-
from supplying uranium-

would be a marginal increase in price, which would have little relevance to anything. But more importantly, it could be an increased probability of customers seeking supplies from countries which impose few, if any, restrictions . If that is accepted, if follows inescapably that the consequence would be to increase marginally the risk of nuclear war and the dangers of long term waste storage. That is a judgement which some people will endorse and others will reject.

I invite the Minister to let us know whether he and his Government endorse both those propositions. I took it from his speech that he was saying that that was his view. If that is the case then he is saying, as a Minister-let us be quite clear whether or not he is saying this because he used these words-that in fact it is marginally, at least, safer for the world for Australia to supply uranium than for Australia to withhold it. Let me say again that if uranium is enriched in Australia, then that would take the supervision and the safeguarding of uranium one important step further because, quite apart from creating jobs, the amount used and the output could be monitored in Australia. So one further step in the nuclear cycle would be done in Australia with total safeguards. The Minister said that it is better for the world at large for Australia to supply uranium than not and therefore the more of the world's uranium that is supplied by Australia the more control there is. He said that we are restricting the selling of uranium because of our view of the markets and our view on employment . Every report that the Uranium Enrichment Group of Australia has made in the several years since it was established confirms that it is necessary to encourage UEGA to quickly get into markets because if we waste time now and others build the enrichment plants and put the contracts in place, not only will we not get more contracts but also there will not be a demand for our yellowcake throughout the world. Countries will make their contracts with others and there will be a fall away.

I invite the Minister to consider the compelling argument that what has happened with regard to UEGA and with regard to the research at the Atomic Energy Commission is the very reverse of what should flow from last Monday's decision. If the Government wants more markets then UEGA reported that there were, potentially, considerably more markets. If the Government wants more jobs, UEGA said there are avenues for more jobs. If the Government wants the world to be at least marginally safer then we can supervise the whole of the process from the taking of the ore from the ground through to the enriching of uranium. Above everything else, what is perfectly clear is that a civil peacetime uranium enrichment plant is of no use at all for weapon making. All that happens in the uranium enrichment plant is that the uranium is enriched from about 0.7 per cent to about 3.7 per cent whereas weapons grade uranium is enriched up to 80 per cent to 90 per cent. Once again, if one wanted to do what the Australian Labor Party has been arguing should be done-that is, make the world more safe-then everything that Senator Chaney and I have said today argues that the Labor Party is entirely on the wrong track and has sold out to the Left. I may say, as one who has been a Minister and as one who has talked throughout the world on contracts for uranium, on yellowcake or enriched uranium, that it is nonsense to believe that governments know as much as free enterprise as to whether markets exist or not. It is absolute nonsense to suggest that a socialist government knows better so uranium cannot be mined and commercially exploited. I thoroughly reject the argument.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I find the last comment quite extraordinarily self-contradictory. SPEECH.PARA: I have a couple of other facts to relate. Senator Sir John Carrick seems to be sure that they have a market even though governments know nothing about these matters, so he says. The general policy which was applied by the Government was that ceilings would be applied to expenditure programs. The ceiling which was applied to the Atomic Energy Commission-I have told Senator Sir John Carrick all of this before, at the Estimates committees hearings-was such that a re-ordering of expenditure within the AEC was required and that re-ordering decision included a reduction in the expenditure on the uranium enrichment program which had previously been proposed. The test bid however continues. It is a two-year program. It is related to Australia's participation in the imposing of effective safeguards.

I want to put another matter straight. Senator Chaney asserted that I had broken the precedent that governments do not disclose details of the floor price . I reject that. In the public comments that I have made on this matter I have referred, in fairly vague terms, to prices in these sorts of words: I do not believe that this Government or the previous Government would have approved a contract at a price lower than around $A35. I have never given a specific figure . I do not believe that the previous Government had to my knowledge, a specific figure. It has been effectively acknowledged by Mr Anthony that not only the initial figure was taken into account by the previous Government but also the pricing review provisions. So I reject the assertion that I have broken precedent and released specifics of government policy on the floor or minimum price. Indeed even had I wished to do so I do not believe it would have been possible because there are many factors which would be taken into account in making a decision about a particular contract and factors which would vary over time. The specific information Senator Chaney sought will have to come from the Department of Trade and not the Department of Resources and Energy, so it will be a matter for the judgment of the Minister for Trade (Mr Lionel Bowen) as to what can be and should be released. However I do not think he will be likely to release on an individual company or contract basis information in the detail that Senator Chaney has requested. Perhaps something can be done along the lines of average prices rather than individual contract prices, but I cannot guarantee that either. I am advised that no spot sales of Australian uranium have been made.

I want to deal very quickly with the analogy between Government intervention in the production and marketing of sugar and Government intervention in the production and marketing of uranium which Senator Chaney claimed was not appropriate because the Government was a signatory to the International Sugar Agreement. The Government did not have to sign the International Sugar Agreement . Previous governments on both sides of politics have made decisions, but if Senator Chaney wants to argue that the principle of Government intervention is wrong under all circumstances, he is making a drastic change to the practices followed by his own Party in government in the past. The degree to which governments ought to intervene is a matter for judgment or prejudice, I suppose, but there is certainly nothing unprecedented about it.

I think it is quite conceivable that Pancontinental Mining Ltd could negotiate some contracts for uranium supply at some time in the next decades anyway, if not in this decade, and at prices which would fall within the price guidelines which would be acceptable to this Government. That is quite conceivable. What, in the Government's judgment, is not conceivable is that Pancontinental could negotiate contracts for sufficient tonnage to get that mine in operation without undermining or crowding out-to use a phrase once favoured by a former Liberal Treasurer-the potential for Roxby Downs to write those contracts. In other words , even though it is conceivable that Pancontinental could produce some contracts , in the judgment of the Government the two projects will be competitive at best and at worst are mutually exclusive for the foreseeable future. I think it is equally conceivable that if Australia had at all times been a gung ho-to borrow a highly technical legal phrase-seller of uranium, with no strings attached and with no price guidelines, then more of it could have been sold. I think that is quite a reasonable proposition, but neither the previous Government nor the present Government was willing to enter into the market as a supplier under those conditions.

Party attitudes to enrichment change over time. I remember that the last Labor Government, and Mr Connor in particular, were eager to develop an enrichment industry in Australia. I also remember Mr Connor being subject to very severe criticism for that, and I remember reading an article published by the Committee for Economic Development of Australia and written, I think, by Dr Susan Bambrick -although I am not certain of that-on the economics of uranium enrichment in Australia, circa 1974, which was highly critical of the proposal of the then Labor Government to get involved in enrichment. I believe also the Opposition parties of the day were highly critical of Mr Connor's intentions in that direction. So attitudes to these questions change over time. Senator Sir John Carrick claimed that a market for enriched uranium for Australia was available some time after 1990. Well, that is a belief that Senator Sir John Carrick is entitled to hold. It may even be proven to be correct. Nobody can tell at this stage. But by his own admission it is some time after 1990 before that is likely . I do have some preliminary information from the Department of Trade regarding Senator Chaney's questions, but it is handwritten and difficult to interpret on the run.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would be quite happy to get it in a tabular form, as long as it is not in a month's time, but in the near future.
—As long as the honourable senator is agreeable to that, I will do it. I do not propose to try to read it out now because having just set eyes on it I will not be able to interpret it correctly.

Mr Chairman, I seek leave to incorporate the information which I sent over to Senator Sir John Carrick a while ago regarding the questions he raised yesterday.
—I have not got any information.

—It is still coming, whatever it is.
—I gave it to an attendant about half an hour ago.
—Perhaps you might like to ask to incorporate it later on once the Opposition has seen it.

—Yes, I will. On the question of employment, Senator Sir John Carrick and Senator Chaney have both picked up the principal reason that I have advanced for the Government's decision on making a choice between Roxby Downs and Jabiluka. I wonder whether Senator Chaney and Senator Sir John Carrick would want to extend their argument to that degree, that we should also become a repository.
—A lot of engineers and scientists would agree with that because it is geographically stable.

—There is quite a rational argument to be put for it in my view, but I wonder whether Senator Sir John Carrick and Senator Chaney want to extend their arguments to that point. The operational production stage at Jabiluka would employ about 480 people and at Roxby about 2, 400. So there is an enormous quantitative difference. —What about indirect employment?

—That applies to all the figures I have quoted. I have used no multipliers, only direct employment. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh) has, whether inadvertently or advertently, confused each of the questions I raised. First of all, as to the Uranium Enrichment Group of Australia, let me make it perfectly clear what the position is today. Let the Minister refute it if he feels this is wrong. UEGA said the following things: First, that there would be a likely market for enriched uranium from an Australian industry from the 1990s onwards; secondly, that it is possible for Australia to have such an industry technically; thirdly, that the centrifuge is the right situation; fourthly, that the Urenco type centrifuge is the logical one, and fifthly, that it would now like to have the approval of the Government to go forward and, combining the technology and the opportunities for markets, to talk to the world to bring about arrangements whereby technology and markets can combine. In other words, should we join with Urenco and share its European market, should Japan come in and be part of it, or should any other arrangement be made?

SPEECH.PARA: I put it to the Minister that where he has denied UEGA its ability to go ahead because the Government will not give confidential knowledge is the very crucial point. At this very moment UEGA is aiming to move into the field of technology and markets and seek to get the two together. The Government has denied it the ability to do so. To raise the red herring of Rex Connor is nonsense. Clearly, those who criticised the building of an enrichment plant in 1974 were right. They knew that, in fact, the American capacity for enrichment-and I challenge the Minister to deny this-was sufficient virtually to supply the world, certainly the free world, well into the late 1980s. Therefore, anybody building a plant as early as 1974-75 would be building miles ahead of the market. So, to raise an argument like that is to raise a red herring.

To raise the fact that the Government is cutting off the research at the Australian Atomic Energy Commission because it needs to provide money for the National Energy Research, Development and Demonstration Council is nonsense. The fact of the matter is that the previous Government, having supplied year by year millions of dollars for NERDDC, was able to supply the money out of the trust funds available last year. Of course, it is the normal duty of a government to find the money if the money is not in trust funds. So let us not have those kinds of excuses. It was done because the Left wing demanded it of the Government. The Minister raised the old chestnut, that is, that the Government had to do this because of the size of the deficit. Let me remind him, as I did yesterday, of his address to the Committee for Economic Development of Australia on 4 November. A substantial part of that address challenges the idea that large or over-large deficits are bad. In fact, the Minister said those kinds of arguments are at best ambivalent. He said that there has been too much talk about deficits. I do not know who is the discredited present Minister now, but the whole of the early part of Senator Walsh's address was based upon the fact that at best there was an ambivalence:
The empirical evidence on these beliefs is at least ambivalent.
He said:
The perceptions are widely held . . . probably too much attention has been focused on the deficit ever since it became politically expedient to do so in 1975.

He went on to argue about countries of the Organisation for Economic Co- operation and Development, saying that it was not the size of their deficits that mattered, but the existence of an effective prices and incomes policy. Let the Minister never again raise in this place the size of the deficit as an excuse for not doing things. Of course, he has run away from the question I asked him. I asked him a question in regard to his statement in refutation of Senator Chipp's Customs (Nuclear Materials and Hardware) Prohibition Bill 1983 the other day, in which he argued rhetorically that to deny uranium to the world could force up its price and could make it marginally less safe for the world in terms of nuclear war. When he was saying that I asked him specifically whether he was stating the view of the Government and stating his view. I say also that it is a pretty pathetic journey if, not being able to answer the arguments on enrichment, the Minister now has to trot out the question of waste disposal. Of all people, he should be the last to do that because he knows that the Fraser Government put aside major funds for the undertaking of the synroc development by the Atomic Energy Commission and indeed, in discussions around the world.

In other words, the Australian Government, under the Fraser Government, was keen to help the world at large to find an absolutely safe method of waste disposal, a method which differs significantly from the vitrification method in two major ways. The vitrification method, which is regarded as safe today, requires the storage above ground of radioactive waste for some 30 years for cooling purposes because hot glass put into the ground with water around will leach. Therefore, one has to store it above ground for some 30 to 40 years. The great potential value of synroc is twofold: Its ability volume for volume to absorb is something like four times as much as vitrification and its ability to hold high level waste is much greater. But its major ability is to be placed in the ground immediately and therefore to be put away with immediacy.

There is no question, and no question ever arose, that the Fraser Government was considering using Australia as a repository of world waste; none at all. What the Fraser Government was doing, both in its uranium enrichment research and in its synroc research, was making the world potentially immeasurably safer. Again, the Minister ran away from the enrichment situation. If indeed Australia can control the whole of the process and monitor it from the mine to the enrichment stage then that is one further step of making it safe. If it can have an enrichment plant that cannot be a weapons plant but can be only a peacetime plant, then of course one has made the world safer. If, in fact, synroc succeeds and we can provide to the world an immensely better method of waste disposal we have made the world safer.

But let us not have these kinds of situations. If the Minister is good at rhetoric let us ask him the question: Does he personally, and does his Government, believe that Australia should be used as a repository for the waste of other countries? I think that it is important in an Appropriation Bill debate for Ministers to answer questions and not to put up rhetoric. I invite the answers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very grateful to Senator Sir John Carrick for the information that the Fraser Government was going to use Australia as a dumping ground for global nuclear wastes. That is something of which I certainly was not aware before. I am very grateful to Senator Sir John Carrick for having told us that that was being contemplated by the Fraser Government. I would be even more grateful if Senator Chaney-or preferably, Mr Peacock-would tell us whether the policy of the Liberal Party remains the same in opposition as Senator Chaney says that it was in government, that is, that Australia was going to make itself available as a radioactive garbage dump for the rest of the world.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer to the other matters raised by Senator Sir John Carrick. It was difficult to follow the disjointed meander that his 15 minutes or so took through a variety of subjects. He asked a series of questions initially. One of these questions was whether UEGA had said a number of things. I do not think I was able to write them all down. He asked: 'Did UEGA say that a market would be available after 1990?' Senator Sir John Carrick asked: 'Did UEGA say it was technically possible to enrich uranium in Australia?'. Yes, as I recall, UEGA did say that. It is hardly a startling announcement. It is technically possible to do an enormous number of things which no sensible person would do. It is technically possible, as I have mentioned before, to grow pineapples in Antarctica.

Senator Sir John Carrick asked: 'Did UEGA say whether it peferred the Urenco technology?' As I recall it, the answer to that is yes. Indeed, reference is made to that in a Press statement put out jointly by Senator Sir John Carrick and Mr Anthony on 6 October last year. It was, incidentally, the last official statement made by the previous Government on this matter. In that statement a number of references were made to Urenco-Centec technology. It states:

Although Urenco-Centec enrichment technology will be the basis for further studies by UEGA on the feasibility of enrichment in Australia, this does not mean that Australia will co-operate only with the Urenco-Centec countries. UEGA has advised the Government that there is greater compatibility between Urenco- Centec and Japanese centrifuge technologies than between Japanese and other technologies, . . . .

Senator Sir John Carrick then meandered off in a sort of general discussion about macroeconomic policy, which does not appear to me to have a great deal to do with the estimates for this Department. I suppose macroeconomic policy being by definition the sum of all the components, for him to do so is not in breach of the Standing Orders, but this is hardly the place to have a debate on macroeconomic policy. However, since he has raised the matter, I am obliged to reply.

In reference to the ceiling which has been proposed for the total expenditure of the Australian Atomic Energy Commission, I have already said that that was reordered. Senator Sir John Carrick then raised the question of the National Energy Research, Development and Demonstration Council. I remember very well the situation we inherited in respect of NERDDC. That was that the previous Government last year had raided the NERDDC trust fund. It had emptied out the hollow log. If I remember correctly about 80 per cent of its total NERDDC expenditure came out of the NERDDC trust fund. What we inherited was a till that was almost empty. That imposed much more severe constraints, other things being equal quite obviously, on the amount of money which we could make available under NERDDC vis-a-vis that which could have been done the year before. I would have thought that was a subject that Senator Sir John Carrick would have had the good sense and the political sense not to raise. The fact is that in his last year as Minister he raided the NERDDC trust fund and almost entirely emptied it. That was the legacy which this Government inherited from Senator Sir John Carrick.

He referred to the Committee for Economic Development of Australia address. What I did in my CEDA address-Senator Sir John Carrick quoted sections of that address-was simply to report some facts which I thought a number of members of the Opposition by now would have known. I said that there were about half a dozen countries which, throughout the very economically difficult decade through which we have just passed, by all the generally accepted indices of economic performance-employment rates, inflation rates and growth rates-had a very good economic record, certainly an economic record vastly superior to that which Australia had for the same period. I also reported the fact that the size of the deficits in those half a dozen or so countries varied enormously. The thing they had in common was an effective prices and incomes policy.

I certainly would prefer it if in economic discussions and economic debate in Australia there were less concentration on the size of deficits. But we inherited from the previous Government a prospective deficit of $9 1/2 billion- for this financial year, on a no policy change basis. The size of the deficit was deliberately concealed by the discredited former Treasurer and discredited former Prime Minister right up until election day, when they were saying publicly that the projected deficit for the next financial year was $6 billion and they knew it was $9.6 billion. That was the situation we inherited fiscally. The situation we inherited psychologically was the widespread perception that under any circumstances a large deficit was economically irresponsible and inappropriate. We inherited those two things-the fiscal inheritance, which was an enormous bill, and the psychological inheritance of the expectations and perceptions of the community-which were generated by the irresponsible opportunism of the former Prime Minister in 1975, supported by Senator Sir John Carrick and, as I recall, every other member of the Liberal and National parties who were in the Senate at that time. The point I was making to CEDA was that if expectations are widely enough held they are likely to become self-fulfilling.

Again, I would have thought that Senator Sir John Carrick, of all people, would have had the political sense not to raise the fact that we inherited, in the fiscal sense, a very serious problem, not only one which had been concealed from the public and the Australian Labor Party in opposition by the previous Government but also one on which false assertions had been made. The previous Government not only failed to tell the truth; it also made assertions which were simply not true. We inherited that situation. We also inherited what I regard as a psychological problem in that sensible discussions about an appropriate size of deficit in this country was stultified all the time from late 1974 until March of this year. Sensible discussions about the appropriate size of a deficit had been stultified because of the irresponsible opportunism of the Fraser Government and all those associated with it.

Finally, Senator Sir John Carrick mentioned synroc. In one of the few statements he made that is correct he said that the previous Government had commenced to fund the synroc program. That is so. That funding has been continued. The amount appropriated this year for synroc, as I recall, is something like $1.3 million. The amount actually spent last year was about $0.3 million. I know that a greater sum was appropriated but the amount actually spent was about $0.3 million. That program has not only been continued; it has been significantly expanded under the present Government. As in so many other areas, nobody can be certain of the final outcome, but in the Government's judgment it is sufficiently encouraging to justify continued funding at the level we have provided this year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats obviously believe that the Government is sensible in getting out of the enrichment business. There is very little point, then, in our pursuing an experiment which will be of no purpose to us, which is immensely expensive and which is particularly demanding of electric power. I think that is the point: One virtually needs a nuclear power station to provide the power requirements of a large centrifuge plant, so by going into enrichment through a centrifugal process one would be creating the whole nuclear power situation and would probably need reactors in Australia just to service that whole incestuous situation.

SPEECH.PARA: Arising from that are a couple of points that I would make. The Atomic Energy Commission, I understand-I want to ask the Minister a question on this matter- now has, with its reduced work load, a considerable number of fairly expert people-computer operators, statisticians and other professional and expert technical staff-who are under-employed. As a result of this, has the Government given any more thought to an idea that was projected some years ago, and which has come up over the years many times, including from the Australian Democrats, that the Australian Atomic Energy Commission as such should be ended and that the whole thing should be reconstituted as an energy commission, so that those people on the staff can be used more properly and there will be a diversity of occupation to which they can be devoted?

My second question is related to that and concerns the extent to which I feel that the National Energy Research, Development and Demonstration Council is not looking at alternative areas of generation, of electric power particularly, which are already successful and quite firmly established in other parts of the world. I would ask, for instance, whether NERDDC has had any kind of contact with Sanyo in Japan, which is now putting $50m into a project to make amorphous silicon cells. Silicon cells, of course, have developed very greatly over the last 10 years. Their cost has come down, because it is not necessary now to slice small sections of ceramic and use them as a photovoltaic cell. The silicon can be sprayed on to a substrate, which can be glass, metal, or even tile, with increasing cheapness, and this will provide the photovoltaic effect.

It is interesting that in last week's Newsweek-I hope that the NERDDC people read it-under 'New products and processes', it is noted that Sanyo is now manufacturing a roof tile, which will be marketed within two years at $10 each and will allow a complete house to be supplied with power in perpetuity on a commercial basis at an overall cost of $3,000. That cost will come down considerably with the enormous amount of research going into this technology in both America and Japan. In a high sunlight country such as Australia, with remote localities and high costs of electricity reticulation, it would seem even more definite, as predicted overseas, that within a very few years amorphous silicon cells will replace nuclear energy as the best and cheapest way of producing electric power. The only use of nuclear energy is in the production of electric power.

If indeed that technology is developing, as I understand it is, if a firm with the reputation of Sanyo is putting such vast sums of money into it, and if similar experiments are being carried out in America, why are we not doing it here? Is it because, as we hear from time to time from honourable senators, that all of these technologies are in the future, 30, 40 or 50 years away? We are merely revealing the fact that we are 30 or 40 years behind the rest of the world. For instance, is NERDDC studying the fact that in California now a series of wind generators is being built, in a fairly unfavourable environment which will supply 450,000 people in San Francisco? Why are we not in this kind of technology when, in the Cape Leeuwin area and on the western coast of Tasmania, we have the best areas in the world for it? What has happened as a result of that?

A couple of weeks ago we heard from a Minister in this place that the research of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation into wind energy had been run down and had ceased completely. I ask the Minister whether we have to live in this sort of Rip Van Winkle world. Australia seems to have some antiquated scientists who do not even observe or know what is going on in the rest of the world. Perhaps they do. I would like the Minister to tell me so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join in this discussion because I am excited by the alternative energy proposition put forward by Senator Mason. I would like to tell the honourable senator that his proposition is quite uneconomic. The provision of electricity through solar means will not eventuate for probably 50 years. My authority for that would be Sir Mark Oliphant.
—It is not uneconomic under all circumstances.

—Okay. I concede the point with respect to direct solar energy, but I am talking about illuminating electric light globes. Using the hydrogen economy through solar energy is a long way down the track. The most significant alternative source of energy is probably nuclear fusion. A lot of work is being done on it at present in the United States. I believe that laser beam technology or electro-magnetic containment-that is probably the preferable method-will see some strides forward as alternative forces of energy within the next 20 or 30 years. But a lot more research needs to be done on that.

SPEECH.PARA: I have visited the experimental wind station near San Francisco. It is a windmill with vanes on it about the size of a Jumbo 747 aircraft. I can imagine the noise pollution that would arise in that area with several thousand or a million or so of those windmills. They are certainly a proposition but they are uneconomic. Senator Mason informed us that nuclear power is costly. I ask the honourable senator to tell me why, in France for example, it has been discovered that nuclear power is 26 per cent cheaper than coal. With the way the coal industry is going, it will become more and more expensive to win coal from the mines of the world. Coal fired power stations will become very much more expensive over the next decade or two. The Electricity Trust of South Australia is concerned at the cost. I would say that in a few years time honourable senators, if they are interested in the environment, as I am, will opt for nuclear power in Australia.

I ask the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh) what research is being done by his Department into the pollution of the environment by carbon dioxide through the use of coal fired and oil fired power stations?

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, come on!

—It is all right for the champion of the left to chime in. He showed his hand a few moments ago when he revealed the way he voted in Caucus the other day. He said that he was going to do his best to reverse the decision made by the Labor Party. I congratulate the Minister and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) for what they have done. Although it is not enough, the fact that Olympic Dam will be able to proceed is welcome news for South Australia. It is welcome news for several thousand people in South Australia and other parts of this country who want to work. It is welcome news from our point of view. It may be of interest to Senator Georges that that particular mine is estimated to contain enough uranium to provide the world with energy for 40 years.
—And radioactivity.
—Right, radioactivity. The honourable senator talks about radioactivity, but he does not worry about the radioactivity that is associated with the coal mining industry.
—Oh, look; that is nonsense.

—It is not nonsense at all. Senator Georges does not worry about the 2.8 tonnes of carbon dioxide that is generated for every tonne of coal that is burned. He does not worry about the effects of the oxides of sulphur and nitrogen on the environment. The other day I read about the concern being expressed throughout the world at the damage that is being caused by acid rain. In West Germany it has quadrupled in the past year and a third of the country's forests are dying.
—And in Scandinavia.
—In Scandinavia and also in North America and Canada.
—Have a look at their power stations. Haven't they got scrubbers on them?

—This source of pollution is operating throughout the world despite use of the most sophisticated scrubbing technology that anyone could wish to introduce. That comment displays the total ignorance of the left wing of the Labor Party. Its members jump to their feet because of emotive reasons without any knowledge of scientific fact. These debates are useful in trying to elicit some intelligent debate on the subject. I am glad that at long last some journalists in Australia have done some scientific research on this subject. They are now writing articles that seem to me to display the knowledge that they have gained by reading scientific documents. In the Weekend Australian there was an article written by Mr Des Keegan that demonstrated that he has done a bit of work on this subject. He refers all honourable senators and other people interested in the subject, particularly politicians who do not know anything about it, to a book called The Struggle for Power by Mr John Grover.
—He is a publicist for the nuclear industry, as you know full well . The book is published at their expense.
—All right. The point is that the facts are there. This article mentions some very interesting points.
—It is a thoroughly biased book.
—Well, Senator--
—Order! The Committee will come to order. Please address the Chair, Senator Jessop.

—I understand your concern, Mr Chairman. Certain honourable senators do not like it when one talks about a document that has been researched and is informed from an engineering and scientific point of view and which is able to discredit some of the anti-nuclear people who are pushing the line that the Australian Democrats would like to push. They are doing it very ineffectively, I might say. The article suggests that a number of the scientists who are anti-nuclear advocates are discredited. I also noticed an interesting article the other day which referred to the emergence of Senator Chipp as the self-styled moral conscience of those coercive Utopians seeking to arrest the very technological process on which the future of this planet Earth could depend . The article said:

SPEECH.PARA: His loyal devotees, now occupying 16 tents around the lawns of Parliament House , this central tabernacle, are chanting incantations against Australia's most valuable sunrise industry, uranium mining and the peaceful fuel cycle.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where does that leave Senator Mason?

—Senator Mason is probably the deputy high priest of Australia with respect to uranium. The objectives of the left wing, of course, appear to be well served by Senator Chipp's unswerving commitment to the formulation of a uranium policy which will guarantee to alienate Australia from the world community in general and from its major trading partners in particular. I suggest that the Democrats look at the path they are following. They ought to look at the problems of pollution that are being created throughout the world by coal fired power stations. They ought to look at the proposition that other countries, such as Japan, South Korea, Taiwan--
—They are uneconomic; they are yesterday's technology.

—I just wonder at the amazing knowledge that my dear friend has in his brain. I cannot agree with any of it, of course; it is all nonsense. I am a little bit concerned that countries such as Japan, a former great military country, South Korea, Taiwan and others have little or no energy available to them. At present, they are forced to seek long term contracts from other countries. I thought that Senator Walsh very wisely suggested yesterday that they are obtaining their resources from Brazil and countries that have no great regard for the safety of those who use them. If we are involved in the provision of this energy source to other countries we at least have a strong voice with respect to the non-proliferation of nuclear weapons, about which I think we are all concerned. I applaud the Minister and the Government for getting into the act, albeit tentatively, for that reason as well as for another reason of great importance, which is that it will give us the opportunity to carry out scientific audits in the countries that are using Australian uranium to ensure that proper safety standards, proper storage technology, are employed. The only way we can do that is to become involved as a major supplier of uranium throughout the world because we can then exercise great influence in the areas that concern us all. I hope that ultimately the Government will see its way clear to enable other mines to commence for the benefit of the Australian workers who want some jobs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I thought I would intervene before the Minister for Resources and Energy ( Senator Walsh) replied because I will raise a couple of matters on which he may wish to comment. I am sure he would rather not prolong the debate. I want to make a couple of comments on the interventions of Senator Georges and Senator Mason. I merely wish to congratulate Senator Georges on being the only one of the famous 46, or whatever it was, who seems to be even vaguely interested in this debate. Although I disagree with his intervention, which seemed to be based on no particular fact, just that he is against enrichment-indeed, terrified of enrichment-he has at least had the grace to attend the debate and make some contribution. As far as enrichment is concerned, Senator Sir John Carrick made it quite plain that it is a process which relates to the upgrading of ore but not to anywhere near a weapons standard, that it is not a process which involves pollution or environmental problems and that it is in fact precisely the sort of move that we have hoped to see generally across our resource industries-namely, a move towards the processing of ores before they leave these shores. I, like him, would be interested in an answer as to whether new contracts which have been approved by the Government are below the floor price. No doubt we will get a response on that in due course.

SPEECH.PARA: As far as Senator Mason is concerned, I must say I find what I would describe as his schizophrenic approach to scientific matters as quite extraordinary. He is an unabashed technological optimist about what one might call the fashionable possible developments that might save the world. He thinks we are going to have all of our electricity off the roof and that we will have all sorts of technological breakthroughs which will remove the need for nuclear and perhaps even coal-fired power stations. So we have a very high degree of technological optimism on his part, and I admire and respect that because I think that, the way the world moves, the discoveries that are made generally exceed our wildest expectations. It may be that if the honourable senator makes a hundred predictions, all of them wildly optimistic, at least some of them will prove to be true and he will be able to die a happy man, having seen his prophecies fulfilled. The odd thing about his attitude is that he is such a technological pessimist about the nuclear industry. The fact is that that industry has been operating on a commercial basis for peaceful purposes for 35 years with a safety record that is unparalleled. The industry has that record because of the technological skill that has been put into it. If other industries had made the same attempts to avoid pollution and to promote safety and avoid accidents as has been made by the nuclear energy industry then many of those other industries would have greatly benefited. I do contrast Senator Mason's extraordinary pessimism and Stone Age approach to the peaceful use of nuclear power with his extraordinary optimism in other areas.

As far as the other matters are concerned, Senator Walsh allowed the standard of the debate to slip a bit when he resorted to an old tactic, when not finding arguments that suited him, of answering arguments which had not been put by his opponents. He did that-Senator Sir John Carrick has already commented on it-when he suggested that we were arguing that Australia should become the radioactive garbage dump for the world. That is a very emotional debating point; he might even regard it as a good debating point. It just bears no relation to the debate which preceded it. The debate which preceded it raised the issue of why it was that this Government was frustrating an investigation into the enrichment of uranium in Australia, a process which is not hazardous and which could not by even the wildest stretch of the imagination be called a process which would make Australia a radioactive garbage dump. We had in the debate the setting up of a straw man, and Senator Walsh had great fun knocking him down. I would like to ask Senator Walsh why he is trying to slide off the clear meaning of his Press release of yesterday. Senator Walsh put out a Press release-he has not suggested that it is not his-which states--

TALK.START.PARA: —I what?
—This is the honourable senator's Press release, is it not?
—Yes, I thought you said I suggested that it was not.
—No, I said Senator Walsh had not suggested that it was not his. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . Government has considered its policy towards the study by the Uranium Enrichment Group of Australia into the feasibility of establishing a uranium enrichment operation in Australia.
He goes on to say:

The Government does not propose to intervene in the study, but notes its completion would require UEGA to have access to classified information attracting international nuclear non-proliferation restrictions.
I repeat, the Government is not going to intervene but notes that the group requires certain classified information. The Press release continues:
The Government is not prepared to enter into relevant agreements to enable such information to be passed to UEGA.

In other words, the Government is putting beyond the capacity of the group- according to Senator Walsh's own statement-the ability to complete its study. I think it is sophistry on Senator Walsh's part to suggest that the Government has done other than stymie the work of the study group on uranium enrichment. I believe he should be man enough to stand up in this Committee-indeed wherever the matter is raised-and admit that the Government has taken a decision that the study should not go on.
The other argument which has been stressed again by Senator Walsh today is that the principal reason for supporting Jabiluka is the creation of employment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Roxby.

—I am sorry-Roxby Downs. The principal reason for preferring Roxby to Jabiluka is the superior employment creation opportunities of the Roxby project. I ask Senator Walsh whether, in the great debate which occurred on uranium policy in the Australian Labor Party at its national conference last year, there was that sort of analysis of the options which faced Australia and whether, at the time when the ALP adopted as its policy-this was last year, not last Monday-there was the phasing out of uranium mining but the putting in of what we have generally described as the Roxby exception. Its policy said that uranium mining would be allowed where it was mixed with the mining of other minerals, although apparently that does not apply to Jabiluka. I ask him whether it is a fact that there was an extensive analysis of comparative employment creation qualities of the various projects. Was the Roxby exception put in on the express basis that it would do more to create employment in Australia? If it was, I think there can be some basis in fact for the arguments that he so conveniently trotted out this week. If it was not, then I suggest, as I said before, that he was simply justifying what were essentially political and doctrinal decisions on an economic basis which is a matter of subsequent construction. There has been a fairly lengthy debate on this part of the estimates. I would appreciate clarification from the Minister on a number of those points which I have raised.

SPEECH.PARA: I raise one further matter. I would also like the Minister to clarify the Government's attitude to compensation. What the Government did in the formal acceptance of the Cabinet policy by Caucus on Monday was to say that various prospects will not be able to obtain export permits and, therefore, will not be able to be developed. Senator Walsh, with a little sliding around yesterday in Question Time, confirmed that that was the meaning and the places such as Jabiluka would not be able to get export permits under the policy as it now stands. I ask the Minister: Is any action being taken by the Government with respect to compensation of those people who, in good faith and under the encouragement of various governments, including some State Labor governments, have invested heavily in getting projects to the point where they are satisfied that they have a potential mine for production and who have now seen those potential mines simply put into quarantine?
