I note that CSR Ltd, which is one of the companies involved in the Honeymoon deposit, in a quarterly mining report which it issues, has advised that the South Australian Government has refused the claim for compensation by the Honeymoon joint venturers. The Government has offered a five-year retention lease over the deposit.

I think there is an important issue of principle involved here. The present Government is on record as saying that it, like the previous Government, encourages investment, both foreign and domestic. I think that the encouragement of investment has to be on the basis that there is some certainty, that there will not simply be an expropriation of the efforts and of the money which has been put into projects. I ask the Minister: What is the attitude of the Government to compensating those investors, those companies, both Australian and foreign, who, on the basis that they would be able to develop what they find, have put large amounts of money in? There are the costs of workers who cannot be retrained or redeployed by the companies. There is the cost of retraining schemes, and there is the cost of the care and maintenance of sites and so on. In some cases decommissioning expenses are involved. Will the Government be doing something to compensate those people who have effectively lost the capital invested?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: - There is one point that someone else might take up. I have been accused of misrepresenting Senator Sir John Carrick. That accusation is not correct. Apparently I misheard him. I thought Senator Sir John Carrick had said that the Fraser Government was considering storing nuclear wastes in Australia, or words to that effect. He claimed that he said no such thing and apparently others have confirmed that. I misheard him. I did not deliberately misrepresent him. However , that matter having been clarified, it leaves hanging in the air the other arguments which are being advanced by the Opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: The Leader of the Opposition, Senator Chaney, and Senator Sir John Carrick have argued that since the Government, in the context of choosing between allowing one mine or another to proceed used, as a major determinant of that decision, the respective employment generating potential of the mines, ergo the Government should be doing everything it possibly can to have Australian uranium enriched here instead of exported-as yellowcake. If that chain of logic were accepted, it inevitably follows that we should also store the waste. While there are some doubts, I suggest, about the economic viability of enrichment in Australia, I do not believe there is any doubt at all that the rest of the world would be quite happy to send radioactive waste to Australia and to pay us for keeping it in custody. That would undoubtedly generate employment. Senator Sir John Carrick asked: What is the present Government policy on using Australia for the storage of radioactive waste? Some waste, of course, that which is produced by the Australian Atomic Energy Commission is stored here already. That is not a matter to which the Government has addressed itself and, therefore, there is no policy.

The honourable senator also referred-I will go through this very quickly, Mr Chairman, because I know that debates on estimates are pretty free-ranging and I really think, this one having gone on for about 3 1/2 hours on matters which are non-specific to the estimates themselves, it is about time the consideration was terminated-to the February economic statement which was put out by the Australian Labor Party prior to the Federal election. It ought to be noted that that statement was put out in the context of the expectation of a $6 billion prospective deficit in this financial year. The macroeconomic conclusions were drawn upon that expectation and argued for a larger deficit. There is no inconsistency between that and the policy finally adopted by the Government which was for a deficit estimated, in round figures, at $8 1/2 billion. So the Government produced a Budget which included a deficit very much larger than what was believed at the time to be the prospective deficit. If Senator Sir John Carrick wants legitimately to criticise the Labor Party for putting out that statement in the context of the expectation of a $6 billion deficit on a no policy change basis, I suppose it is legitimate to do so. It is legitimate to criticise members of the Labor Party for having been mugs enough back in February to believe what the previous Government told them about the prospective size of the deficit, but on no other grounds is it legitimate to do so!

The questions which were asked by Senator Georges have to a large extent, if not entirely, been covered by questions already asked by Senator Chaney to which I have responded by saying that the information on these matters is held within the Department of Trade and its release would be at the discretion of the Minister for Trade (Mr Lionel Bowen). It would not be at my discretion. The questions will be referred to the Minister. However, I can say this much: I understand that there is a floor price policy. I think it is probably an over simplification to describe the policy which is being pursued in those terms, as it would be an oversimplification to describe the policy of the previous Government in those terms, because a floor price, as commonly interpreted, means that there is some fixed figure below which no sale will be made, whereas it is somewhat more complex, because there are mechanisms for varying figures from time to time. I will refer that question, along with Senator Chaney's questions, to the Minister for Trade to see what information, and in what detail, he will make available.

TALK.START.PARA: —So what you are saying is that there is no floor price, there is a pricing policy?
—Yes. A pricing policy would probably be a more appropriate term to use than the term 'floor price'. This matter is not administered by me and I will seek clarification.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Mason raised a question regarding the future of the Atomic Energy Commission. Currently legislation is being prepared regarding the Atomic Energy Commission. As I understand it, the previous Government also had some legislation either in preparation or in contemplation regarding the restructuring of the Commission. Funds are provided for solar electricity generation. But with the exception of some very specialised requirements for electric current, that is, relatively low volumes in remote areas, the solar silicon cell continuous electricity supply option is not economically viable. Probably within a factor of 10 to 25 it is not price competitive with electricity generated for bulk usage in thermal power stations, at least in Australia, but it is viable and it is of course, used by Telecom Australia, amongst others, in some specialised circumstances.

On the question of what one might call commercial scale electricity generation, principally I would expect, for the reason I have given, the use of solar electricity for the continuous supply of electric current in high volumes is far from being economically viable. Principally I would expect for that reason, an application for one quite large NERDDC project grant this year was rejected.

In regard to the generation of wind electricity, particularly in Tasmania, in my view there are prospects that this may be economic in the context of a minor supply of the total grid. However, the technical data which is the prerequisite for making a responsible judgment on that question is inadequate. I have approved-the co-operation of the Tasmanian Hydro-Electric Commission will be required for this to be fully effective-funds of, I think, $67,000 for a continuing study of wind velocities at various sites and at various altitudes in order to obtain a more adequate technical base upon which an assessment can be made.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that in association with the air monitoring station at Cape Grim on the northern end of the west coast of Tasmania? It is one of the chain of air monitoring stations.

—I think not, but I am not certain. If the honourable member wants this matter checked out, I will see that someone does so. However, as I said, I am not certain of that point. Senator Jessop asked whether any research on carbon dioxide pollution is being funded. Not to my knowledge, but again that is subject to confirmation, although I guess that indirectly, through various university research programs, it is possible it is being carried out. To my knowledge research is not, in an obvious way, being funded through NERDDC.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Chaney returned to the Uranium Enrichment Group of Australia question, within the context of which the employment argument was raised. He asked me whether this matter was considered by the Australian Labor Party Conference. I am not sure whether he meant to say 'Conference' or 'Caucus' meeting. The Labor Party Conference was held in public. There is a full transcript of its proceedings. If Senator Chaney wants to know what happened there or what was said there he can obtain a copy of that transcript from John Curtin House, I think for $30. I am not going to give him one. If, on the other hand, he meant the Caucus meeting held this week, yes, the employment generating potential was considered-at least it was raised in the debate and it was raised by me in a similar context and in a similar way to the way in which I have presented it to the Senate.

I think that yesterday Senator Kilgariff asked me a question which included a reference to compensation. I did not answer that, not because I was trying to evade it but because it was part of a multiple question and I was not able to take sufficient notes to remember the question in total. Cabinet was requested by the Caucus meeting on Monday to consider the question of compensation, and that will be done. It is, however, my firm understanding that there is no legal obligation on the Commonwealth to compensate, for example, Pancontinental Mining Ltd for Jabiluka. My understanding is that the legal situation is pretty clear- there is no obligation to so compensate. But the matter will be considered by Cabinet at some time-possibly next week; maybe thereafter.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is the Fraser Island precedent, I presume, for there being a basis for an obligation even if it is not an enforceable legal obligation.

—I think it would be reasonable to argue that the Fraser Island precedent could be applied to a government decision which closed down an existing mine. However, I think we are moving into a qualitatively different area if we try to apply it to a potential mine site in which exploration actively has taken place and exploration expenditure has been incurred. That is something the Cabinet will consider.

SPEECH.PARA: I might add that I understand the historical background to the Honeymoon prospect in South Australia for example, was that the venturers, the principal one of which is CSR Ltd, made an application to the South Australian Government for a production licence and that that application was rejected by the South Australian Government. I was aware of the fact that the South Australian Government stated that it accepted no obligation for compensation because it had never issued a production licence. Likewise, of course, no production licence has been issued for potential but non-operating mines in the Northern Territory nor, to the best of my knowledge, has any production licence been issued for Yeelirrie in Western Australia, although I am not certain about that. That is a question which is due to be considered by Cabinet.

I know that Senator Peter Rae wants to say something. I know that debates of this nature are allowed to be wide ranging. However, we have spent a great amount of time on this matter and I think it is time that the actual subject matter of the appropriations was addressed by the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take on board the words of the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh). I will not detain the Committee for long. However, I think that a final point needs to be made in regard to a couple of matters that have been raised during the debate. First, I thank the Minister for his replies. Telecom Australia installations and things of that kind of course use the old type of silicon cells. I wish to draw the attention of the Minister to the availability of new technology and amorphous silicon cells and hope that the National Energy Research, Development and Demonstration Council will look at this.

SPEECH.PARA: The next point arose from Senator Chaney's comments. Does the Minister agree with my understanding that an enrichment plant can be arranged quite easily to provide enriched uranium to any degree of enrichment; in other words, that it is quite possible and perfectly feasible to obtain weapons grade enriched material from such a plant, it being only a matter of the number of times the material is put through the centrifuge? That is absolutely fact. In fact, enriched uranium from just that source was used in the first atomic bomb that was ever exploded. I pose those two questions to the Minister. However, just briefly, I assure Senator Chaney and Senator Jessop that the most cursory investigation in a number of countries-including Japan, the United States of America and Scandinavia-will show that alternative renewable technologies are well advanced in those countries and that, indeed, we are truly the Rip Van Winkle land in that respect.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all, does the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh) agree with this statement: 'It is the Government's intention to phase down the uranium enrichment research and development being undertaken by the Australian Atomic Energy Commission at Lucas Heights'? I mention to the Minister that the source of this statement is a letter under his hand. If he wants to check this quote I will be happy to send him the letter. I have a series of questions which I would like the Minister either to answer now if he can or, if he feels he cannot, perhaps to answer later. Do the Minister and his departmental experts have reason to dispute the claim by the French Ministry of Energy and the National Electricity Authority- the Electricite de France-that coal fired thermal electricity generation is more than half as expensive again as nuclear power generation in France and that oil fired thermal electricity generation is two and a half times as expensive? In France the claim is that coal fired thermal electricity generation is half as expensive again and that oil fired thermal electricity generation is two and a half times as expensive.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, do the Minister and his departmental experts agree with the Federal Republic of Germany's Kraftwerk Union Corporation assertion that it would cost very significantly less to generate power from a 200 megawatt nuclear power station-and this is the important point I want to make-than it would cost to generate electricity from a similar oil fired thermal power station? Thirdly, do the Minister and his departmental experts agree with Japan's Overseas Electrical Survey Institute that nuclear is cheaper than coal, oil and hydro as far as Japan is concerned in the following proportions: 1:1.25 in relation to coal; 1:1 .6 in relation to oil; and 1:1.75 in relation to hydro? I would also ask the Minister what distinguishes the hydro-electric generating costs in Japan as being so comparatively expensive. Fourthly, I ask the Minister whether he and his expert advisers have any reason to dispute the study undertaken by the Finnish Atomic Energy Commission-and I remind the Minister that Finland gets over 40 per cent of its electricity from nuclear power stations-which showed that for Finland nuclear power including the full cycle of waste disposal, and decommissioning, was one-sixth less expensive than was the use of coal. Do not these facts and a whole horde of others demonstrate beyond doubt that the experience in the countries which have developed contemporaneously nuclear power and alternative forms of power shows that the economics of nuclear power is now beyond dispute-unless we quote some of the extraordinary figures from the United States of America which people have been quoting as support for what I believe to be the untrue case, that nuclear power generation is an extraordinarily expensive method of power generation. If I have a chance, I would like to talk a little bit about small nuclear power stations and the comparison with hydro- electric generation because it does have some relevance in the Australian scene in the future, particularly in one State.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise because of a number of remarks which have been made, in particular by Senator Georges-I compliment him on speaking in this debate and understand his reasons-and by Senator Mason. I think every Australian would agree that anything tending to promote nuclear warfare or the proliferation of nuclear warfare would be heinous and should be stopped. But I rise because there is a great distortion in the arguments that are put forward regarding the peacetime use of nuclear power generation, the use of uranium and the alleged dangers of enrichment. The fact is that all indications are to the contrary. Whilst in no way wanting to minimise the duty of people to reduce the effects of man-made radiation, I want very briefly to point out the evidence contained in a publication by the World Health Organisation. This is a United Nations publication, a factual publication on the effects of radiation, both man-made and natural, in causing carcinogenic disease or cancers. I want to state these points because I think that the matter needs to be put into perspective. I repeat that it would be the duty of every person to reduce man-made radiation to the absolute minimum. I say this against the background that if one lived in Sydney at sea level, over the year, one would absorb about 100 millirems of radiation. On top of that, all man-made radiation from atom bombs put into the stratosphere and into the cosmic mix over the years has added two millirems, so the level in Sydney is 102 millirems. By electing to work in Canberra one elects by altitude to add another two millirems to his total, or an amount equal to that produced by all of the atomic incidents. That is not to say that one should not try to reduce that level. If one travels in aeroplanes repeatedly, one adds more; they are elective things. To put this matter into perspective, I want to read a number of things very briefly from a publication by the World Health Organisation. The document states:

SPEECH.PARA: Cancer is primarily a disease of old age. For example, in countries where life expectancy is in the range of 60-70 years, about 20% of all deaths are due to cancer, but the average victim is about 65 years old.

Over 1500 different agents besides radiation are known to produce cancer. This list includes such items as chimney soot, arsenic, paraffin oil, coal tar, some components of tobacco smoke, ultraviolet light, asbestos, some chemical dye intermediates, fungal toxins in food, viruses and even heat. For a large majority of these agents the situation is less clearly understood than it is for radiation, and for most of these cancer-inducing agents there are no detailed and generally accepted regulations to protect against the risk of contracting cancer.
The important paragraphs are the next ones, which state:

Taking into account all the radiation (both natural and man-made) that a population is exposed to and the total number of cancer cases (from all causes) that are recorded, it is about 100 times more likely that cancer will be produced in the average individual by some other cause than by radiation.
I repeat:
It is about 100 times more likely that cancer will be produced in the average individual by some other cause than by radiation.

The publication goes on to make clear the potential sources of cancer. Tobacco smoke and chemical pollutants in the atmosphere of industrial cities represent roughly 25 per cent, dietary factors represent 35 per cent, spontaneous events in the body represent 10 per cent to 20 per cent and other environmental causes represent 20 per cent to 30 per cent. The article concludes:

It is presumed, nevertheless, that natural background radiation (and man-made radiation) do have some effects on human health; they may cause up to about 1% of all the cases of cancer and genetic defects . . .
That includes the natural background-the cosmic rays, the phosphorescent rocks, our bones, the food we ingest plus what we have caused. I say this to put it into perspective.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did they include Hiroshima and Nagasaki?

—I have a very keen interest in Nagasaki and Hiroshima. As Senator Georges may know, I was fortunate not to have been at Nagasaki when the atomic bomb was dropped but some 25 of my colleagues were. I have followed that journey and indeed I have a detestation of nuclear war and the suffering it causes. I have read all that I can on this subject. I rise merely to put the matter in perspective. Indeed, the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh) put it in perspective the other day-it was a rare occasion, one on which, as I said, he made a good speech-in responding to Senator Chipp. He raised the question which Senator Georges raised by way of interjection today thinking it a small matter. I refer to acid rain, that is, the nitric and the sulphuric acid that fall in the atmosphere. Let me just put it in perspective with what I have just said. At the International Atomic Energy Agency, where I was privileged to be an attending Minister, a subject of constant discussion by nations was the permanent damage being done to the ecology of the world and to human health by acid rain. It was pointed out that in Canada 2,000 lakes of significant size have been destroyed forever. Their flora and fauna, their whole ecological system, has gone forever because of acid rain. That figure has been doubled in Scandinavia. The Scandinavians are absolutely obsessed with the danger to the ecology from pouring nitric and sulphuric acid down upon people. The American Medical Association has estimated that it is possible that some 50,000 deaths a year in America are caused by the effects of acid rain. Nobody suggests that some 50,000 deaths a year are caused by nuclear power stations.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister also referred to the greenhouse effect, that is, of sending hot carbon particles into the stratosphere, raising the temperature of the atmosphere, melting the polar ice caps and therefore raising the sea levels. That is a great threat which in the next 50 years or so could lead to the destruction of everybody living on the littorals. Nobody here seems to be looking at this kind of situation. In a huge ecological situation they are confusing the danger of nuclear war with the peacetime use of nuclear energy. I want equally to point out, while I am on my feet, that the International Atomic Energy Agency, quite contrary to Senator Mason's argument, has said that no matter how much conservation there is, no matter how much use there is of renewable energy, of coal, of natural gas or of oil, an increasing use of uranium for nuclear fuel will be necessary.

If that does not happen the living standards of the world will fall sharply. Indeed, the world will be imperilled by destabilisation. So we have a major job in that regard. It is not good enough for Senator Mason to talk about solar energy and wind energy as though they are reliable alternatives at the moment. Australia is one of the leaders in the world in solar energy research. It has done some very good research into wind energy. Honourable senators may like to go to Rottnest Island and see the helical wind-powered generators there. The more these alternative energy sources are studied the more we realise that we are dealing with something that is, at this moment, only fractional, as the Minister said.

I rose to put the situation into perspective. It always seems to get distorted when we discuss uranium. Uranium exists throughout the world. If Australia does not export one further ounce of uranium, the world will still have recourse to unlimited supplies. Uranium will be used. But, as the Minister said, if we supply it it will not only be marginally cheaper to the world but also we will be able to monitor its sale so that there will be marginally less risk to the world that uranium will go into the making of nuclear weapons. The key is that uranium will be used throughout the world. Nothing will stop that. Uranium can be found in any country. It can even be obtained from the sea. The real question is: Will its use be monitored? The whole purpose of my intervention in this debate today was to say for Lord's sake let us obtain the widest markets we can for uranium consistent with our strengthening, to the utmost, the safeguards associated with the supervision of the movement of uranium throughout the world. For Lord's sake let us have a look at whether we can get a viable uranium enrichment industry because, if we do, it will be one further step in the monitoring of the sale of uranium. In other words, we will be able to provide enriched uranium to the world at a level of 3.7 per cent enrichment, which is not even close to weapons strength. I cannot understand why the Government should confuse this situation at all. I commend the World Health Organisation's publication on this matter. In no way have I ever attempted to minimise the dangers of ionising radiation. It is the duty of all mankind to minimise the elective amount of radiation that man absorbs. Man absorbs an enormous amount by non-elective or natural means.

I have raised this information today because I think we ought to be able, from time to time, to have a civilised debate and put in perspective what is a vital matter and also to try to look at the nuclear debate in terms of the use of uranium in both peace time and war time. I would very much welcome a debate on nuclear disarmament. The Opposition and I are implacably opposed to nuclear disarmament. We are in favour of disarmament. But that question has no relation to this debate except that the more we monitor the use of uranium the more we restrict the danger of uranium being used for weapons purposes. I commend its export and I commend the enrichment investigation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not have time to answer Senator Peter Rae's questions now.

SPEECH.PARA: Progress reported.
Sitting suspended from 1.45 to 2 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Social Security. I refer to today's well documented reports from Caucus yesterday which I think have reported that the Government's apparent decision is again to examine aspects of the proposed assets test. What brought about this reappraisal? Was it the proposed reduction to the revenue contemplated by the introduction of the so -called leisure package? What further reduction in estimated revenue receipts is now expected as a result of representations made by the Australian Labor Party back bench in Caucus? What now is the expected revenue saving from the introduction of the assets test? Given that further reductions to the revenue are likely to follow, how will these reductions affect the Government's capacity to assist the most needy pensioners?

—Senator Messner's question apparently results from a report in one or two newspapers this morning-a report which is speculation and which is not based on fact. As I said, after the Budget Speech this year Mr Keating announced the intention of the Government to introduce an assets test and gave broad outlines of how that assets test might apply. Both he and I also said that we would spend the time from then until the end of this session consulting various organisations, groups in our Party and other interested persons as to the outline of that assets test. There have been many meetings about the assets test; meetings of the policy committee of the Party, meetings of the policy committee of the Cabinet and meetings of the Cabinet. There are differences of opinion within the community et cetera as to the level, for instance, at which one may consider it reasonable to exempt a holiday home, if one exempts it at all. Naturally some people living in New South Wales, who consider their housing values to be higher than anywhere else, have different views from others. As a result of that the New South Wales group has made representations to me. At the moment the final outline of the assets test has not been completed. At the moment it is before Cabinet. When it has passed the Cabinet-if honourable senators understand our party system-it will go before the meeting of the parliamentary Labor Party and it will then be presented to this Parliament in legislative form. The exact amount of savings to the revenue on the assets test will depend on the final outline of that test itself. I think Senator Messner must contain his anxiety until the outline of that test is presented to Parliament.

—Mr President, I have a supplementary question. The Minister has , I think, implied that there was some discussion in Caucus yesterday about this matter. Is it the intention of the Government, in the light of the representations that have been made by various organisations, apparently to lock into the Government's decision, the various bodies in the community interested in this matter as it apparently is trying to do with Caucus?

—I hardly think it is a supplementary question, but I point out that I neither implied nor said that there were any questions in Caucus about the assets test yesterday. In fact I do not mind saying that there were, as there were the week before and the week before that. Any suggestion that the Government can lock Caucus or lock any organisation into any bit of legislation through consultation is nonsense. The final form of the legislation and the final form of the assets test will be the result of a decision of the Federal Parliamentary Labor Party and the Cabinet, and that is not locking anyone into it; it is consulting with them and talking to them about what the best form of that test might be.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Is he aware of advertisements currently appearing in the media featuring recently retired Federal politicians? Is the public being accidentally misled into thinking that these financial ventures advocated by ex-politicians are Government backed? Will the Government consider a code of conduct that would exclude such activities, especially as Parliament has provided such generous retirement benefits?

—No, I have not seen the advertisements to which Senator Ray refers, but I think from the perceptive way in which he asks the question I can divine what the advertisements were about. I think they have been about on previous occasions. I think it is very difficult for a government to prescribe codes of conduct for people who are beyond the reach of this Parliament. That has been a problem over many years in terms of retired public servants and a problem for governments of all persuasions. I think the same sorts of difficulties would apply in relation to former members of parliament. As the question by implication contains a constructive suggestion regarding this matter I will certainly refer it to the Prime Minister and have an answer given to Senator Ray as soon as possible to see if anything constructive can be done if the advertisements are misleading in the sense which Senator Ray suggests.

—My question, which is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, refers to media reports that the Minister for Home Affairs intends to change the method of arts funding by the Commonwealth Government and thus the Australia Council's role? Is it a fact that in a letter to the Australia Council the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment attempted to pressure the Council into support for the Australian Labor Party's preferred areas of funding, instead of allowing the Australia Council to follow its long standing process of peer group assessment and grant giving experience? Is it also a fact that the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment and some of his senior officers have been promoting changes in arts funding, by methods including background briefing of journalists, which would diminish the statutory independence of the Australia Council and the principle of arms length funding for the arts, and replace it with political assessment and pork barrelling methods? Is the Government deliberately promoting this climate of uncertainty about the future of the Australia Council? If not, will the Minister give an immediate assurance that the scope and independence of the Australia Council will continue undiminished by political interference?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will have to refer the specific matters in Senator Martin's question to the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, Mr Cohen, for an answer. But I can certainly assure the Senate that it is the policy of this Government to uphold the independence of the Australia Council and indeed to strengthen its capacity to assist the development of Australian culture. Evidence of that, of course, was the significant increase in the Budget this year for the Australia Council. I would also point to a major change in the administration of arts funding within the Council which demonstrates our commitment to independence rather than to political interference. That was the decision taken by this Government and by the Minister to transfer decisions about funding the two largest or two most generously funded companies-the Australian Opera and the Australian Ballet-back to the Council. As honourable senators will be aware, prior to the change of government those companies had been directly dependent on political favour; that is, their funds had been secured directly by a decision of Cabinet and the views of the Australia Council in these matters were completely overridden and ignored year after year.

ANSWER.PARA: Now, those two major companies, which receive such large amounts of funds in comparison with other programs funded through the Council, have been transferred back to the Council, and decisions about the funding of those bodies along with other bodies will be taken by the boards and by the Council itself. So I can assert in the Senate that there is no intention to undermine the independence of the Australia Council, which is not to say that we are not a government without views and policies with respect to the development of Australian culture. We do certainly have such views and have such policies and of course we would expect, in a general sense, that any statutory body operating as a part of this Government's activities would be aware of the general policy directions of the Government. But individual decisions about individual grants and individual programs are made and will continue to be made, I am sure-and Mr Cohen will be able to support this-by the Australia Council and its boards.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I am sure that all honorable senators would welcome the recent 1/2 per cent reduction in home loan interest rates announced by several government banks and at least one building society in the last week. In view of the reluctance of the private sector banks to cut rates, I ask the Minister: What action, if any, has the Government taken so far, and what action is planned to encourage the spread of interest rate relief to those home buyers repaying loans to the private banks? What would a further 1/2 per cent reduction in mortgage interest rates mean to home buyers if the private banks followed the initiative taken by the government banks?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that both Mr Keating and Mr Hurford are meeting representatives of the private banks tomorrow evening to discuss the provision of housing funds and, I would imagine, the question of interest rates to which Senator Maguire referred. But the decisions about those rates are, of course, at the discretion of the banks rather than of the Government per se.

ANSWER.PARA: In regard to the latter part of Senator Maguire's question concerning the effects that a fall in interest rates of the magnitude which occurred recently in part of the banking sector and in particular, the Commonwealth Savings Bank last week, would have on actual or prospective home purchases, there are a number of points which I think are worth making. One point is that the Commonwealth Savings Bank interest rate is now 11 1/2 per cent; not since July 1981 has it been that low. The Commonwealth Savings Bank interest rate for housing loans peaked at 13 1/2 per cent last year and that of the trading banks at 14 1/2 per cent. So, from a level of 13 1/2 per cent at the beginning of this year, the Commonwealth Savings Bank interest rate has now fallen by 2 per cent. The consequence of that for actual or potential home buyers holding a loan of $ 30,000 is a reduction in the monthly repayment of $44 or $11 a week. Naturally, this is welcomed by the Government, not only because of the direct stimulus that a fall in interest rates is likely to have on building activity, but also because a fall in interest rates of that magnitude relieves a very significant proportion of the population of a substantial financial commitment which will then be available for expenditure in other areas and generate additional employment by adding to total demand.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Resources and Energy . On the basis of one tonne of uranium oxide producing 1.9 kilograms of weapons grade plutonium when reprocessed after use in a so-called peaceful nuclear electric power station-and that, Mr President, is I think a generally accepted figure-does the Minister agree that the conservative estimate of 1.2 million tonnes of recoverable uranium oxide at Roxby Downs would produce 2.28 million kilograms of plutonium? Is the Minister aware that six kilograms of plutonium will produce a dirty, Hiroshima-size nuclear weapon? Is the Minister further aware that the International Atomic Energy Agency safeguards inspectors allow a 1 to 1.5 per cent loss of plutonium without considering that a breach of safeguards has occurred, and I understand that Australia subscribes to that view , so that at least one per cent of the Roxby Downs plutonium, that is, 22,800 kilograms, is completely outside nuclear safeguards agreements and that this plutonium would produce 3,800-I repeat, 3,800-dirty, high fall-out, Hiroshima- size nuclear weapons? I reiterate that that is outside the safeguards agreement-
—Order! Will the honourable senator ask his question?

—Does the Minister not agree that even one nuclear weapon made from Australian uranium is one too many and that the only way to avoid up to 3, 800 weapons being made from Roxby Downs uranium without a breach of safeguards agreements is to refuse to mine and export this uranium at all? Short of that, what is the Government going to do about tightening up safeguards to prevent the sort of scenario I have described?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The amount of plutonium which could be produced if the entire uranium content of the Roxby Downs ore body was put through a nuclear reactor power plant is of the order of 2 million kilograms. Senator Mason had a slightly higher figure but I am not going to quibble about that. Several points ought to be made, however. One is that that plutonium is not separated from the other materials and until it is reprocessed is not potential atomic weapons material. Moreover, it is not of weapons grade. I will expand on that a little later.

ANSWER.PARA: A more important aspect, probably, of Senator Mason's question was whether the safeguards currently in operation are designed to or are guaranteed to be accurate to within a loss of 1 or 1 1/2 per cent. I am advised that the nuclear material balance for a reprocessing plant allows for an accountancy error of around one per cent, or is designed to keep any accountancy error to less than one per cent. There is, however, a back-up, or complementary safeguards measure which extends the containment and surveillance activity and has a goal aimed at detecting within 10 days the diversion of as much as 8 kilograms of plutonium, which is slightly more than the quantity which is required to make a nuclear device.

But to return to the question of weapons grade plutonium, the point there is that weapons grade plutonium is produced by very special operation of dedicated reactors involving very short irradiation of fuel. This would be totally uneconomic for power generation. If power reactors were to be operated in such a way, the safeguards procedures would detect that they had been programmed to operate in that way. Reactor grade plutonium contains a large proportion of higher isotopes of plutonium because of its long irradiation time. These isotopes render such material unsuitable for weapons production, although it is technically feasible with a high level of technical capacity and sophistication to produce nuclear devices from plutonium produced in a nuclear power reactor. It is technically feasible, but the link between the generation of atomic power and an atomic weapon is tortuous. Provided that the controls are strictly maintained, it is, to say the least, highly unlikely.

Finally, Mr President-I do not want to draw too long a bow with that-I have drawn attention to the tortuous and unlikely association of the operation of a power reactor and the production of an atomic weapon. Many other materials are used in the construction of an atomic weapon. Although I do not want to draw too long a bow, one could argue that none of those materials should be supplied either, lest they be misued for that purpose. In closing, I mention that the plutonium for the nuclear device detonated by India some years ago was, I understand, produced in a research reactor and not in a power reactor. I believe that it can be argued that a research reactor is more suitable for the production of plutonium for atomic weapons than is a power reactor.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Is the Minister aware that in 1977 the United States Government announced that it had successfully made and tested a small nuclear bomb made from reactor grade material?

—I was not aware of that specific fact. I have acknowledged that it is technically feasible to produce a nuclear device but that it would require a high level of technical sophistication to be able to do so. The linkage between the generation of power in a reactor and the detonation of a bomb is tortuous and, with the accountancy procedures and the back-up procedures to which I have already referred, it is highly unlikely.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Cook Sen P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister representing the Treasurer seen the article in yesterday's Melbourne Age headlined: 'Wage case gives shops 4.3 reasons to be jolly'? If he has, I ask him whether that article reports that the Victorian State Manager of Woolworths Ltd, Mr Ross Hanlon, said that:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . his chain was expecting retail sales to increase as a result of the national wage decision.
I ask the Minister whether the article reports Mr Hanlon as having gone on to say that:
There were already some signs that sales were increasing as a result of increased consumer confidence following the wage result.
Woolworths expected the trend to continue as the 4.3 per cent wage rise was paid to more workers.
I ask the Minister whether it is also true that the article reported the general manager of Myer corporation planning, Mr Neil Williams, as having said that:
. . . the national wage increase and a general levelling off in unemployment had contributed to rising consumer and business confidence which was being reflected in retail sales.

Do these comments reflect business confidence in the Labor Government's economic strategy and, in particular, in its wages policy? Is it not pleasing to see comments from the business community which appreciate the two-dimensional character of wages; namely, that while wages are a cost, wages also provide purchasing power for consumers?

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr President. Is it in order to ask a Minister whether something is pleasing? It seems to me to be a very strange question, one which is not related to the Minister's responsibilities.
—There is no point of order.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Cook in the final part of his question drew attention to a very important-I think 'two-dimensional' was the phrase he used-aspect of increases in incomes. On the one hand, they obviously add to potential total demand; on the other hand, they add to costs. The judgment of the Government, which is central to the prices and incomes policy, is that increases in demand should be transformed into higher levels of output and higher levels of employment instead of simply higher prices. That is, as has been stated many times before, central to this Government's economic strategy. I believe the present indications are, as Senator Cook's question suggested, that that economic strategy has been appreciated by the business community in general, and the business community has considerable confidence in it. In the early part of Senator Cook's question he asked whether I had noted the reports from a number of very prominent retailers. Yes, I have noted those reports.

ANSWER.PARA: I think it is beyond argument that anything which increases total demand when unemployment is at its present level in isolation must be regarded as a good thing and something that is ultimately likely to increase output and employment. Other factors, of course, can come into operation. A couple of weeks ago Professor John Nevile gave a paper at the Australian Labor economists' conference in Melbourne in which he analysed over the last six years what he saw as the primary cause of the continuing and deepening economic recession which has prevailed in Australia. His conclusion was that the paramount cause of that was a deficiency in total demand. I commend a study of that article to honourable senators on both sides of the House.

In closing, there are two dimensions to this matter, as Senator Cook's question stated. The crucial point is to ensure that increases in total fiscal demand, which are to be welcomed and are welcomed, are supplemented by a mechanism to ensure that that increase in nominal fiscal demand is tranformed into higher levels of output and higher levels of employment instead of simply into higher prices. It is that objective to which the Government's prices and incomes policy is, of course, directed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs been drawn to an article in the higher education section of today's Australian entitled 'Overseas students ''face considerable financial hardship'' '? Has the Minister seen or heard of a submission to the Federal Government from student groups at the University of New South Wales and Macquarie University calling for the abolition of the overseas student charge as a way of easing financial pressure on these students? Has the Minister noted that that submission also labels as obnoxious the claim made by the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, and restated by its Minister, Mr West, and the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs, Senator Ryan, that most overseas students came from wealthy families? The submission further claims that the fees are not only inequitable and discriminatory but, in the context of Australia's foreign relations and aid, irrational in the extreme? What action does the Minister intend to take to alleviate the problems of overseas students as explained in that submission?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did see that article in the Australian. In reply to Senator Lajovic's question I point out something which he may not be aware of although it has received great publicity. I refer to the fact that the Government has set up an inquiry into the whole question of overseas students-who they are, their circumstances, where they come from, whether we should change the way in which they are selected, whether the fee does indeed impose hardship, whether there is a case for having more free places, the matter of our foreign relations and the relationship of that consideration to making free places available in Australian universities, and so on. In fact, all of the factors which we need to take into account when considering the contribution we will make to our region particularly and to other areas, through the overseas student program is under consideration by an inquiry.

ANSWER.PARA: The inquiry is one in which the Department of Foreign Affairs, the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and my Department are participating, but the chairman of the inquiry is an independent chairman, Professor John Goldring from Macquarie University. The inquiry has started to take submissions. Obviously the submission referred to in Senator Lajovic's question and reported, to some extent, in the Australian today was one such submission. Obviously, it reflects the views of the people who made it. The inquiry will be taking into account the views of all organisations that have an interest in this matter. Of course, the Government has its own overall views about foreign policy, immigration and education matters. However, I cannot respond specifically at this stage to the question of what steps we will be taking to assist overseas students, although there will be such steps, because we will wait for the inquiry to report and then we will reshape the private overseas students program.

I should point out though-this is something that will be known to some honourable senators on the opposite side of the chamber-that that program does cost in excess of $70m a year. It is already a substantial contribution, if it is viewed as an aid program, which in some ways it certainly is, to our region. We have no intention of resiling from this level of commitment and indeed we may well increase it, but we are interested in all the questions that the inquiry is addressing. The inquiry will take into account the points raised in the New South Wales students' submission, as it will with all submissions that come before it. Obviously the Senate will be made aware of the recommendation when the Government has received a report from the inquiry and has made a response.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs. My question is prompted by an article in the Courier-Mail of 7 November , in which it is outlined that a qualified teacher of the deaf cannot obtain employment as a teacher in Queensland because he is deaf. Are hearing-impaired teachers of the deaf able to obtain employment as teachers in the Australian Capital Territory or in any State of Australia other than Queensland?

—I am advised by the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority that to be eligible for employment in Australian Capital Territory government schools persons must possess recognised teaching qualifications and meet residency and general medical standards. Hearing-impaired persons are not necessarily precluded from employment in Australian Capital Territory government schools on the basis of disability. I am not able at this stage to provide information about the provisions applying in the education systems in the States , but if Senator Colston wishes to bring to my attention more detailed information about this particular case, I shall try to get a more detailed reply for him. But in principle, hearing impairment is not in itself an obstacle to employment in the Australian Capital Territory teaching service.

—My question is directed to the Attorney-General. Did Mr Costigan or his officers intercept telex messages from Sydney solicitors Allen, Allen and Hemsley to solicitors in Singapore and Hong Kong, as was alleged in the Federal Court of Australia yesterday? If so, was the interception authorised , and by whom? If the interception was not authorised, what action will the Minister now take to ensure that unauthorised intercepts do not recur?
—Order! Before the Attorney-General answers the question, I draw his attention and that of the Senate to the fact that the matter was raised in the Federal Court of Australia yesterday.

—Although I think there are limits to the sub judice rules in the way in which they have sometimes been applied in this place, when a matter in issue is squarely one of those which a court is presently engaged in determining, it really would be quite inappropriate for me to put an answer on the public record even if I had one, which I do not.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Special Minister of State. It refers to the Government's current education and enrolment campaign. Did young people have any input into the actual formulation of the campaign aimed at youth? Is the overall campaign being evaluated while in progress to establish whether it is having the desired effect on young people and other targeted groups?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer in both cases is yes. Prior to the development of any advertising material, qualitative research was carried out among selected groups of young Australians, mainly in the 17 1/2 to 21 year age group, but also among those up to the age of 30. The results of this research have already been made public by the Australian Electoral Office in its research report entitled ' A qualitative analysis of attitudes towards enrolment and voting'. That report also details preliminary research among non-Australian and British subjects and among non-English speaking members of the community. As advertising material was being developed, all possible advertisements were subjected to similar rigorous research. Many more advertisements than are to be used were tested on the sample audiences. The final products chosen were those which generated the most positive reactions.

ANSWER.PARA: Concerning evaluation, it has to be remembered that there are influences on enrolment external to the campaign. There are habitation reviews, State elections and by-elections. There will be a change to the nationality qualification for enrolment as from 26 January next year. All of these things affect enrolment, so it could be almost impossible to say without hesitation that the campaign alone has resulted in this or that number of additions to the electoral rolls. Nevertheless, additions and changes to the rolls are being monitored. We do not expect that the campaign will result in a wholesale rush of people to become enrolled, but the campaign is designed to generate an awareness and an appreciation by the individual of the value of being able to take part in the democratic processes in the government of this country. Increased enrolment may well be gradual. But, for example, it is anticipated that there should be quite significant effects on the enrolment activity which will be triggered by the announcement of the closing of the rolls for the referendums on 25 February next year, and the electoral rolls will undoubtedly be in their best shape ever for the redistributions of 1984.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. It relates to the sex discrimination Green Paper on affirmative action in public and private employment, which the Minister promised the Senate would be available in about August to lie on the table to allow community comment. As nearly three months have now elapsed without sight of the paper, I ask the Minister whether she will now confirm that the Government has no intention of proceeding with the Green Paper in view of the vast problems that the Sex Discrimination Bill has encountered?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that I have received what one might call a loaded question. I do not consider that the sex discrimination legislation has encountered vast problems. What it has encountered is problems of time-tabling and the lack of co -operation of senators such as Senator Walters, who insisted on calling quorums throughout that section of yesterday's debate that was concerned with that legislation, which demonstrates that despite the general support from the Opposition for the spirit of the legislation, some members of the Opposition are determined to promote a filibuster.

ANSWER.PARA: Turning to the first part of the honourable senator's question, I assure her that a draft paper explaining the purposes, the mechanisms and the benefits to employers and to individual employees of affirmative action plans is well in hand. In fact, I have such a draft prepared at this stage, but I do not intend to make the draft public until the legislation is enacted. I can explain why that is so. All honourable senators will be aware of the fact that there has been sometimes a deliberate attempt to confuse-I think sometimes the confusion is genuine-the provisions of the sex discrimination legislation with the objectives of affirmative action. They are two separate kinds of programs.

The sex discrimination legislation, as honourable senators will know-I shall not take up the time of the Senate on that now-simply provides a mechanism for complaint and redress by an individual who has been discriminated against. The affirmative action proposal will require major employers to remove obstacles to equal opportunity that exist within their organisations. Those obstacles will be identified by them. Time-tables will be identified by them. But they will be required to report to the Human Rights Commission about the progress that they have made in removing obstacles to equal opportunity for their female employees. This is something that applies to public and private employment. It is a rather separate kind of proposal from the complaint mechanism and redress mechanism that is being established under the legislation. Because there has been confusion on the subject in the minds of some people-confusion that could be represented no more clearly than in the case of Senator Walters herself and her comments both in this place and on the media-I have decided that it is sensible to complete the debate on the legislation and then proceed to have public discussion about affirmative action.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Has the Minister seen the report in last week's National Times to the effect that my speech on 13 October on corruption in the Department of Foreign Affairs and my question relative to the irregular appointment by Mr Henderson to the Department of the son of Sir Robert Sparkes were cut out of the Department's magazine Backgrounder? Does this act indicate censorship by some person or persons within that Department? What was the cost, via wastage, of the exercise?

—I will refer that question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs for a detailed reply, but I have no doubt that the basic consideration motivating the removal of that material from the Foreign Affairs Backgrounder was a quite legitimate and understandable desire not to slur unnecessarily and improperly the reputation of people who have been put under suspicion in this place.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer to the Government's recent decision to allow two Marxist organisations to open offices in Australia. Is the Government aware that the leader of the South West African People's Organisation, Mr Sam Nujoma, is on record as saying that he is interested not in majority rule but in seizing power by force? Secondly, is the Government aware that the African National Congress recently claimed full responsibility for a bomb attack in Pretoria which resulted in the death of 18 people, and 213 people being injured, many of whom were civilians, including children? Is the Minister aware of the Denton United States Senate Committee report on terrorism and security, which was published in November last year? I ask the Minister whether he is aware that on page 3 of that document the following statement appears:

QUESTION.PARA: On the staff's return from southern Africa it was clear that a great quantity of evidence was indeed available to demonstrate the validity of the allegations that the Soviet Union had successfully penetrated and, in large measure, taken over the control of the ANC and SWAPO.

Does the Government believe that these Soviet-backed terrorists are more acceptable to the Australian people and their way of life than innocent amateur black and white sportsmen and sports- women from South Africa?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs announced in the last week of October that the African National Congress and the South West Africa People's Organisation would be allowed to establish information offices in Australia. An Australian resident, said to be the Pan-Africanist Congress representative, already operates an information office in this country. The Government's position on this can be further spelt out as follows: The African liberation movements already maintain offices in a number of Western and Third World countries. Their primary function is to disseminate information on apartheid and , to a large extent, counter the propaganda put out by the South African Government. It is true that SWAPO, the ANC and the PAC have each at times perpetrated acts of violence which have been properly condemned by this and previous governments.

ANSWER.PARA: While not condoning the arms struggle, the Government nevertheless understands why opponents of apartheid have turned to it. The Government believes, and has said so over and over again, as, to give him his credit, did Mr Fraser, the previous Prime Minister, that apartheid itself is the root cause of the escalation in tension, in confrontation and violence in South Africa. Any liberation movement offices that are established in Australia will not be granted a privileged status; nor will their staff be given any special standing. They will have to abide fully by Australian laws. The Government would require and obtain an undertaking from any ANC and SWAPO representatives seeking to come to Australia that they would not advocate violent means of obtaining change. The Government would retain the right to withdraw permission to stay in Australia from any representative who failed to respect such an undertaking. No definite proposals for the establishment of ANC or SWAPO offices, however, have yet been presented to the Government. Should the Minister care to comment on some of the other more tendentious matter in Senator Jessop's question, I will draw the honourable senator's question to his attention and give him the opportunity to do so.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question without notice is directed to the Minister for Education. I preface it by alluding to Senator Walters's contribution to the debate last night on the Sex Discrimination Bill in which, amongst other things, when referring to a small country town in Tasmania, she said:

QUESTION.PARA: Seventy books, including the New Testament and the Old Testament, other religious stories and animal books, were removed from a Tasmanian school library and destroyed on the ground of their being sexist. Is that not an appalling indictment of the Bill? Is that not an appalling indictment of this international Convention?

TALK.START.PARA: —A dorothy dixer.

—It is not. I ask: Is it a fact that the Tasmanian Liberal Minister for Education, Mr Max Bingham, has completely and utterly repudiated that version of events? Is it a fact that he completely exonerated the librarian concerned? Were many books, in fact, removed from the library during a normal culling operation on the simple ground of being outworn and deteriorating from much handling? Can the Minister assure the chamber that none of this hysterical deception and charges of book burning have any basis whatsoever in the Bill or the Convention?

—I understand that Senator Tate's suggestion that the Minister for Education in Tasmania, Mr Bingham, has totally repudiated that newspaper account is the case and that he has repudiated the suggestion that there was any politically inspired motive in removing old books to get new books in stock. I do not have that information in writing from him, but I have information that he has repudiated that bizarre story that appeared in the newspaper. I would like to comment on the implication in Senator Walters's claim about this bizarre story last night that it had some relationship with the United Nations Convention. There is absolutely nothing in the United Nations Convention, and certainly nothing in this Government's policies or legislation, which would promote or justify any such bizarre behaviour.

—The Attorney-General may be aware that in the last two days leading up to the 1980 general election I was subjected to the most dishonest and extravagant advertising campaign ever conducted by the Liberal Party in Western Australia. The matter of misleading political advertising was then taken on appeal to the High Court which ruled, in effect, that there is no law to prevent dishonest or misleading political advertising in Australia. In view of that I ask the Attorney-General: What steps will the Government take to prevent blatantly dishonest and misleading advertisements by politicians or political parties to win support for themselves or odium for their political opponents?

—There is undoubtedly a good deal of competition for the title which Senator Jack Evans conferred upon himself as having been the subject of the most dishonest and extravagant advertising campaign ever conducted by the Liberal Party in Western Australia because there have been many predecessors as subjects for such campaigns. It is well acknowledged that there are problems in the state of the law as, indeed, Senator Evans discovered when he litigated in a famous case before the High Court against another honourable senator in this place to discover the scope of the then section 161E of the Commonwealth Electoral Act. The present Government, in response to that revealed deficiency in the present electoral law, which at the moment allows deceptive and misleading and thoroughly false and scurrilous advertising to take place, has brought forward remedial measures in the Commonwealth Electoral Legislation Amendment Bill which is now before the Parliament and will shortly be in this place. In that respect, I refer the attention of the honourable senator to clause-
—Will it be retrospective?

—It is not retrospective, regrettably. I refer honourable senators to clause 114 with its new section 161 of the Electoral Act and some accompanying further provisions in clauses 136 and 138 of the Commonwealth Electoral Legislation Amendment Bill that is proposed which deal with the question of injunctions. The basic object of the exercise and of these new clauses is to enable action to be taken-particularly during campaigns, by means of injunctions as the preferred remedy, rather than challenging election results after the votes are in-to have struck out and prohibited advertisements which contain erroneous statements of fact and which are, in fact, designed or likely to be misleading or deceptive. The intention is not to rule out misleading or erroneous comment or opinion because to do so would obviously be to scrub out a considerable proportion of election puffery that runs during campaigns. But the intention is to address the particular matter to which Senator Jack Evans refers . There will, of course, be a full opportunity to debate that and other clauses of this Bill in this place.

—Is the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs aware of a report appearing in the Canberra Times this morning of a meeting of parents of non-government school pupils held in Sydney on Monday last? Has the Minister's attention been drawn to a statement attributed to Senator Peter Baume at that meeting, that the Minister had 'chosen to confuse school assets, often built up over generations, with the income needed every month to keep a school running'? Does Senator Baume's statement amount to a gross misrepresentation of Government policy?

—My attention has been drawn to the Canberra Times report of Senator Baume's statement in Sydney on Monday night. I can vouch for the authenticity of that report because I have seen a television film of Senator Baume making that very allegation. As all honourable senators in this place will know, the criteria used to determine which non-government schools would have their grants reduced by 25 per cent in 1984 had nothing to do with assets. The determination was made solely on the basis of their cash income per pupil from private sources alone after allowing for debt servicing and earmarked capital funds. Those schools that have income from private sources equal to about 95 per cent or more of government school recurrent costs per pupil had their 1984 Commonwealth grants reduced. There was no use of school assets in determining this year's funding formula. Senator Baume knows that to be the case because the funding formula was made public and was sent to all the schools which were to be affected by the decision. But not only that, Senator Baume sought information about how that particular budgetary decision, the formula, was arrived at, from the Commonwealth Schools Commission, under the provisions of the Freedom of Information Act. So Senator Baume was in no doubt that assets were not taken into account in asserting the formula, yet before an audience of 5,000 people, as the newspaper report has it, he implied that assets had been taken into account.
—No, I did not, Minister. I did not say that. You are misinterpreting it.

—Senator Baume deliberately gave the impression, and indeed succeeded in giving the impression, that assets had been used in the determination of the formula whereas he had in his possession, after seeking details under the Freedom of Information Act, information to the contrary. One has to ask why the Opposition spokesperson on education is prepared to behave publicly in such a totally dishonest way.

—My question is addressed to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. I have noted her criticism previously and during this Question Time of those who have criticised the Sex Discrimination Bill. Is it a fact that she has now indicated that she will move on behalf of the Government more than 50 amendments to the Bill which she introduced by that name? Does she expect to move any further amendments beyond those she has already indicated will be moved on behalf of the Government? Further, does she agree that it would speed up consideration of the Bill if it were withdrawn and redrafted, incorporating the many amendments which the Government has now found it must make to make the Bill a reasonable piece of legislation, in the Government's view? Withdrawal and redrafting would obviate the need for a Committee debate on the more than 50 amendments of which she has already given notice. If she does agree to that, why is she not withdrawing the Bill and presenting it in proper form to the Senate for consideration?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is interesting indeed when in government to engage in an exercise of consultation and seeking co-operation on an important piece of legislation for which I believe, and many people in the community believe, there ought to be bipartisan support. When I introduced the Sex Discrimination Bill, I deliberately left it lying on the table for some time, saying while I did so that it was the Government's intention-because this was such an important piece of legislation and new, federally, although various States have had it for many years without this amazing performance that we have seen from some people here- to discuss the legislation with the Opposition and with the Australian Democrats , who I might say have been very co-operative, and with all interested parties so that we could make amendments, clarifications or elucidations in the Bill and therefore have a piece of legislation which is associated with Australia's commitment to an international convention, a convention signed by the Opposition when it was in government, and so that we could have a piece of human rights legislation for which we could all feel support.

ANSWER.PARA: Having engaged in all sincerity and good faith in this process of consultation, having taken on board suggestions for improvements, clarifications and so on--

TALK.START.PARA: —From Chaney.

—From Senator Chaney, amongst other people, including the Australian Democrats and other interested parties-we are now being accused of ineptness and incompetence for continuing with the legislation in a form which will require a number of amendments.
—It would facilitate consideration if you would just redraft it.

—I would like to be able to attribute to Senator Chaney the same sincerity with regard to his comments on wishing to facilitate the passage of the Bill as I and my colleagues had when we brought the Bill before the Senate. We have considered the possibility of withdrawing the Bill and redrafting it to incorporate the amendments but after lengthy discussion with Parliamentary Counsel officers and other relevant experts we decided it would not facilitate debate and discussion. Honourable senators will wish to discuss particular amendments, and are entitled to do so. I believe the form in which the Bill has been presented, with the amendments incorporated into the text, clearly set out in different type faces and so on--
—The same as the FOI Bill.

—The same as the FOI Bill. It is a clear presentation of the Government's intentions and a useful indication of the amendments we have made as a result of the consultation process. The matter will be facilitated if honourable senators opposite adopt a serious and constructive approach to a piece of legislation which, after all, they say on an official level they are not opposing.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. The Minister did not respond to that part of my question in which I asked her whether she expected to introduce any further amendments beyond those of which she has already given us notice.

—We never believe that anything is set in concrete until the Senate has finished dealing with it but I do not expect there will be any substantive amendments. It may be that in the course of the many debates there may be some minor improvements that I and my colleagues will be happy to accept.
—Do you expect them?

—We have no further substantive amendments and I am not aware of any being proposed. If the Opposition has amendments which do not undermine in any way the thrust and purpose of the Bill then, as always, we will have an open response to them.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ROYAL COMMISSION ON THE ACTIVITIES OF THE FEDERATED SHIP PAINTERS AND DOCKERS UNION

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Attorney-General. Is he aware of the concern expressed on the AM program on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation this morning about the future of the investigations being carried out by the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union? In particular, is he aware of the query raised in the program about the Government's failure to express adequate support and confidence in the Royal Commissioner? How does the Attorney respond to such claims of concern and queries as outlined in the program?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has to be said that the AM commentary this morning was somewhat one-sided and muddled, as a lot of commentary has been so far, not surprisingly since most people who have chosen to leap into the public domain have not yet seen the details of the Bill which is to be tabled in this Parliament tomorrow. As to the particular question of the transitional arrangements, I have made it quite clear-as clear as one can possibly do-that there will be a smooth transition from the work of Mr Costigan and his commission to the new National Crimes Authority. Indeed, consequential amendments legislation to be introduced tomorrow, along with the major parent Bill, is specifically designed to facilitate that smooth transition by making provisions for the transfer of information where appropriate from the existing Royal Commission to the new Authority. In announcing the Australian Labor Party' s decision on Monday, I said in the statement issued jointly with the Special Minister of State:

ANSWER.PARA: The Government believes that the proposed Authority will meet the major objectives and concerns that have emerged during the public debate on the Crimes Commission issue over the last six months . . .
One of the points we listed as a concern that would be met is:
The need to maintain intact the resources and expertise of the Costigan Royal Commission, and to ensure the continuation of its work;
In our statement-this is all to demonstrate that there is no ground for misapprehension, or should not be, in the newspaper and public commentaries so far-we further said on Monday:

It is proposed that, subject to further consultation, the Costigan Royal Commission complete any outstanding reports early in the New Year but not be formally wound up until at least 30 April 1984 in order to enable an efficient transfer of staff, materiel and ongoing investigations to the new body.

I make it clear that a number of investigations, having a life span of anywhere between three months and three years, are presently being actively pursued by the Costigan Commission and in a great many of those cases it would manifestly be quite irresponsible to wind up the Costigan Commission without making provision for the ongoing character of those investigations. As to the question of confidence in the Royal Commissioner, I make it clear again, as I said at the Press conference on Monday, that Mr Costigan has and continues to enjoy the complete confidence of the Government in the conduct of his present commission.

I take this opportunity to dissociate myself and the Government completely from the comments made by the honourable member for Prospect, Dr Klugman, in the House of Representatives yesterday. There is no foundation whatsoever for any suggestion that Mr Costigan is or has been engaging in any form of blackmail or indeed in anything other than an entirely reasonable and public- spirited desire to ensure the continued effectiveness in this country of the fight against organised crime.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs.
