In answer to a dorothy dix question in the Senate yesterday by Senator Crowley, the Minister made a feeble attempt to justify the Government's policy on independent schools. In the long statement that Senator Ryan made there was no reference at all to the central, that is the previously established, principles of government funding of non-government schools, the basic grant, the funding nexus and the ability for newly registered schools to gain the established capital grants.
—Order! Will the honourable senator ask his question and not make statements?

—Why does the Minister continually evade these central principles which are the bases of the recent protests and the public uproar? Why does the Minister evade attending public meetings, such as the one in Sydney on Monday at which 5,000 people protested against these very principles being abandoned?

—In answer to the last part of Senator Teague's question, it is rather difficult for me to attend public meetings which are organised specifically on dates on which I am unable to attend. As I have said publicly, the organisers of the meeting for Monday night in the Sydney Town Hall contacted my office before they established the date and asked whether I would be available on that date. When they were told that I would not be available they proceeded to organise the meeting for that date. Clearly they did not wish me to be present at that meeting. They achieved that objective.
—What about Ballarat next week?
—Order! The Minister is answering the question.
—See you in Ballarat.
—I should inform the Senate that I have no rendezvous arranged with Senator Harradine in Ballarat.
—You have been invited to speak at Ballarat.
—It is very interesting that Senator Harradine indicates that he is closely associated with the people who are organising meetings specially set up for me not to appear at.
—The National Civic Council paid his expenses, just like it paid his election expenses.
—Mr President, I rise to call for Senator Grimes to withdraw what he has just said. Senator Grimes said that my expenses had been paid for by the people organising this meeting in Sydney.
—I did not. I said it was the National Civic Council.
—Well, I ask that Senator Grimes withdraw that also. It is a reflection on my integrity as a member of parliament.

—I happily withdraw the fact that I said Senator Harradine's expenses to go to Sydney were paid for by the National Civic Council. I note that he did not ask me to withdraw the fact that I said his election expenses were paid for by the National Civic Council.
—That is also totally incorrect. It shows how advanced the Minister's knowledge of the political situation is. I ask that Senator Grimes withdraw that remark also.
—I ask the Minister to withdraw that statement.
—If there is something offensive about the National Civic Council paying expenses, I withdraw.
—I ask the Minister to withdraw.
—I withdraw.
—I call the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs.

—Senator Teague, in the first part of his question, asked why, in answer to Senator Crowley's question yesterday, I did not discuss our view on matters such as the nexus and so on. The reason is that on many occasions in this Senate, not to mention in many other forums throughout the countryside, I have set out our Government's funding policies. I do not really think that at this stage of Question Time I should go through it all again. I simply refer Senator Teague to the education funding guidelines which clearly set out our reasons for changing the funding formula, and our objectives and justification for doing so and to the many other occasions in this Senate on which I have set them out.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The uproar in the Senate today is only a reflection of the uproar of the public on this matter. Why does the Minister evade not only at public meetings but also in her answers in the Senate the basic principles that are of concern to the public of Australia and this Senate? Why does the Minister evade giving answers?
—I have nothing further to add.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

PROCTEXT.PARA: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Harradine proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The divisive and potentially destructive character of the pivotal funding guidelines issued by the Minister for Education, Senator Ryan, to the Australian Schools Commission concerning non-government schools.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: — The cause of education justice in Australia has been set back two decades by the actions of the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan) and by her guidelines issued to the Australian Schools Commission-those pivotal guidelines referred to in the matter of public importance. By the late 1960s, after 80 years struggle, particularly by parents who chose to send their children to non-government schools, all major parties recognised the principle that parents have the right to choose the type of education and the type of school most suited to their children and to have returned certain of the taxes earmarked for education as an essential to the free exercise of that choice. Limited and qualified though the recognition of that principle was, it was accepted. The principle of the basic grant was accepted as was additional help in respect of needs. Indeed, by 1967 a nexus, a link, was established between the grants to non-government schools and the cost per pupil in government schools; in other words, the government school standard cost nexus. This removed from political manipulation an exercise of education justice by parents. It removed from the political whim of the Minister their rights to exercise that freedom of choice. Many parents had to make, and continue to make, great sacrifices in the exercise of that choice.

SPEECH.PARA: True education justice has not been achieved. Only 13 per cent of the Australian education budget is spent on the 25 per cent of the school population in non-government schools. Ten years ago it would have been unthinkable for a meeting of 5,000 people to be held in the Sydney Town Hall, overflowing into Sydney Square. But such a meeting was held as part of the outcry against the deliberate striking at the heart of these principles by the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs, Senator Ryan. Senator Ryan's guidelines issued to the Commonwealth Schools Commission reflect her views, which she subsequently made public in the Canberra Times of 26 September 1983. In that newspaper she is reported as saying:
The view that parents who choose non-government schooling for their children had a right or entitlement to government funding of that choice because they were taxpayers was a specious argument.

Senator Ryan has destroyed the educational consensus that had developed by the late 1960s, albeit because of political pressure. So this vast outcry is building up throughout the whole length and breadth of Australia. On Monday night, 5,000 people in Sydney carried a resolution, the first paragraph of which stated:

That this meeting applauds the spirit of co-operation and unity that has been shown by all parents in the Non-Government school sector, from all schools, Catholic and Non-Catholic, at all levels, in the face of the concerted and consistent attack presently being mounted against the right of freedom of choice in education and condemns the arbitrary action of the Government in discriminating against some children and causing uncertainty and apprenhension in the minds of parents and children alike.

Ten years ago it would have been inconceivable that such a meeting could have taken place and, much less, that it should have been necessary. But necessary it was because the parents are becoming most concerned that their rights are subject to political whim, to the whim of whatever Minister happens to be in power, and to political manipulation. There will be further meetings. I know of one that will be held in Bourke on Friday night and another which will be held at Ballarat in a fortnight's time, on 22 November. Senator Ryan has been invited to speak to the latter meeting. I have been invited to that meeting and I have accepted. That is why I said I hoped to see her there.

How destructive are the guidelines? The matter of public importance says that the guidelines are divisive. Patently the Minister's actions have been divisive. The matter of public importance also says that the guidelines are potentially destructive. Certainly, they have destroyed the educational consensus that had been built up over the years, that took out of the political arena the divisive sectarian debate that plagued this country for two decades before a certain degree of educational justice was achieved by 1969. The spectre of that sectarian debate has been raised by the Minister again, and by nobody else. Of course that is destructive of the type of consensus that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) talked about when he went to the people earlier this year. I am sure that he did not know what the end result of all this would be. Certainly the guidelines are destructive of the consensus. However, in the words of the Central Commission of Catholic Bishops of Australia, Senator Ryan's pivotal guideline is potentially destructive to the non-government school sector.

Why has Senator Ryan taken this action? Why has she issued the guidelines? A number of excuses have been given. However, let me describe the pivotal funding guidelines that are referred to in my matter of public importance. First of all, the Minister in her guidelines has broken the nexus or the link between per pupil grants for non-government schoolchildren and the cost of educating children in government schools. That link will no longer exist; it is gone. Grants for 1984 have been made on the basis of a completely arbitrary Government decision. The Minister gave a most specious reason for disconnecting the nexus. In paragraph 31 of the guidelines the Minister says:
. . . it does not redistribute sufficiently between schools on the basis of need . . .
That is patently nonsense. Surely the existing categorisation system recognised the differences in needs, if that is a concept with which she adheres.

TALK.START.PARA: —The key word is 'sufficient'.

—That is precisely what I was going to say. If she considered that certain children were not receiving a sufficient return she should have addressed that problem, but she should have maintained the current situation while she was doing that and, on an interim basis if you like, she should have improved the lot of the needier. But, no, she did not do that. She broke the nexus and left education justice to the whim of political manipulation. The nexus has little to do with distribution but everything to do with seeing that all grants, including needs supplements, rise automatically each year. But she has broken that nexus; that has gone.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister announced that in 1984 there would be a reduction of 25 per cent in the per capita grants to children in 41 schools in Australia. These schools are all protestant schools-mostly boarding schools. She stated that the moneys would be going to level three schools which, as everybody knows, and as she said , are mostly Catholic schools. This is a most provocative and divisive statement . It is one that has been rejected by Catholic parents right throughout Australia and by the Catholic Commission of Bishops, because they know something that Senator Ryan apparently does not know when she tries to rob Peter to pay Paul. They know that Peter and Paul happen to be brothers in the same faith, something that apparently she does not comprehend.

Poor Catholic schools have been used as an excuse for this action. As I have said, if something had to be done, surely it could have been done without breaking the nexus. The Minister has broken the nexus and that has put at risk not only the schools that are directly affected now but also each and every single school from here on out. Furthermore, Catholic schools have been painted by her, and unfortunately I believe yesterday were categorised by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) also as poor Catholic schools. A public impression has been created by this Government that we are somehow improverished, that we are somehow substandard. I believe that it is a disgrace and harmful to the future quality of education to have that sort of impression created in the minds of people.

TALK.START.PARA: —They don't knock back the grants, though.

—That is a pathetic statement by Senator Tate. He would not know. He has no children, let alone any children attending schools. Nor does he have to fork out money for school fees. As I said before, this is a question of parents' rights to choose the type of education most suited to their children. That is what it is all about. The end result of Senator Ryan's actions is integration. Her hand picked Radford Committee made this recommendation relating to integration:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the only realistic approach to take is to envisage integration . . . on the basis of priority and need, of private schools into the public sector. A possible strategy might involve a target to achieve the integration of schools by the time of the Australian bicentenary in 1988 or by the end of the decade. The A.C.T. could provide a 'laboratory' to test the concept of integration so that a possible national implementation might be considered by the Commonwealth and States.

That is what it is all about. That was the decision taken by the Radford Committee, which was hand picked by Senator Ryan, this year. That was its statement; that was its report. Senator Ryan, forced by the Prime Minister of Australia, who in turn was forced by the outcry in Canberra against that proposition, had to distance this Government from that Committee's report. The Minister should have resigned at that stage because through her actions she has herself attacked principles that are very dear to the hearts of parents and that she cannot ultimately take away. Of course she has been prodded into doing this by the New South Wales Teachers Federation. She has appointed Mr Van Davey to the Commission. She has appointed to the Commission at least three people who have themselves played, and whose organisations have played, an active role in the anti-State aid campaigns. She has refused to appoint one representative of non-government school parents, not one, and that is where the right lies-in the hearts and in the souls of the parents.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the Catholic Education Commission?
—And she took one off.
—Yes, she took one off. Whilst I am on that subject, this is not an argument between non-government schools and government schools. After all , I am a product of a government primary bush school.
—What does that mean?

—I suppose many of my voters, if not the majority, are in that category. No, it is not an argument between non-government and government schools. There will be pressures on those schools also. Senator Ryan has denied parental rights. How has she done this? She has employed a sectarian device, and the typical capitalist ploy of economic blackmail, which is unworthy of a Labor Minister. She would not know what that means. She has appointed Van Davey, and I ask her to deny whether Mr Van Davey, of the Commonwealth Schools Commission, has said that the Schools Commission must for 1985 put forward to the Minister as one of its options, the zero option, that is, no funding for non-government schools. Her appointee to the Schools Commission has said that within the last three weeks and has insisted.
—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Education and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter of public importance which has been brought before the Senate today by Senator Harradine is extraordinary in its hypocrisy. Senator Harradine has taken it upon himself in this debate to speak of the divisive and potentially destructive character of the education funding guidelines of this Government. The only divisive aspect of these series of episodes which we have been witnessing lately are those which have been organised by Senator Harradine and his anti-Labor colleagues.
—That is totally incorrect.
—What about the bishops? Are you saying they are incorrect?
—Order! Senator Harradine was given a fair go and I want Senator Ryan to be given a fair go. I call the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs.

—An objective observer of the current debate on education in this country, and the debate to which Senator Harradine has just made a predictable contribution, must be astounded by what is going on. We have in Australia nearly 10,000 schools. We have 7,556 government schools and 2,312 non-government schools. All of those schools, with the exception of 41, received in the Budget we introduced additional funds from the Hawke Labor Government. Not only this, but the pupils in all of those schools, including the 41, will receive considerable benefits from a whole range of new programs which will be administered by the Commonwealth Schools Commission. In the light of that, one would think overwhelming, evidence of our Government's support for pupils in all schools, it must be absolutely astounding to the objective observer that we have these debates and allegations about discrimination, rights being intruded upon, potential destructiveness and all the other melodramatic nonsense to which the Government and the general public is being subjected.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the time has come to ask what is going on, who was behind the meeting organised at the Sydney Town Hall on Monday night and what are their real objectives? I should make it clear that I am not wishing to attribute any insincere motives to the majority of people who attended that meeting. Clearly, they had been alarmed by fallacious and mischievous interpretations of government policy. No doubt they went in good faith to express their anxieties. However, a few questions have to be asked at this stage. Why was the meeting organised specifically on a date on which I told them I would be unable to attend? If the organisers and the people participating in the meeting had a genuine desire to discuss aspects of education policy about which they felt concerned, why did they greet the contribution of my colleague, the State Minister for Education in New South Wales, Ron Mulock, who has also been extremely supportive of the non-government school sector, as I and this Government have been, with slow clapping and jeers? That kind of behaviour hardly suggests that the organisers, at least, were interested in a genuine discussion about, admittedly, complex problems of finding equitable funding and support formulas for all Australian schools at a time of economic hardship. We know Senator Harradine's motives. They are what they have been for a very long time. They are aimed at eroding the Labor forces in this country and the Labor Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr President. Since I cannot say what I would like to say in response to that I draw your attention to the state of the House. (Quorum formed)

—There seems to be some sort of campaign now being developed that I am unwilling to meet and discuss matters of education policy with the non- government sector. At this point I table a list of meetings that I have had with a very wide range of non-government organisations, all of them major non- government organisations, in the past few months. Of course, those meetings are part of an ongoing program of meetings that I have had and will continue to have with these organisations. I have had very favourable and constructive discussions at all of them. I table that list of meetings and the names of the organisations with which I have met.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, it is of great concern to Senator Harradine and his echo in News Weekly, Santamaria, that the Catholic education commissions are, in fact, extremely supportive of our needs-based approach to education. They are extremely appreciative of our new programs such as the participation in equity program.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are about as up to date as--

—Senator Harradine has just treated us to a diatribe about how our real intention is to take over all schools. One could find almost word for word what Senator Harradine has just said in this article by B. A. Santamaria in News Weekly. That would not surprise anybody in this place. I will table that article too. Senator Harradine made one remark in leading off in this debate with which I totally agree. Senator Harradine said that in Australia true education justice has not been achieved. I can only concur with that. That is precisely the reason why our Government has introduced new programs, has increased funding for the needier schools and has adopted a different way of funding the non-government sector. We are concerned with educational justice in contrast with our predecessors. We are concerned with equity. We are concerned with the poor parish schools. Senator Harradine took offence at the reference by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to poor parish schools. I can assure Senator Harradine that there are many such schools. I have visited them in New South Wales, in the western suburbs of Sydney such as Marrickville, for example, and in Melbourne, Perth--
—In Adelaide.

—Yes, indeed, I visited a very poor little school in Adelaide. It is doing a wonderful job with students, all from non-English speaking families, including a lot of new Asian refugees. Nuns are battling in extraordinarily difficult circumstances, with a little bit of bitumen and concrete playground and with no proper resources for the teaching of English to these migrant children. They have no back-up facilities to enable them to have consultation with the parents and so on who are also experiencing high levels of unemployment and difficulties with the English language. There is, as Senator Harradine seems not to be aware, a whole range of schools which are poor and which have my total sympathy, my total support and the support of our Government. I admit that I place a higher priority on visiting such schools and discussing the problems with the nuns who run them and the parents of the children who attend them than on meeting with the representatives of the 41 best resourced schools in this country. I have met with and I have had discussions with the representatives of such schools. I have no objection to meetings or discussions with representatives of those schools. But if Senator Harradine wants to know where my priorities lie, I should state that they do not lie with meetings with the representatives of the 41 best resourced schools in this country which have the support of some of the richest people in this community.

SPEECH.PARA: My priorities do lie with those poor schools like the little school in the electorate of Port Adelaide that I visited recently. I make no pretence about that. That is where my priorities lie and that is where this Government's priorities lie. This is a Labor Government. This Government has been elected on a platform of redistributing wealth, power and opportunity so that the disadvantaged in the community can have a fair go. When we act according to those principles it seems to provoke great amazement and all kinds of wild allegations and accusations. We are determined to provide better educational opportunities for all Australian children. We are acting to carry out this determination. Our record is good. Senator Harradine chose to take a slightly historical approach to the development of aid for non-government schools in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Historical or hysterical?

—It was slightly ahistorical, actually. I can only remind the Senate that at the time when the Whitlam Labor Government was elected the parish school system in Australia was about to collapse. Every Catholic education commission in this country will confirm that claim. Now it is stronger, larger, growing and in a much better position than it was at the time when the Whitlam Government came into office because, under the Whitlam Government, the needs- based education policy was established, the Schools Commission was set up and, under the ministry of Kim Beazley, a whole range of new programs, resources, teacher training opportunities and all of the facilities that are necessary for upgrading education were introduced. Until that time, under the previous conservative administrations, there had been no consideration or concern given to the poorer schools in the non-government sector. I think that that fact of education history in this country bears repetition at this stage and bears repetition to those representatives of the 41 schools who suffered a very modest reduction in their Commonwealth grant so that, at least, we can have a debate in terms of real information about what has happened.

SPEECH.PARA: I also point out to the Senate that this Government took office at a time of record unemployment. The unemployment of youth is a national scandal. Honourable senators know that I recently visited northern Europe for the purposes of discussions and getting some directions about youth employment training programs . All developed countries of course have problems of unemployment, and all developed countries have the problems of unemployed youth. But no country that I visited in Western Europe has anything like 25 per cent of its young people unemployed. Countries in Scandinavia are appalled at having three or four per cent unemployment, but we inherited a situation where about 25 per cent of our teenagers are on the dole. I think that Senator Harradine, as he wishes to present himself as some sort of representative of the disadvantaged people in our community, should address himself to that problem. One of the reasons why we have this very high level of youth unemployment, which is much higher than the levels of Sweden, Norway, Denmark, West Germany or Austria, is that our education system has not been providing proper education opportunities for all children. Most of those unemployed teenagers come from the poorer schools, government and non-government, and they are the first objects of our concern.

I think it is time that not only Senator Harradine but also Senator Peter Baume and the other members of the Opposition and the 5,000 parents who turned up at the Sydney Town Hall, gave some views about what their response is to the fact that we have this huge unemployment rate and this huge discrepancy vis-a-vis the opportunities available to the children who attend those 41 schools. All of the children attending schools in group 1 and group 2 have excellent opportunities. They are opportunities that we do not wish to see reduced in any way and which will not be reduced in any way. But when one compares their opportunities and their subsequent opportunities for higher education, for employment and for contributing and participating in this society, with the opportunities of those children in the poorest non-government and government schools, who are facing an ever lengthening dole queue, I think it is really appalling that all we hear from the Opposition and from Senator Baume is constant harping on the fact that 41 schools have lost a small amount of their Commonwealth grant.

I remind the Senate that the purpose of our education funding policy is to improve educational opportunities for children, be they in government or non- government schools. We brought down a Budget which gave a 3 per cent real increase to the category 3 schools-the schools about which Senator Harradine expresses concern-and that increase was larger by $4m than what those schools would have got under the previous percentage link formula. It is not politically possible and it was not socially possible for us to continue with a formula which gave as much to the better off schools as it gave to the poorer schools. It is not possible for us because we are interested in improving the opportunities of the children in the poorer schools. We are interested in equity and in participation. Therefore, we could not continue a formula which simply maintained the discrepancies between the schools that can provide everything that children need in terms of their educational opportunities and the schools which are unable to provide, despite the best efforts of the teachers, adequate educational opportunities. For that reason we decided not to continue with the percentage link formula but to introduce a different policy, a needs based policy. I am amazed at why this seems to be causing such consternation. Any suggestion that there will be less funding for the non-government school sector from a needs basis than there was on a percentage link formula is wrong. There will not be less funding for those schools which had previously not been able to provide adequate educational opportunities for their children. There will be more.

TALK.START.PARA: —And next year and the year after, and the year after that?

—Senator Teague, by way of interjection, refers to next year and the year after. I want to say this: We had no time to develop a comprehensive new formula for the funding of non-government schools because of the timetable of the Budget at the time when the Government was elected. Therefore we used, as the Senate has heard even again today, the formula based on the private income of schools to determine which schools needed more assistance and which schools in our view did not need the level of assistance they had previously been getting, and only 41 schools came into that category. However, for the next Budget we will have in place a more comprehensive formula of needs. That formula is currently being worked out by the Schools Commission in consultation with all of the non-government schools authorities. I am hopeful that at that stage we will see a true consensus about the purposes of Commonwealth education funding and that the current anxiety that some parents understandably feel, given the performance of people such as Senator Harradine and Senator Peter Baume, will no longer have any basis. But the development of that formula does depend on proper consultation and co-operation with the people concerned, with the people who run the schools, who are the parents who choose the schools-
—Why did you not do it before?

—The consultation has been an ongoing process. If Senator Harradine addresses himself to the list of meetings that I have had he will see that that is the case. What I am now becoming very concerned about is that the occurrence of public meetings, of the kind that was organised on Monday night, clearly set up to attack the Government and to continue the confusion and the misrepresentation of government policy, will militate against a sensible coming together of all of those who are genuinely concerned for the education of children. This Government is genuinely concerned for the education of children. This Government, in the short period it has been in office, has shown its good faith by the kind of Budget it introduced and by the accessibility that non- government agencies have to me. We have a marvellous opportunity, we believe, to establish once and for all a proper equitable formula whereby all schools in Australia will receive adequate funding. Our ultimate and, one would hope, shared objective of true educational opportunity for all children will be achieved. I sincerely hope that those people who organised Monday night's meeting will bear in mind the seriousness of the task we are involved in and will adopt a co-operative, instead of this very aggressive and eroding, approach .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say to Senator Ryan that the parents of non-government school children do not believe her. While her Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) talks about consensus she is spreading division into the non -government school area. While he may preach reconciliation, she is separating group from group, school from school and religion from religion. She is part of a government which, while it gave assurances before the election, has wasted no time at all in dishonouring those assurances. Part of the Australian Labor Party agenda must be to appease those teachers federations whose support, directed towards the ALP to the extent of $750,000, was so important in the March election. That appeasement will require several things. It will require a movement towards the reduction of aid for non-government schools. It will require immediately the phasing out over four years-that is what Labor policy is , five per cent this year, five per cent in each of the next three years-of the support to a small number of schools. It will involve this year the giving to all group 1 schools of less support than they would have received under the existing formula. All group 1 schools and all group 2 schools will receive less than they would have received. Eventually the Australian Teachers Federation policies will be quite clear, as are the policies of many other anti-state aid groups-no support for any non-government school of any kind from any government source. This Labor Party and this Labor Government are beholden and indebted to the teachers federations. We have in place, only eight months after the Labor Government came to power, policies that are divisive in nature, that are potentially destructive of the dual system of education that we know and policies which are in clear breach of election undertakings given by the Labor Party when it was seeking the votes. It is quite clear now that the Labor Party and the Government had absolutely no intention of honouring the pre-election commitments served up to the community as part of its cynical vote-catching campaign. But it is worth recalling just how expedient the Hawke Government was prepared to be. It gave a specific undertaking in writing in relation to non- government school funding which I will read out:

SPEECH.PARA: Funding at present levels will be maintained during the period of time required to allow the Schools Commission to determine the community standard and to allow schools in the light of that determination to make their decision.

That is a specific written undertaking. Ask the 41 schools what happened to that undertaking. That promise has been dishonoured, cynically and quickly. What should those schools make of the statement by the ALP spokesman for education at that time, Mr Hurford? He said:
I do have to say at the moment-
and that was in February-
the assessment of what is a 'wealthy' school is totally inadequate . . . We do not currently have an accurate assessment.

But after the election, without being able to say what is a wealthy school and in spite of a specific promise given to the electors beforehand, Senator Ryan wastes no time, but starts paying off the teachers federations as quickly as she can. I am sure that the honourable senator's response today will be of some interest to the many groups of parents whom she has declined to address in person or through her representative. What about the thousand parents in the Albury district, many coming from long distances, from other towns, who were told that Senator Ryan was not going to be present? Actually, Senator Ryan had, in fact, declined to attend and had declined to send even a representative to meet the group. That meeting was mainly made up of parents of children at Catholic schools, mostly poor, parochial schools. If Senator Ryan thinks that these meetings were meetings of silvertails only, then she is even more out of touch than the rest of her party and the rest of Australia thinks.

What about the parents at meetings in Canberra, the Minister's own electorate? Seven hundred people and 900 people attended those meetings. What about the many meetings in Melbourne? In Springvale a couple of thousand people attended. At meetings at Malvern, I think, 500 people attended. What about the meeting at Strathfield in Sydney? Those attending were told that the Minister would be attending. They were later told that no, she had changed her plans. That meeting was organised by the Catholic parents and friends organisation. The people there represented poor, parochial schools. But no, Senator Ryan accepted an invitation to that meeting and then thought better of it and did not attend because she was going overseas four days later.

What about the 5,000 parents at Sydney Town Hall last Monday night? I understand that Senator Ryan could not be present. The meeting was organised not because she could not be present; it had already been organised. But if she was not going to attend, what stopped her from sending a representative? Does she have no confidence in her own colleagues?

TALK.START.PARA: —What stopped her from going? She was here.

—She was in Australia. She was here. She declined to attend and she declined to be represented. She could have been represented by any other member of her Caucus. I understand that many parents in the Ballarat district are waiting with bated breath to see whether Senator Ryan accepts an invitation issued some time ago to join with them on 22 November. I mention to the honourable senator that the invitation has been sent to her. There has been no response. There has been no indication of whether she will send a representative . The parents have written to the honourable member for Ballarat, Mr Mildren- they have had no response, no indication-and to the Labor Minister of Victoria, Mr Fordham, and have had no response. But the Hon. Walter Jona is coming. I think the Minister should ensure that, if she cannot be at the meeting or if she will not be at the meeting, the Labor Party is represented.

SPEECH.PARA: I find it amazing that Press reports state that Senator Ryan could complain about the bad treatment she says she received from the organisers of the Sydney meeting. I think she might reflect on the treatment that she and her Prime Minister have given to those people. For the organisers of the Albury meeting to get a message that no representative would be sent because the matter was too delicate-that is the message that was sent to the Albury meeting and it was read out to the meeting-almost beggars description.

The campaign at the moment is committed to the defence of freedom of choice in education in Australia. It is about the freedom of parents to choose the type of education they want for their children and to be supported in that choice. They want to be supported financially as taxpayers to make that choice possible. It is a campaign that recognises that the majority of parents sending their children to non-government schools do so at considerable personal sacrifice. The majority of families are two-income families by necessity, not by choice. They need the second income to pay the school fees. But Senator Ryan ignores, as did Mr Hawke, just yesterday, these realities-that people are making financial sacrifices, major sacrifices, to get their kids as far away from the influence of the teachers federations as they know how. So they take them to non- government schools.

Let me say further that recent opinion polls make quite clear the attitude of Australians. The opinion polls show that a majority of Australians are against the reductions in aid and that 71 per cent of parents with children at government schools support the continuation of aid to non-government schools. How can the Prime Minister claim that he has the support of all Australians in this kind of crusade? He has not. It is beyond me how he can make such a claim. Non-government schools across Australia have rejected the policies of the Government. They are not happy. They do not trust the Government. They believe that, group by group, schools will be lined up for arbitrary and punitive treatment.

The Central Committee of the Catholic Bishops of Australia is against the measures. The Victorian Catholic bishops are against the measures. The Anglican bishops are individually against the measures. The Australian Parents Council is against the measures. The Catholic parents and friends organisation is against the measures. The National Council of Independent Schools is against the measures, as are the associations of independent schools. Not only are they against the measures, but they know that it is quite irrelevant in this debate to talk about so-called wealthy schools and so-called poor schools.

What the Labor Party seems unable to comprehend is that it is the parents who are poor or wealthy, not the schools, and it is the parents, not the schools, who pay the fees. There is a difference between the assets which a school has built up over generations and which enable anti-state aiders to accuse the school of being rich and the income needed every week and every month to keep a school running. It is the school fees and the support which provides that income . I challenge Mr Hawke or Senator Ryan, who has left the chamber now, or any other member of the ALP to have the temerity to call every parent and every child at those group one schools either elite or privileged. I do not think they would be so stupid.

Yet we see policies which do not acknowledge individual circumstance, policies which are shrouded in high-sounding principles about supporting the most needy, but which do not support parents on a basis of need and which strike at the very fundamentals upon which freedom of choice is based. The rhetoric of anti-state aiders has consistently talked, and in disparaging terms, of so-called wealthy schools. The schools chosen, whenever this kind of talk occurs, have always had good assets. So they go out and the photograph the gates of Santa Sabina, a school at Strathfield, and they say 'Look at this wealthy school', quite ignoring the fact that the parents who use Santa Sabina are parents who are struggling to pay the fees, and parents who need support from all taxpayers.

Reduced support from government for some parents will mean higher fees for them to pay to keep their children in the schools they choose. The effect will be on the parents. It will not be on the schools. Senator Ryan seems to know absolutely nothing about the needs of parents. I do not believe that she has any information relating to the salaries of parents. She has no information that enables her to say that the parents at a certain school are less entitled to support than the parents at another school. Yet, in abrogation of a specific written election undertaking-I repeat, written undertaking-she has not waited for the Commonwealth Schools Commission to do its job. She has not waited for a new formula, but has introduced policies which will hurt these parents and hurt their chance of keeping their children at the schools they want.

TALK.START.PARA: —Create an elitist, wealthy system.

—I agree with my colleague. What Senator Ryan will succeed in doing will be to make non-government schools more elitist and less accessible . We already know that fees for many of these schools will have to go up next year. In the group one schools, funds for which have been reduced below what they would have received, the rise will be higher than it need have been. I regret the disruption that will occur in the learning program of the students who may have to change schools and in schools that may have to change the structure of their classes or their offerings. These are the people, of course, whom Mr Hawke talks of as the elite and the privileged. The ones who will have to get out are the least privileged and the least elite. Those most in need of the support of those schools are the ones who may not be able to carry on. The Sun newspaper in Sydney yesterday in an editorial put it very well. It stated:

SPEECH.PARA: They packed the Town Hall last night, leaving 2,000 people outside to keep in touch by TV with the event inside.
They weren't there for any rock concert or to hail the newest superstar of show business.
Five thousand parents turned up because the Federal Government is ripping off the private school system.
And they-and many more-fear the ripping will emasculate the system or at least sap its strengths to cover the weaknesses of public schools.

The editorial went on to say that private schools have long outlived their reputation of being places for silvertails. There is no doubt that the Government has miscalculated on these policies. I ask the Minister-I know many of her colleagues are concerned-to be careful that she does not end up out on a limb all on her own. This is the most pragmatic Labor Party in history. It would cost only a few million dollars to restore the basic grant and to restore the percentage link. If the Australian Labor Party did that we would have no objection at all to the extra support going to those schools most in need. Senator Ryan, however, could end up in a party of one if she is not careful. I say to her again: The parents of Australia do not believe her and do not trust her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I utterly repudiate this matter of public importance brought into the chamber by Senator Harradine charging the Government with devising divisive and potentially destructive funding guidelines issued to the Australian Schools Commission. I certainly intend to deal with the matters of principle and notions of fairness and equity which have been propounded by both Senator Harradine and Senator Peter Baume. Before I do, in response to the puerile interjection by Senator Harradine that I had no capacity to comment on these issues because I did not pay the fees for any children of mine at Catholic schools or any other non-government school, I point out that, whilst that is true, I do pay the fees for my godchildren at Marist Regional College in Burnie. The short answer to Senator Harradine is: Neither do the bishops. I think Senator Harradine should consider that for one moment.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to the principles involved I urge on this chamber that the needs principle advocated by this Government indeed increases the very possibility of the choice of parents being exercised throughout the length and breadth of Australia. It actually increases the number of Australian families who can make a realistic choice of non-government schooling for their children. Far from being divisive and destructive, the allocation of funding to schools on the basis of varying degrees of need is such a neutral and widely understood concept that not only does common sense attest to it and perceive it as being neutral and fair but also, in being that, I believe it lifts the funding debate above the sectarian bitterness which characterised much of Australia's history for many years-for decades upon decades. I believe that the relevant guidelines, when assessed in a fair manner, as I said, must be seen to lift the whole funding debate outside a sectarian debate. Clause 5 of those guidelines is worth quoting. It states that the aim is:

To assist in ensuring that each child has an adequate standard of resources available to support his or her education. The Government recognises that the majority of schools in the non-government sector . . . cater for children from a wide range of ethnic and socio-economic backgrounds, yet do so with limited resources by comparison with many other schools. The Government therefore has provided for a significant increase in resources to these needy schools. Considerations of equity and financial limitations require that the funds for needy schools be found partly by some reallocation within the education budget.

That is the nature of the enterprise we are undertaking. What is divisive or destructive about that? It does draw a distinction between schools which are well resourced and those with inadequate resources. That is not a divisive matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about parents' rights?
—I will come to parents' rights.
—Come to them quickly.

—I will. That is a very relevant and proper distinction to be taken into account by a government distributing scarce tax dollars to support the education of all our Australian children. We say that capital and recurrent funding grants will be used to ensure the survival-this is my point-of a large number of ordinary non-government schools in category 3. That is how relevant and proper the distinction is. In the application of that needs principle a greater share of resources is being pushed into those areas where the household income of the parents-single parents sometimes-is meagre or absolutely fully stretched on ordinary commitments, so that children from those households can be sent to non-government schools if their parents so wish. Senator Peter Baume is correct; our policy of redistribution of some of these education tax dollars may make it marginally more difficult for parents who are spending large amounts of money on fees for a child's education at one of the 41 well-resourced schools to find a hundred or so extra dollars.
—It will.

—I concede that it may be difficult for a household which is fully stretched to pay fees of that order. In the unlikely event that household income itself remains static over that year, this extra amount may lead a very small handful of such parents to withdraw their children from that well-endowed non- government school and place them if they so wish in another non-government school that does not have such a high fee structure, or perhaps they can send them to a government school. I concede that that may apply to a small handful of such parents, but I ask the chamber to consider the other side of the coin. I ask honourable senators to consider the responsibility of this Government to enhance, to increase the possibility of choice for as wide a range of parents as possible. That includes parents in the lower income groups where the household income is so meagre, so tightly budgeted-particularly in times of unemployment, which can have an absolutely catastrophic effect in many ordinary homes around Australia-that they could not afford the fees, low as they are, charged by the local parish school, the Christian Brothers or the systemic Catholic system. This Government generously supports the ordinary parish school systemic system established under the aegis of the Catholic church in Australia. Insofar as the level of resources in many of them is low or inadequate, this Government is determined to redirect a preference in funding, a priority in funding and, yes, a redistribution in funding towards them. Only by a redistribution-I believe this is the answer to Senator Harradine's claim-can the choice of many hundreds of thousands of Australian families be made a realistic choice. It is only in that way that non-government schooling can be made possible and accessible to many of these families throughout Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: If we do not make this extra commitment of funds to those schools in category 3 or in the more needy and less well resourced schools, of course the payment for capital works and the payment for recurrent funding will have to be found by the schools taking loans outside the school's provident fund structures. They will have to fund those loans from higher fees, which those households will not be able to bear. The burden of such higher fees would be too crippling, would have too disastrous an impact on those households. It would be so devastating that the parents would have to withdraw their children from such schools, if indeed the schools themselves could continue. I believe that not to carry out this marginal redistribution away from the well-resourced schools to the more needy schools would be to reduce drastically, except for those parents who can afford higher fees, the opportunity for that choice of schooling which does reside in parents and which this Government very generously supports. All that argument can be based on simple egalitarian principles, a simple political program such as was put forward by the Australian Labor Party at the last election. This Government's preference for the needy can be adequately defended in this way.

I would like to bring another strand into the debate since both Senator Harradine and Sentor Peter Baume brought up the question of the ethos of Catholic schools. The fact is that most of the schools in the non-government sector derive their special character, their ethos-indeed their very justification-from their adherence, as they say, to certain Judaeo-Christian ethical principles. I should have thought that one of the main strands, one of the leading motifs, in that set of traditions is that one is on the side of the disadvantaged, of those who are in need, of those who have less material resources, so that one can liberate them from that lack of material resources. It has that effect; but also, in providing those resources, of course, as a law giver or as a ruler, one is acting justly. 'Acting justly' does not merely mean acting in an even-handed way. It means actually getting on the side of those who are disadvantaged or who have less material resources and vindicating their right to exercise, in this case, freedom of choice as to where they will send their children for education. This Government is acting entirely in line with that tradition. In relation to the Catholic schools, it is about time that the Catholic education officers and the principles of Catholic schools, who know how generous this Government is being with its schools programs, its capital funds and recurrent funding, came out and showed a bit more fortitude.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you say that the Government is generous?

—It is extremely generous, as has been indicated to me at the opening of various extensions to Catholic schools-St James at Cygnet, and St Brendan's Shaw College at Devonport. Because of this Government's policy such schools have recently had extensions opened. It is about time that they revitalised the leaders of the great teaching orders that opened up the Catholic school system in Australia and looked at their particular priorities.
—You say that the Government is generous.

—The Government has been and is more generous than was the previous Government in redirecting funds to this particular group of schools. I am very surprised that Senator Harradine cannot find any sort of generous sentiment to acknowledge that. Actually, I am not all that surprised. As for the leaders of the teaching orders in Australia who opened up the opportunities for that choice in education in the cities and all the great provincial towns, one thinks of Mary McKillop, who started teaching in a stable in South Australia and who founded one of the great bands of the Sisters of St Joseph. One thinks of Edmund Rice, who taught the poor lads in Ireland, and his brothers, who came out here and established that type of school in every centre of population in Australia. They would know what this Government is about, even if those who attended the meeting on Monday night do not grasp that. We go beyond pious platitudes, and we are carrying that sort of belief into practical effect.

SPEECH.PARA: No one, as Senator Ryan correctly pointed out, can express surprise if the attitude of this Government is radically different from the response and the principles and guidelines issued by the previous Liberal-National Party Government. That Government had quite different motivations, and was rejected as a consequence by the Australian people in a decisive and overwhelming way on 5 March. In general, that rejection of Senator Peter Baume and his colleagues who were in government at that time, was because Australians wanted a government which perceived the obligation to act fairly and justly and without undue deference to particular vested interests trying to corner the resources which should be available to lift the standard of living and the opportunities for education, health care and so on of all Australians.

That is in general. But in the particular-and this enables me to draw together the various themes of my remarks this afternoon-I say to those who pursue the line of attack advocated by Senator Harradine that they ought to listen to the words of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in our policy speech delivered on 16 February 1983, in which, having outlined our education policy based on needs, he said:

I say frankly and unequivocally that under these proposals 98 per cent of children in the Catholic education system will be better off in terms of Commonwealth assistance, and in saying that I am mindful that the Catholic and the Government systems cater for children from all ethnic and socio-economic backgrounds.

I believe that we are enhancing the opportunity for parents who want to send their children to government schools and to Catholic schools which cater for children from all ethnic and socio-economic backgrounds so to do. Honourable senators opposite are putting in grave jeopardy the understanding which this Government has of what the Catholic education system is all about, as expressed in that statement by the Prime Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —Next year and the year after.

—I am fighting Senator Harradine because I believe that whilst his alliance with the 41 schools, which to him is a matter of ecumenical principle- something which this Government has no right to take into account-may have some virtue of ecumenical solidarity, in fact it will lead to a revival of sectarian bitterness in this country, not between denominations I admit, but between taxpayers and non-government schools. Senator Peter Baume has made the most vitriolic attack that I have heard on the government school system since I have been a senator. It was the most vitriolic attack that I had ever heard fall from the lips of any senator. It was a sort of reverse sectarian attack, which does not become the Opposition at all.

SPEECH.PARA: The needs principle is the only neutral principle capable of acceptance by the greater part of the Australian community. It appeals to common sense. It enables the national Government to discharge its obligations to all Australian children, to ensure that none of them is disadvantaged in schooling because of inadequate material resources. Finally, and in complete contradiction to the charge levelled against the Government in this debate, it enables the Government to support a wider range and number of parents in the exercise of choice as to the sector in which they wish to educate their children. That is the mandate that the Government had conferred on it in the last election, and we shall fulfil that mandate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I claim to have been misrepresented. Senator Tate, in his closing remarks, suggested that I had attacked government schools. I made no such attack. A perusal of the Hansard will show that I attacked the teachers federations with vigour, and I shall continue to do so, but at no stage have I attacked government schools or government schooling. Unlike many members of the Australian Labor Party, I received half of my schooling in government schools.

—Mr Deputy President, I claim to have been misrepresented. Senator Tate, in his misleading statement, indicated that I had suggested that he had no warrant to speak on this matter since he was not a parent and did not have children attending government schools. My statement was in response to his snide interjection-
—Senator Harradine, you are tending to debate the point.
—Senator Tate interjected that the category 3 schools would accept the 3 per cent increase. I did not say that he had no warrant to debate this issue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I assume that honourable senators in this debate feel quite proud of themselves for having yet again inflamed in this community bitter and vitriolic attacks upon one another, using children as the excuse. This has been going on for about 15 years, and I suppose that it will go on for another 15 years. I intend to take no part in that type of debate any longer. The types of meetings that have been held around the country at which people have been cat-calling, yelling and clapping their hands when snide and personal remarks have been made about various people, be they Ministers or whatever, seem to be about the lowest type of debate that one can get, but it is fostered by people because it is seen to be useful for a few votes.

SPEECH.PARA: What we need to realise, and some people must say it, is that if we keep looking back, we shall keep fighting the old battles that have been fought time and again and we shall use a new generation of kids to fight them for us. The only way in which we shall get out of our present problem is by looking forward and by putting forward propositions that may solve our current problems. I have not heard one speaker in this debate so far put forward a constructive idea as to how we can move forward from where we are.

Obviously, what is needed is for us to take this debate out of the political arena, because politicians have shown yet again in this debate, that they will use anybody for votes. If the people who are interested in kids, the parents and teachers, got together out of the light of the Press, before which they have to make statements for public consumption, and spoke to one another honestly, on the basic principle that what they were interested in was not their own survival and a few paragraphs in a newspaper but the best education they could get for all of the kids in this country, that would be a meeting which would have the fruit of success contained within it. That will be the only way we will move forward. Otherwise we will just continue the brawling and the rather disgraceful cat-calling and name-calling that we have had for so long.

During the last election every political party put out a series of statements about its position on various matters of concern not only to the teachers federations but also to the parents and citizens associations and the independent schools associations. In those statements various political parties made commitments. I do not know whether Senator Harradine filled out such questionnaires, but he may very well have done so. The various major political parties outlined what they would do in government and their position on what they would argue for if re-elected. The Australian Labor Party, in the document entitled the 'Hayden Education Plan', in item 12.4, stated the following:

In government, Labor will take new initiatives to improve the resource levels of schools with little capacity to improve their level of resources. These initiatives will require discussion and agreement with the non-government school sector.
I emphasise the words 'discussion and agreement with the non-government school sector'. The document continues:

During the period of these discussions Labor will maintain in real terms the existing levels of funding for all group 2 and group 3 schools and for those group 1 schools which choose to operate within the community standard.

That was written down. That promise was made and was promptly broken. There have not been those consultations, that holding off until some type of agreement was able to be reached. The money going to those various schools has not been maintained in real terms. There has been a shuffling of statistics, but I do not think that anybody who reads the figures would be taken in by them. Those promises have been broken, and broken decisively. Mr Hawke's policy speech of 16 February this year went even further. It stated that an Australian Labor Party government would:
. . . reduce by 5 per cent per year the direct Commonwealth grant going to a very small number of wealthy private schools endowed with resources far above those of any other schools.

That has not occurred. What, in fact, did occur was a 25 per cent cut in the first year. Further, the Australian Labor Party promised to 'maintain in real terms the existing levels of funding for all group 2 and group 3 schools. That did not happen. Thus, the commitment given not only in the Hayden document but also in the Prime Minister's speech have not been maintained. the Australian Democrats, in response to the questionnaires, said that we stood by the notion of funding on the basis of need. Indeed, we were the only political party to do so during the election campaign. Having had the courage of our convictions, we were utterly outraged when the Government, during the election campaign, deliberately weakened its position to entice votes from the non-government schools sector. Having sat down and scarcely warmed the benches on the Government side, the Labor Party cast that sector aside. I believe that the Liberal-National Party lost government not for the reason given by Senator Tate, but because it did not keep the promises it made to the electorate. The Hawke Government is doing precisely the same thing.

Education is an extremely important area. If we are to accomplish anything meaningful in this area we will have to look at where we can make changes. I believe that the state schools system should become more decentralised. Individual schools must be given the opportunity to evolve their own approaches to the educational problems of their areas. Parents and teachers must be involved in the decision making in those schools and school finances, as far as is compatible with public accountability, must be much more under the control of the schools so that they are able to organise their own funding priorities and allocate accordingly. In other words, state schools have to take on some of the present characteristics of non-government schools. Likewise, the private schools system will have to change. Certainly, it will have to relinquish its control over entrance and exit requirements, and conform to the entrance and exit provisions which are imposed on the government schools in the various States and Territories.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you talking about integration, Senator?

—A uniformity of such regulations will mean that undoubtedly problem children will be spread over all schools. Likewise, the ability to expel must be uniform for the same reason. I respond to Senator Baume's interjection to say that in one year that I taught in a government school I had 28 children in my class plus four who had been expelled from the local private school. Those children lowered the educational chances of the 28 children. They had been expelled for scarcely anything, certainly for nothing for which I could expel them from a state school. Everybody is involved. We must not treat this operation as though it concerned only that group of children and that group of children. We have to look at all Australian children. We have to get some sensible forward planning instead of trying to trade off one group against another and think that we get a few votes for doing so. With respect to the operations that I have been talking about, we definitely must attempt to come up with some propositions whereby we can suggest ways of moving forward. I believe that parents and teachers will be able to do this providing politicians leave them alone.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Harradine referred in his remarks to freedom of choice. I believe very strongly in freedom of choice but it does not extend purely to the freedom of choosing a religious school. It also extends to the freedom to choose a particular school with particular educational biases and bents. Such schools need not be non-government schools. They ought to be government schools as well. We ought to foster those types of schools and those types of outcomes. The only way in which these hopes can be realised, I believe, is by introducing a weighted index. To quote from a document circulated by the Democrats during the election campaign, a weighted index is one:

. . . which takes into account the educational advantages of a school, its innovative or special character, the number of pupils, the state of buildings, grounds and equipment, the library and other resources available in the school, its isolation, the experience and stability of the teaching staff, the range of social, economic, physical and mental disadvantages catered for in the school. The aim of this weighted index is not to discriminate against any child but rather to ensure that the present operation of a dual system does not disadvantage any children in any way that would not have occurred if only one system had been in operation.

I believe that that last principle is the principle that we need to implement. I do not believe that it is beyond the wit of this country to be able to do that. We have argued constantly, not only with this Government but also with the previous Government, the need for increased educational expenditure. Indeed, the children of this country are out greatest asset. That statement has often been used as a platitude but it happens to be true. It happens to be true now more than ever before. The concept of human capital in developed and developing countries around the world is based very much on the capacity, the skills, the understanding and the knowledge of its citizens; it is based less on industry, less on primary industry and much more on that element which is associated always with education.

By investing in education we are investing in our best resource. All governments have never grappled with that essential problem. Although one can get votes for building a dam, a road or a new building, one does not get them for putting more money into education. By looking only at the short term, we blight our own future. It is only by looking at the long term that we will provide our children with a country in which they will want to live. We believe that the debate as it has been conducted in the community is not a debate worthy of this nation or this society. We do have many problems and any debate and any group of people which purposely set out to divide our community I will not support, and neither will the Australian Democrats. Those people, whether they be in the government school sector or the non-government school sector who wish to work constructively together, we will support. I have met every group within both of those sectors and I have found people on both sides with good will, a willingness to debate and a willingness to try to look ahead for fruitful solutions for all children. Any group which wants to set itself up and condemn and cast slurs against another group is not worthy of this community. What we ought to be doing is working together to build lifeboats to our future. We need to assist each other in the development of that precious resource, the children of Australia, and we owe it to ourselves to bury our differences and show that reasonable people can co-operate to the maximum advantage of those in their care . Unless we do, then this debate will continue, the politicians will be happy and the children will suffer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Zakharov Sen A.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to refer to some of the matters raised so far in the debate before I go on to make the contribution I originally intended. Senator Harradine referred to the destruction of education consensus. I do not think he would find too many parents in government schools or in needy non-government schools agreeing with the term educational consensus if he is talking about recent years. These parents, who are the parents of the majority of Australian children, welcome the new guidelines. I have attended meetings of parents in a number of schools over recent years and I can assure Senator Harradine that educational consensus is not an accurate description of the views of those parents. That was particularly during the time of the Fraser Government . Both Senator Harradine and Senator Baume referred at some length and I add, with some heat, to meetings which they allege the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs, Senator Ryan, did not attend or to which she did not send representatives. I have here a letter which is an invitation to one of those meetings to which I think Senator Baume referred, a meeting in Ballarat on 22 November. It seems to me, from a long experience of working in schools and as a member of parent organisations, that it is a rather strange way to organise such a meeting. The letter is dated 31 October and the date of the meeting is 22 November; in other words, three weeks notice is being given. It reads, in part:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee of which I am a member represents concerned parents and teachers across the total spectrum of Education both in Government and Independent Schools. My Committee has asked me to inform you that Senator Brian Harradine ( Tasmania) has kindly consented to address a Public Meeing on this subject in the Ballarat Civic Hall on Tuesday, 22nd of November . . .

I would have thought from my years of experience in schools that if one wants a Minister to attend a meeting, the Minister is likely to be the one with the heavy timetable so one first checks and organises the meeting to fit the Minister's time rather than organising a speaker who is known to be in opposition to the policies of the Government and then say to the Minister: 'Well , if you are free on that night perhaps you can tag along'.

TALK.START.PARA: —She is not half as busy as I am, at the moment.

—Don't make me laugh. I also mention my own experience of last week. I got an invitation to Monday night's Sydney meeting. I received it I think on Tuesday or Wednesday of last week and even for a back bencher that is pretty short notice. I would expect the parents' organisations in my own State to give me more notice than that. I wrote back explaining why I could not attend that meeting.
—It was acknowledged.

—I am glad it was acknowledged. I specifically asked for it to be acknowledged, knowing that sometimes these matters are misrepresented. Also, I cannot let pass Senator Baume's attack on teacher unions. I have been a member , and am still a member, of one of those teacher unions. I have been for the last 18 years. I believe that education in Australia is beholden to the Australian Teachers' Federations but not for the sorts of snide implications that Senator Baume made. It is the teachers who, on the whole have fought for better conditions for students. Some of those better conditions are qualified teachers in schools, smaller classes and more help for migrant and disabled students. The Teachers' Federation supported the election of this Government, not for any selfish reasons but because it believed that this Government shared its concern for education. I remind Senator Baume that government schools are supported by 75 per cent of Australian parents and by a very strong parents' organisation which, strangely, has not been mentioned today. I refer to ACOSS.
—No, ACSSO.

—I am sorry, the Australian Council of State School Organisations. The Australian Council of Social Service is another organisation with which I am involved. I refer briefly to something that Senator Macklin said . I quite agree that parents and teachers do have to get together for the benefit of their schools. In my State they have done that very effectively and I believe the Victorian education system shows the benefit of that long co- operation over many years. I know State schools, like private schools, do vary from State to State but in my State it is the government schools rather than the private schools that are doing the sorts of things that Senator Macklin believes they should do in terms of consultation.

SPEECH.PARA: I am speaking, as I mentioned before, from many years of experience working in schools and also as a parent of former students in both government and non- government schools. I was also-I regret this fact-a student in a non-government school, but that was back in ancient history. The Government's guidelines provide the most help for the schools most in need, which did not happen under the previous Government. Under the previous guidelines it was possible for some schools to provide what most people regarded as luxuries. I refer to things like very expensive sporting complexes. At the same time, other schools in the non- government sector, as well as government schools, worked with substandard buildings, grounds and other facilities.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is just not true.

—The honourable senator should come for a tour with me and I will show him I am referring to the needier schools. I would like to say something in this debate about the question of choice, which I know has been raised already. Many of the letters I have received from individuals and groups opposing the guidelines talk about the right of parents to choose their children 's school. Nobody is denying parents the right to choose their children's school . Perhaps it is significant, though and I say this as an educationist-that they do not talk about the child's right. By secondary level, at least, I believe the child does have some right of choice. In fact, in my experience as a counsellor very often the child's choice may be more valid than that of the parents. But how many people in the community really have had the right to choose, either under the old guidelines or before those guidelines were established? This morning's Age newspaper lists current fees, under the old guidelines, for a number of Victorian private schools. At secondary level the cheapest fees for the schools listed are $630 a term or nearly $2,000 a year. The dearest fees are $1,233 a term, or $3,700 a year. How many people on low or even average incomes can afford such fees? They are the basic tuition fees. On top of that parents have to add the cost of probably expensive uniforms and extra fees in some subjects such as music, art or science. Is that a real choice for the majority of parents, even if they have only one child, let alone three or four or more?
—There are an awful lot of women working to pay fees like that .

—I am coming to that right now. It is said that many parents do make sacrifices to pay those fees. I know that they do. Many parents also make sacrifices to keep their children in government schools. But many parents also make sacrifices for other things that they consider important for their children , such as a tennis court, a swimming pool or a house at the beach. We do not expect the Government to heavily subsidise those choices. I believe the right to choice in education does not include the right to have other people pay dearly for that choice.

SPEECH.PARA: I would also argue from my own experience, and the evidence of the letters which I have received, that the choice of a non-government school is often based on insufficient or incorrect information about the alternatives. Many parents who send their children to non-government schools have mistaken beliefs about their value relative to government schools. They believe that if they pay a lot for something, it must be better. I wish to mention a few of those misapprehensions. There is much misunderstanding, for example, of the significance of pass rates in senior forms, because those who place emphasis on those rates are often unaware of the selection policies which vary vastly between schools.
