Senator Macklin also referred to that. Government schools accept all students regardless of their ability or behaviour record. They do not tell their students, as many private schools do, to move on if they are unlikely to pass in senior forms or if they are in any way perceived as difficult students, or if, as one local private school principal said to me the student does not measure up to the private school's standards. Apparently the principal thought the child would measure up to government school standards. Certainly, we accepted him and he was a credit to the school. To my mind that sort of attitude , particularly in a school which prides itself as being Christian, is appalling. This method of selection involves not only selecting students in the first place but also the promotion and retention of those students. It is a stark contrast to the government schools which accept and keep most of the students whom they accept.

Another misapprehension is that parents have more say and involvement in their children's education at non-government schools. In Victoria at least the situation is quite the reverse. School councils have heavy parent representation . In most cases they represent the majority of the council. Those councils have a great deal of power. Parents are involved in curriculum planning. They are encouraged to be involved in these areas. As far as possible, parents are involved in the school programs. They are involved in areas such as individual help with reading and community involvement courses. Some parents claim that teaching is superior in non-government schools. This is often based on the spurious evidence of higher school certificate pass rates to which I have already referred. Honourable senators may not be aware that some teachers in those schools are without any teacher training. The class sizes are often up to 50 per cent larger than those permitted in government schools. Any teacher or student knows the benefit of smaller classes in terms of both the quantity and quality of student-teacher interaction.

Students in government schools very often have a larger choice of subjects in the curriculum. At the school which I left at the beginning of this year there is a choice at Year 10 level of over 50 different semester units. None of those is a mickey mouse unit. They cover a wide range of academic, cultural and physical educational options. Many non-government schools make little or no provision for students who do not wish to pursue a career in non-academic areas. In the school which I left this year we had numerous students transferring from non-government schools, but not because they had been tossed out-some, in fact had won scholarships to those schools but they found that the schools did not meet their educational needs or that, sometimes, they were no longer welcome because their results might not enhance that school's academic record and hence its marketing power.

TALK.START.PARA: —What has this got to do with the debate?

—If the honourable senator thinks about it he will realise that it has everything to do with it. Government schools accept all students and endeavour to devise school programs to meet their needs. If parents are concerned about choice they ought to look a lot more at the government school system. I am surprised that organisations such as the Parents Council of Australia seem to have so little regard for needy schools in the non-government sector which have benefited from the new guidelines. Such groups seem to assume a choice only between government and non-government schools. If the 41 resource rich schools should become too expensive for some who wish to send their children to them-I would argue that many of those schools could well absorb at least some of the increases in net costs-those parents still have the choice of a large number of non-government schools of many varieties in the other funding categories. Finally, I know that many parents have chosen to send their children to non-government schools and still support our priorities which are reflected in the guidelines. They have exercised their choice, but they do not expect other people to have to pay for it. I conclude by quoting from those guidelines. Guideline No. 35 states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government acknowledges that many parents exercise a choice in favour of private schooling, but the extent to which this choice will be subsidised will be determined on the criterion of need.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating a matter of public importance which was introduced by Senator Harradine in these terms:

SPEECH.PARA: The divisive and potentially destructive character of the pivotal funding guidelines issued by the Minister for Education, Senator Ryan, to the Australian Schools Commission concerning non-government schools.

The question that is before us is: Why have the Government's policies divided Australian schools? Why have the Australian Labor Party's policies reawakened the State aid debate with all of its division and destruction? Why is it that the one million Australian families who are associated with independent schools are being so alienated by the policies of the ALP Government? That is the question that is before us. It is right that Senator Harradine should bring to our attention yet again the divisiveness and destructive character of the ALP's policies. Mr Acting Deputy President, you are from South Australia. You have taken a very close interest in education matters. I am glad that I am addressing the chamber through you, as I want to appeal to you and to all members of the Government in this matter of debate on independent schools that the Government rethink its decisions and that it stop the uproar that is going on around Australia. I genuinely put forward this positive plea to members of the Government.

The Government can stop the uproar by reintroducing the nexus. It would cost only $4m. The bill for education from public funds in Australia this year is $8, 000m. For $4m, back bench members of the ALP Government can ensure that this Government reintroduces what had been an established basic grant for all children in Australia alike. There is no monetary cost involved in the nexus. It is a commitment that the grants to the independent schools will be directly indexed as a proportion of the cost of a government school place. Very little monetary cost would be involved in this present financial year. The reason there is uproar around Australia and the reason the division has been reawakened by the policies of the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs, Senator Ryan, is that the independent schools know that the Government has taken away the honesty principle. It has taken away the guarantee that when the costs increase in the years to come an increased proportion of those costs will be met by the basic funding, the basic grant. It is a simple matter for the ALP members of this chamber to put to their Government that those two basic principles be re- established so that the Australian public can be guaranteed that independent schools will be treated fairly and justly by the present Government. Then the uproar will cease.

We have heard about all the meetings which were held in Albury, Melbourne, Tasmania and Sydney. The meeting in Sydney attracted 5,000 angry parents. There was an overflow of 2,000 people outside the Sydney Town Hall. The Minister evaded attending that meeting. She only watched the television replay. Today in Question Time she said that she did not go and did not send a representative to that angry mass meeting in Sydney. All she did was watch the television replay. I sincerely appeal to members of the Government that they can stop the division and stop the debates in this chamber by simply reintroducing the two established principles for funding of independent schools. Those principles are concerned with the basic grant and the nexus under which independent school grants are a proportion of government school costs. That is what the Catholic Bishops of Australia complained about in their solemn joint statement of September. That is what people at all of the public meetings all over the country have been complaining about. They acknowledge that level 3 independent schools will receive more money in real terms this year through the current Budget. However, they are alarmed that two of the principles that had been established by the previous Government and governments before it have been abandoned by the present Labor Government. This public concern at last has reached the Senate Labor Caucus members. The front page of this morning's Australian carries the following headline: 'Ryan forced to defend school funds policy in caucus'. The article begins:

The federal Minister for Education, Senator Ryan, was forced to defend the Government's policy on aid to private schools before the Caucus yesterday after the huge anti-government rally in Sydney on Monday evening.
Both the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, and Senator Ryan were faced with questions . . .

In the Caucus this week the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs was put on the mat because of her policies. The ordinary Labor members of this Parliament are worried. They are worried not only about their seats but also about the public concern that is being expressed. Parliamentarians have a right to represent the people.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. I think that the honourable senator is grossly misrepresenting what went on in the Caucus. He was not there and he cannot know what went on. He is relying on the Australian newspaper report and is misrepresenting the position. I ask him to correct his remarks.
—There is no point of order.

—Labor Party members of this Parliament-and the honourable senator who took the false point of order did not deny the newspaper report that this was hotly debated in Caucus yesterday-are now concerned that their Government is being seen to attack three groups of people in Australia: First of all, the one million Australian families associated with independent schools; secondly, the aged of Australia, and already discussions in Caucus and Cabinet have led to a headline this afternoon which says that the assets test is about to be abandoned or is about to be severely changed as a result of the alarm that has been expressed by the Australian public; and thirdly, the unemployed. They were the people who were promised jobs, jobs, jobs. However, the unemployment level has increased during the life of this Government. If I were-and I am not- an ordinary Labor member of Parliament I would have asked severe questions of the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs at the Caucus meeting this week. I would have asked why the Minister's policies have led to such public uproar-why the public is so concerned about the policies that she has announced. She has undermined the established principles of the funding of independent schools and policies are now seen by the public to be divisive and leading to insecurity. I trust that that concern will lead to the Caucus persuading the Minister and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to reassure independent schools in regard to these principles.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Tate and Senator Ryan both tried to defend this abandonment of principles by appealing to one thing. They appealed to that one thing because they know it has bipartisan support in this chamber. All parties accept the needs principle; we all support the needs principle. Senator Zakharov in her contribution a few minutes ago misrepresented the former Government by saying that we did not embrace the needs principle and that we did not give increased support to those schools that were in need of more educational resources. It is well known that throughout the whole period of the Fraser Government we were seeking to achieve the Karmel targets for resource levels in government and non- government schools alike. There were six levels of funding under this arrangement. Independent schools received six different standards of financial support. Those in greatest need received very much more than those in category one, which were in least need. In 1980, when our policies had achieved a greater equality of resource, those six categories were reduced to three categories. Right up to this point-1983-level 3 schools receive far greater resources than other schools. In fact, they receive double the recurrent resources of level one schools. So Senator Zakharov is misrepresenting the former Government's policies .

Senator Tate and Senator Ryan in part of their speeches gave a very constructive outline of the importance of the needs principle. We acknowledge that. Senator Tate, in a characteristic way, referred to the Judaeo-Christian values of the Australian community, which require us to give greater help to those who are disadvantaged. We acknowledge that. I accept even the argument and the values that Senator Tate put forward. We in the Opposition, in the Liberal Party, support that. Senator Harradine when speaking to the matter of public importance which he brought forward today asked: 'Why did you not give even more help to the disadvantaged schools?'. We are not complaining about that. But why, when $8,000m is spent from public funds, does the Government create a divisiveness by taking away $4m as the basic grant for some children in Australia?

In the few minutes that remain I would like to refer to the strategy of those who want to upset the independent schools system in Australia by changing the vocabulary in regard to schools. The first is the notion or concept that a basic grant should not be talked about, that the Minister must evade any discussion of a basic grant, that abolition of the grant should not even be defended. Similarly there is the notion that a funding nexus should not be talked about, that that bit of the vocabulary has to go because the principle has been abandoned. 'The new vocabulary that we will introduce', say the radicals, 'is to bring in a notion of a subsidised school'. We now have this ridiculous nonsense of a non-government school, an independent school-they are the terms in which we have always talked about them-being referred to by the Minister as a subsidised school. A subsidised school!

TALK.START.PARA: —As if government schools are not.

—Senator Baume is right-government schools get a 100 per cent subsidy from the taxpayers. Independent schools get a 20 per cent, 30 per cent, 40 per cent or whatever subsidy, if one wants to call taxpayers' contributions to schools a subsidy. I do not. The independent schools get a proportion of the 100 per cent subsidy going to government schools. So if we are going to talk about subsidised schools, and this word has been introduced for divisive purposes and to change the concepts, we have to realise that the most subsidised schools are the government schools.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me further the argument in this way: The parents of children attending independent schools pay their taxes in exactly the same way as everybody else does. However, if their children attend independent schools they receive from the public purse, from government spending, maybe 30 per cent or 40 per cent-60 per cent in the case of the most disadvantaged schools-of their education costs. Therefore, between 30 per cent and 60 per cent of the cost of educating their children is received back from public funds. However, in the case of government schools 100 per cent is received from the taxpayer. So let it be understood that the parents of children at independent schools are, if one wants to argue that way, subsidising the children at government schools. I am not wanting to be facile about it but I am saying: Let the Government be on notice that it will not use this term 'subsidised school' when it ought to be referring to a non- government or an independent school. The strategy of the Government has been divisive and I appeal genuinely to honourable senators on the opposite side of the chamber to please take heed of the debate here today. It has been repeated almost fortnight by fortnight throughout the whole of this year, ever since the policies and principles that had been established for independent schools have been abandoned by this Government. The problem can be resolved by re- establishing those two basic principles, the basic grant and the funding nexus. With that positive step, we can have this divisiveness and destructive character taken out of education.

DEBATE.TITLE: TAXATION (UNPAID COMPANY TAX) ASSESSMENT AMENDMENT BILL 1983 (No. 4)

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Gareth Evans) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate the second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

Some two months ago I introduced in the Senate a Bill by this title which itself was a revision of an earlier Bill by the same title. The major purpose of those earlier Bills was to give effect to this Government's election undertaking to recover personal tax avoided by former owners of companies that were the subject of 'bottom of the harbour' schemes. In addition, the Bills were designed to strengthen and improve in several identified areas the legislation passed by the Parliament last year to recoup the company tax that was evaded by the use of these schemes.

The Bill introduced two months ago was estimated to yield $60m in 1983-84 and $ 270m in total. Honourable senators will recall that the Bill was defeated on a tied vote in this chamber. The rejection of this important part of the Government's Budget must have the effect of transferring the burden of taxes avoided by 'bottom of the harbour' scheme participants-which the Bill sought to recover-to the ordinary Australian taxpayer. As foreshadowed by the Treasurer ( Mr Keating) in his statement of 26 October 1983 the Government now has before the Parliament a Bill that deals only with measures to strengthen and improve the recovery of evaded company tax.

Mr Deputy President, the present Bill proposes to strengthen and improve the company tax recoupment measures in the same areas as were proposed in the Budget Bill rejected by the Senate. I shall outline them once again. In addition, the Bill will provide new provisions for 'anomalies' relief in cases where a public company was interposed in the chain of ownership between the stripped company and the person seeking relief. I turn now to the details of the Bill.
Post-Sale Avoidance Schemes

The recoupment tax legislation contains a let-out provision that operates where the stripped company was the subject of an unsuccessful post-sale scheme to avoid tax. Under this escape clause there is no liability to recoupment tax on the people who benefited by non-payment of the company tax. This provision was inserted by the former Government for reasons which are best known to it. In our view it defies logic and nothing that has been said in recent months in any way dissuades us from that view. It is our announced policy to abolish it and this is to be done by the Bill.
Pre-Sale Avoidance Schemes

Consistently with the removal of the post-sale avoidance scheme provision, this Bill will also ensure that, in ascertaining the potential tax liability of a company for the purpose of determining whether the recoupment tax legislation applies in relation to it, any pre-sale scheme which is ultimately established to be ineffective of its tax avoidance purpose is to be disregarded.
Anomalies Relief

An addition to this Bill is the provision of an additional avenue of relief from recoupment tax payable under the present legislation, in cases where a public company was involved in the chain of ownership. The existing law gives the Commissioner of Taxation a power, the non-exercise of which is subject to a full review by independent taxation boards of review, to eliminate, but not to reduce, a particular recoupment tax liability. This power to give complete relief may be exercised where the amount otherwise payable is less than $100 or in other circumstances of a special kind. In administering the existing relief provisions, the Commissioner views as a basic ground of relief that the person liable for recoupment tax and closely connected persons have not in any way benefited from the evasion of company tax giving rise to the recoupment liability. The new provisions to be inserted by the Bill will enable full or partial relief to be granted in cases where relief is not available under the existing law. The provisions will assist people in cases where their recoupment tax liability was traced through an interest in a public company, that is, where they are well removed from the actions giving rise to the recoupment tax liability in question. In such cases, the proposed provisions will allow an appropriate level of relief from payment of recoupment liabilities. The situations to which the provisions could apply are varied and intended application of the provisions cannot be explained by arithmetical formulae or the like. However, they would, for example, men that a public company shareholder unconnected with the scheme who received only a relatively small benefit from the evaded company tax could have his or her recoupment tax liability reduced so as to appropriately reflect the benefit received.

In the first instance, the Commissioner of Taxation will consider whether a person is entitled to this 'anomalies' relief on the basis of the guidelines laid down in the Bill. It is to be expected that by far the majority of cases will be dealt with in this manner to the full satisfaction of the people concerned. If the Commissioner does not grant relief to the full extent that the person concerned desires, there are rights of objection, review and appeal that may be exercised. In particular, a claim refused by the Commissioner may be reviewed independently by a taxation board of review, which for this purpose is to sit as a recoupment tax anomalies tribunal. Where a person has already paid company tax or recoupment tax from which relief is granted by the Commissioner or an independent tribunal, an appropriate refund of the tax paid or part thereof will be made.
Other Changes

Moving to other aspects of the Bill, there are several further amendments designed to improve the administration of the legislation or to correct technical deficiencies. The Bill proposes to remove one of the pre-conditions to liability for recoupment tax-the requirement that the company was by a stripping scheme rendered unable to pay its tax-which was inserted by the previous Government, it seems for presentational purposes. The element that the requirement expresses is, in substance, present in all cases of pre-tax profit stripping to which the legislation applies and a specific reference to it is quite unnecessary. The 'stripping scheme test', and an associated provision requiring full disclosure by the Commissioner of known details of it, is being exploited by some taxpayers as a means of delaying issue of recoupment tax assessments.

It is also proposed by this Bill to re-insert in the recoupment tax legislation a provision removed by the previous Government which authorised the Commissioner of Taxation to report to this Parliament the names of persons who fail to meet their liability for vendors or promoters recoupment tax. The Commissioner is already required to provide in his annual report to Parliament details of breaches or evasions of the taxation laws and it is consistent with that duty that he be authorised, where he considers it appropriate, to report details of failure to pay recoupment tax. A still further change in this Bill, not contained in the earlier Bills, will enable a former owner to whom a refund of company tax is made as a result of a successful objection or appeal against the company assessment to receive interest under the Taxation (Interest on Overpayments) Act on the amount refunded.

Finally, I explain an amendment to an evidentiary provision of the recoupment tax legislation. The provision in question reflects the settled policy of the tax law in these matters and seeks to ensure that persons liable for recoupment tax can only contest the correctness of the underlying company assessment through the established objection and appeal procedures against the company assessment itself. For this purpose it provides that a certificate specifying the amount of a company's liability to company tax is to be conclusive evidence except in an appeal concerning the assessment of the company. Some technical deficiencies in the provision need to be corrected and the Government has, with an eye to a particular constitutional question, decided to press ahead with other amendments as well. Honourable senators will know that the recoupment tax legislation has been under constitutional challenge, on a number of grounds. One of them concerns the evidentiary provision and reflects a legal argument that the Commonwealth cannot validly levy a tax that is uncontestable. It is said that there are circumstances where a certificate that is conclusive evidence would render the tax uncontestable. Obviously it cannot be predicted what decision the High Court will reach on the particular point but the Government has concluded that it should solve the difficulty by legislating so that the certificate represents only prima facie evidence, with the result that the matters that are the subject of it will therefore clearly not be uncontestable. In providing to that effect the Bill also proposes that such a certificate would in appropriate circumstances represent conclusive evidence if a provision in the Bill that reinstates its conclusive nature were to be proclaimed. A decision on whether to make the proclamation, and thus have the provision revert to the conclusive evidence form that is reflective of settled policy, will be made in the light of any High Court decision on the underlying constitutional point.

Mr Deputy President, the measures contained in the Bill are estimated to yield about $40m in respect of the strengthening provisions, while the anomalies relief would entail a revenue cost of about $5m. In the 1983-84 year, the net revenue collected would be about $20m, or about one-third of the amount which had been expected from the defeated Budget Bill. As usual with amendments of the taxation laws, an explanatory memorandum giving details of the amendments contained in the Bill is being circulated to honourable senators. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Kilgariff) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: NATIONAL HEALTH AND MEDICAL RESEARCH COUNCIL

PROCTEXT.PARA: Report 1982

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I was very interested to receive the Medical Research 1982 report and to glance through the remarkable list of research that has been funded by the National Health and Medical Research Council. I am particularly interested in some of the things that the Council points out and highlights in its report. Some of the research that is going on in Australia, such as the recombinant DNA research, gene synthesis and major advances towards the development of a vaccine for malaria, illustrate three very important contributions being made by Australian research scientists to the world's fund of knowledge in these very important areas. Of course, that highlights some of the high technology growth area in this country. Biomedical research is one area of great optimism and prospect for Australia. The report further refers to the Commonwealth Research Centres of Excellence Committee that makes 10 awards, five of which were made in the biomedical field. I suppose that is a matter of considerable praise. On the other hand, it probably also illuminates the limited areas in which there is high excellence of research in this country.

The report also suggests that the importance of medical research is not to be seen in terms of its immediate value to the community but in terms of its long term value and therefore it ought not be funded with short term benefits in mind . But in fact the principal contribution of medical research is the gain for the Australian health status of people along the line, if you like, further away. It takes quite some time, even if research is developed, to implement the results and make sure they are within the reach of Australian people, so the funding has to be based on the need for that time to elapse. It also suggests that the particular significance of contributions is to the prevention and treatment of major disease and that the prevention focus is the most important focus of the research. The report also points out that, of course, it is very difficult to put a costing on research grants for prevention, particularly when that prevention effect happens down the line. The Council is also arguing, of course, that the costs for research ought not to be in terms of prevention only but also in terms of the awareness of the medical community, in particular, of that new knowledge and therefore the saving of costs to the Australian taxpayer, in particular, because that research and that thinking permits proper medical practice and not a willy-nilly, uncritical, unempirical and inevitable expense as a consequence of poor knowledge.

The point that struck me most, though, in this whole document was the mention made of the success of the Australian research sector in terms of the relatively high standards of health care in this country, the quality of medical education and research and the international prestige of Australian researchers. I think there is no doubt that we have a very high standard of health care in this country. But, if we look for an area in which we have very poor health care, it is amongst Aboriginal people in particular. I find it quite remarkable, and although I must say I have only skimmed this report with a broad toothed comb and not a fine toothed comb, I find no reference to any particular research into the problems of Aboriginal people and their particular health needs. I find that that is a little remarkable in an organisation that actually attracted $27.298m for research in its 1982 budget. I feel that it is worth while making the point that the health of Aboriginal people in this country is really quite deplorable, particularly when compared to the excellent health care provision for the rest of the population, although I might qualify that if we talk about poor Australians in cities. Even so, the health status of Aboriginal people is quite dramatically worse and yet there is no particular research addressing itself to those problems. Apart from that, I found the report a most interesting document. It highlights the extraordinary range of research that is being done in the health area.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

The 210th Report of the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts contains the Department of Finance Minute on the Committee's earlier report, No. 199-Financial Statements for Commonwealth Undertakings.
The Department of Finance Minute is the formal mechanism used by the government for responding to the Committee's recommendations.

The Committee's 199th Report, a Discussion Paper on the Form and Standard of Financial Statements for Commonwealth Undertakings, was tabled in Parliament on 28 October 1982. The 199th Report contrasted public sector and private sector reporting and canvassed contemporary views of financial reporting by public sector bodies. In evaluating the private sector the Committee was concerned only with its relevance to the public sector; it made no judgments on the adequacy of the process or standards for the private sector itself.

The report covers a wide range of accounting and financial reporting issues dealing both with practical steps which may be implemented in the short term to improve the quality of financial statements and with the direction research in government accounting should take in the longer term.

The Committee is generally satisfied with the Department of Finance response to Report 199 and is pleased to note continuing widespread discussion and critical analysis of the issues surrounding the development and content of accounting standards for the public sector.

A major step in implementing the Committee's findings was taken on 16 May 1983 when the Minister for Finance issued guidelines which are intended to be adopted by Commonwealth undertakings, which have their financial statements approved by the Minister for Finance. Earlier, in November 1982, guidelines were issued for annual reports of departments and authorities.

While the Committee welcomes the issuing of guidelines it wishes to stress that such guidelines are only the initial step in the process of improving published financial information on Commonwealth undertakings.
The following three recent developments are of interest to the Committee:
1. The announcement on 1 September 1983 by the Ministerial Council on Companies and Securities that an Accounting Standards Review Board will be established and operate from 1 January 1984.
2. The announcement during September 1983 by the Australian accounting profession that it has established a Public Sector Accounting Standards Board; and

3. The recommendation of the New South Wales Parliamentary Public Accounts Committee that a (NSW) Annual Reports Act be introduced to specify the reporting and accounting requirements for (NSW) Statutory Authorities.

The Committee commends the initiative of the Australian accounting profession establishing the Public Sector Accounting Standards Board and expresses the hope that the Board's responsibility and powers of enforcement are in accordance with the theme of the 199th Report's recommendations. The Committee will be monitoring the activities of the Public Sector Accounting Standards Board and the Accounting Standards Board in so far as they relate to Commonwealth administration. The Committee wishes to be accorded observer status at all meetings of the Public Sector Accounting Standards Board.
As previously stated, the Committee is generally satisfied with the responses to its 199th Report given that it is a discussion paper.

The Committee is concerned that those responses in the Finance Minute calling for further research not go unnoticed and that appropriate resources be made available for the undertaking of such research. The Committee requests that the Minister for Finance report to the Committee, on or before 31 October 1984, on the progress made in researching those matters noted in his Department's reponse .
I commend the report to honourable senators and members.

TALK.START.PARA: —I incorporated that statement in order to save the Senate's time. I attract the Senate's attention to a part of that statement which states:

SPEECH.PARA: A major step in implementing the Committee's findings was taken on 16 May 1983 when the Minister for Finance issued Guidelines which are intended to be adopted by Commonwealth undertakings, which have their financial statements approved by the Minister for Finance. Earlier, in November 1982, guidelines were issued for annual reports of departments and authorities.

While the Committee welcomes the issuing of guidelines it wishes to stress that such guidelines are only the initial step in the process of improving published financial information on Commonwealth undertakings.

There are three matters of interest to which I attract the Senate's attention. An announcement was made on 1 September 1983 by the Ministerial Council on Companies and Securities that an Accounting Standards Review Board will be established and will operate from 1 January 1984. That is a welcome initiative. Further, the statement referred to the announcement during 1983 by the Australian accounting profession that it has established a Public Sector Accounting Standards Board. That certainly is welcomed. The third point mentioned in the statement was the recommendation of the New South Wales Parliamentary Public Accounts Committee that a New South Wales annual reports Act be introduced to specify the reporting and accounting requirements for statutory authorities in New South Wales. That also is to be commended. With those few words I commend the whole of the report to honourable senators.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not have time to answer Senator Peter Rae's questions prior to the suspension of the sitting for lunch, but before moving on to that I want to correct a statement that I made. I was aware of this before lunch but there was not time to correct it. SPEECH.PARA: Senator Rae quoted some words which I did not get down but they related to the phasing down of the enrichment research or study program at the Australian Atomic Energy Commission. He asked me whether I agreed with those words. I think I wrote them down; if I did not I wrote something very similar to them. They were used in the context of a phasing down of the enrichment research or study which had been contemplated by the AAEC under the previous Government. The position at present is that the test bed will continue for this year and next year because it is doing work which the Government considers necessary for the safeguards arrangements and the safeguards review.

The other question Senator Rae asked related to whether the Department or I agree that a coal fired station in the northern hemisphere-I think he said France-is 50 per cent more expensive than a nuclear power station, that an oil fired power station would be 150 per cent more expensive than a nuclear powered station and so on, and whether a 200 megawatt nuclear reactor would produce power at similar cost to an oil fired power station of the same capacity.

TALK.START.PARA: —It may help you to know that I have sent a copy of the pinks of my questions to your office. It should be on its way now. I would be happy for you to respond later.

—A response from the Department has not been possible because, until recently, we have not been able to get the precise questions that Senator Rae asked. Nobody in my office or in the Department was able to take them down quickly enough. The Hansard copy was not available. A departmental response will come through. However, I make the general observation that all such calculations make assumptions about things like interest rates, the price of oil, the cost of decommissioning nuclear power stations and the cost of storage. Assumptions and judgments are entailed in all of those assessments. The final conclusions can be changed very substantially, as I am sure Senator Rae knows, by varying the assumptions which are fed into the models. With that quite important reservation , one thing that I think is particularly difficult to assess is the long term cost of storing the waste of a nuclear reactor. I have no trouble accepting that , in some parts of the world, nuclear power, by any reasonable assessment, would be cheaper than an alternative source of power. Likewise, I do not believe it is conceivable that in Australia nuclear power is likely to be produced at a similar cost to some alternative, although Senator Rae asked a specific question about the cost of a 200 megawatt nuclear station as against an oil fired station .
—That was in Germany.

—In Germany, was it? I make that general observation because in most parts of Australia where there is a substantial demand for electricity, fairly low cost coal is available for thermal stations. In areas where low cost coal is not available, the total demand for electricity is well below the optimum economic size of a nuclear power reactor. The sort of information that has been fed to me suggests that any nuclear reactor below about 500 megawatts is likely to have very substantial dis-economies of scale.
—That was another question I wanted to ask you. There were 140 allegedly operating around the world economically at under 500.

—Yes, but I do not think they have just been constructed. I think those nuclear power stations were built many years ago. The sort of advice that I have given is that anyone contemplating a nuclear power station now would be looking for at least a 500 megawatt output in order to achieve the economies of scale which are possible. But that sort of conclusion would be very substantially influenced by the assumption one makes about interest rates.

SPEECH.PARA: I have been given some information in response to a question asked earlier, I think by Senator Peter Rae, concerning the link between Cape Grim and the air monitoring station operation and the study of wind generation in Tasmania. This study-that is the study to which I have referred in the Senate a couple of times -and which is proposed to the Hydro-Electric Commission, would include wind resource measurements, the collection of data on wind generators and assessment of power output from suitable machines, the study of the integration of wind generators into the grid, infrastructural and environmental studies, detailed cost estimates and a study of potential for local wind generator manufacture. Wind resource measurements, which would be the first part of the study, would involve an evaluation of the wind resource measurements already undertaken by the HEC and the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation in the Marrawah district and the Department of Science and Technology at Marrawah and Cape Grim.

ABSORPTION OF INDIGENOUS CRUDE

Total idigenous liftings for this fiscal year have been:
July-399 kb/d
August-394 kb/d
September-418 kb/d
October-472 kb/d
Production from major Australian fields during October was:
Bass Strait-397 kb/d
Barrow Island-21 kb/d 434 kb/d
