TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday the discussion-I think it is an important one for the long term future and I was genuinely seeking information-was on what was the minimum amount of oil that one would have to get from countries other than Australia in order to deal with those fractions of the barrel that were from the middle and the lower end of the barrel. The Minister in the course of his reply indicated that he felt that the level of technical self-sufficiency for Australia-I hope I do not misrepresent him-was 70 per cent. During his answer I reminded him that we hoped that in the course of this decade we may be producing in Australia, for the short term at least, up to 77 or 78 per cent of our need in terms of barrels as distinct from particular fractions or qualities. I asked whether he would indicate some comparison of what was the minimum overseas necessity in the other fractions or the other qualities, and what we could supply here. What has been agreed for incorporation shows that out of a total requirement for a day of some 570,000 barrels, a minimum 120,000 barrels of particular kinds need to be imported. I thank the Minister for his co- operation. I do indicate, however, that that is 120,000 barrels-I am not cavilling at figures and I hope he will accept that-which is something like 21 per cent, making 79 per cent self-sufficiency possible. So that he has no thought that I am nitpicking, I point out that what I am basically looking at is the theoretical picture of where we might stand in Australia under all sorts of difficult circumstances, for example under circumstances where it might be difficult to find readily, through some Middle East trouble or otherwise, the particular kinds of oil from overseas. I simply rise, apart from thanking the Minister, to indicate that on this basis-it is purely theoretical and I do not develop the argument any further than that-technically we could use 79 per cent mix from Australia and 21 per cent import. The Minister will of course fully understand that we could do better than that if we had to, but we are just talking about a theoretical situation and I do not seek any response from him on that.

—I will respond very briefly. What Senator Sir John Carrick has said is correct, but to get to that theoretical 79 per cent figure would require very substantial adjustments to existing supply patterns.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to raise a quite separate matter and to ask the Minister whether he could inform the Committee of the Whole of the role which his Department of Resources and Energy plays in assessing the likely impact of revenue changes on resource industries. I raise that matter in the context of one of the areas in which the Government had to go back on one of its Budget proposals because of the, I think , unexpectedly severe impact that the changes to the excise on fuel oil were going to have on a number of resource projects and indeed upon the Northern Territory Electricity Commission. In the Budget Speech the Government announced that it would impose an excise on fuel oil, heating oil, power and lighting kerosene at the same rate as the rate on motor spirit and diesel fuel, that is, 9.027 cents per litre. Heating would be subject to a rebate of 7.155 cents per litre leaving a net excise of 1.872 cents per litre. There was-I am sure Senator Walsh would remember-something of an explosion by some of those who were affected by the changes. After representations the Government, on 26 August, which was a very short time after the Budget was brought down, announced a number of changes. Excises on fuel oil, heating oil, power and lighting kerosene were reduced to 1.872 cents per litre and the process of having a high excise of 9.027 cents and then a rebate for heating oil, requiring a lot of paper work and costs, was abolished leaving a net excise of 1.872 cents a litre. That of course was a sensible procedure that could and should I think have been introduced at Budget time.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not for a moment argue with the Government for its having changed its mind on this matter. It appeared to me, on the information which was made available and on the information which we found was available from public sources, including sources such as the Minister's own Department, that it was quite clear that a substantially greater amount than was shown in the Budget Papers would be raised by that levy. But I do not think that is so significant. The total amount of revenue to be raised certainly is not the point I am concerned with at this stage. What I am concerned about is that on a proper examination of the effect of the Budget change it became apparent that some projects would be subjected to very large additional costs. There was very limited ability on the part of those projects to substitute other fuels. It was quite apparent that the additional costs were unreasonable in that they bore too heavily upon those resource projects. I think the Gove alumina plant was a particular example.

Again I do not propose to waste the time of the chamber by putting in a lot of detail, but I think it was said at the time that the changes would have meant that the price of electricity in the Northern Territory-that is already a very expensive commodity-would have risen by about 28 per cent to cover the costs. Perhaps this matter should be raised during the debate on the appropriations relating to the Department of the Treasury, because I guess that it is the Treasury's fundamental responsibility rather than that of the Department of Resources and Energy, but I must say that, in my experience, there was a preparedness on the part of departments to bring forward proposals where they had not taken the trouble to assess the actual on-the-ground impact.

I think that if one went back through the seven years of the Fraser Government one would probably find a few examples of changes we introduced where the impact was rather greater than we would have wished or than we would have anticipated. I would like to know whether the Minister has given any attention to this matter and whether his Department in the past-and if not in the past, then in the future-may have had some role in trying to ensure that the changes which were made are not changes which are simply impossible for industry to cope with. In other words, I think that there needs to be foresight within the system, and I do not mean this as a partisan remark because I suspect that there is a deficiency in the way that Budgets are traditionally put together. I think there is a deficiency in that the matters are looked at in the broad and there is probably no attempt actually to see how that will apply to a particular industry , even a quite major industry. So, one of the questions I address to the Minister is: Did his Department or, to his knowledge, did any other department provide any information to the Government on the actual impact of those changes which I have outlined, the changes which the Government had to remove?

The other matter is that there are continuing problems with respect to the changes which have been left in place. I want to direct the Committee's attention to what I see as the Minister's misapprehension about some aspects of that and to seek the Minister's comment on it. I think some concern has been expressed about the situation of Nabalco Pty Ltd in the Northern Territory, and the effect of the increases which have been left in place. A report in the Northern Territory News on 30 September this year has Senator Walsh saying that the big improvement in world aluminium prices recently should give Nabalco, which produces and experts alumina and exports bauxite, the capacity to pay the excise. I cannot vouch for the correctness of that report in the Northern Territory News, but that is what Senator Walsh is reported as saying.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Northern Territory News is not terribly reliable.
—Let me give the quotation, because I am not trying to put the words in the Minister's mouth. I would be happy to hear any correction he has to make. The Northern Territory News reported:

SPEECH.PARA: With regard to mining operations at Gove, he said the very big improvement in world aluminium prices recently should give Nabalco the capacity to pay the excise.
The price improvement should more than offset a relatively small increase in fuel costs-less than 2c a litre.

I do not know whether Senator Walsh made that remark on the advice of his Department, off the top of his head, or on the advice of somebody else. But it appears from the inquiries that I have made that that report, if accurate, is not based on fact. Nabalco will have an increased cost because of that excise. The cost that is passed on to the residents of Nhulunbuy will be $7.7m in this year, as a lot of the fuel oil is used to produce electricity for the town. The price that the town's residents have to pay for electricity has gone up by 10 per cent due to that excise change. So part of the additional cost is recovered from the residents of the town who simply pay higher electricity charges. As I said before, had the full excise increase gone through, the Northern Territory Electricity Commission claims that it would have had to increase the cost of electricity by 28 per cent. But the increase of under 2c which has been left in place has already given rise to an increase of 10 per cent in the electricity charges at Nhulunbuy.

The statement that the Minister is said to have made about the price of aluminium going up appears to show that he has some lack of understanding about the industry as it is conducted at Gove. As I said before, Nabalco mines bauxite . It refines some of it but it exports both alumina and bauxite. While alumina is, of course, the raw material from which aluminium is produced, just because the price of aluminium has gone up, it does not mean that the price of alumina or bauxite has increased. In fact, on the figures which are publicly available, it would seem that the price of those commodities has not gone up at all. The Australian Bureau of Statistics produces a price for export of alumina from Australia. It is an average of exports from four sources. So it may be that more precise information is available to the Minister which would suggest that there is a saving. But according to the ABS, the price for the September quarter 1982 was $185.58 per tonne and the price for the September quarter 1983 was $185.80 per tonne. So there is, in fact, a price increase shown of 22c per tonne. But I doubt that that is the sort of price increase which would cover the sort of cost increase which is referred to.

In the March quarter the price was $178.44 per tonne, so it dropped. It went up in the June quarter to $191.78 per tonne and in September dropped back to $185. 80 per tonne. I ask the Minister whether he has been reported accurately and whether the figures which I have are perhaps unrepresentative of Nabalco's exports. It may be that Nabalco has some high-priced part of the market. Whether or not the Minister stands by the statement that it can recover costs from increased prices as against the proposition which appears to me on the facts which are available to me-and I do not have access to a department-it would appear that the consumers of Nhulunbuy are picking up part of the increase and that the industry will have to bear the rest. The fact is that the Government has, by its measure, made this industry somewhat less competitive. I must say that one of the encouraging things for Australia was that in a time of very considerable downturn-and that time for that particular industry seems to have passed-Australia managed to maintain fairly high levels of production and certainly Nhulunbuy remained in production during those difficult times. But I would query whether it was a time to be imposing additional costs on that industry.

Another fundamental problem arises out of the Government's decision to put an excise on fuel oil. Fuel oil is a generic term. There are many types of fuel oil , each differing slightly in chemical composition. There are a lot of other oils of similar chemical composition but which are not called fuel oil which are used for petrochemical feedstock. Those oils are not subject to the excise. It appears that the imposition of the excise relates to the end use of the product rather than to any particular quality that it has. Is that correct?

TALK.START.PARA: —That is correct.

—So the question of the imposition of the excise really depends on the end use. There appears to be some inconsistency in the Greenvale nickel plant in Queensland. Most of the fuel oil there is used as a reducing agent in the production of nickel, rather than being burnt as fuel oil. Thus, the oil in that case is not used as fuel substitute and really is similar in its end use to petrochemical feedstock. But that is subject to the excise, unlike the feedstock . That might be thought to be a fine point. Perhaps the argument is that, in fact, when it is put in as a reducing agent, the effect is that it is really burnt because that is what a reducing agent does. It is oxidised. But it appears to me that there is some illogicality in the imposition of an excise in those circumstances. Other companies are in the same position. For example, Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd uses fuel oil as an aggregating agent in producing coke for its steelworks. I would be interested to know how the oil is treated in those circumstances. I think that is all I wish to raise during this part of the Estimates debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In regard to the last point raised by the Leader of the Opposition, Senator Chaney, that is, Greenvale, Senator Chaney has correctly pointed out that the excise was directed at fuel oil used as an energy source. In Greenvale the great majority of it is used as a chemical reductant. The Government has agreed to consider the Greenvale decision in that context.
—It is still a matter for consideration, is it, Minister?

—Yes. I have not previously heard that Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd had used fuel oil in what could reasonably be regarded as a similar way to the way in which it is used in Greenvale. The advice I received was advice to the contrary-that there was no other plant in Australia that could reasonably be compared to Greenvale in its use of fuel oil.

SPEECH.PARA: In regard to Senator Chaney's first question concerning the role of the Department of Resources and Energy in making the original decision, I think there are limitations on how much detail I could or ought to divulge here. The submission on this question came from the Department of the Treasury. In retrospect certainly I acknowledge that the decision was made hastily and that the submission was probably presented without adeqaute co-ordination. The Government made a judgmental error in haste. I know that Senator Chaney has been through the process of preparing a Budget himself. He knows, no doubt, of decisions of the previous Government, made quickly when the deadline was approaching, which were on subsequent reconsideration decided to be wrong. The Government recognised that error of judgment very quickly and substantially rectified it. I will accept some personal responsibility for that error because, although the decision was made in haste, I had read the submission, I had previously known that the Greenvale project, for one, was a substantial consumer of fuel oil and was a marginal or sub-marginal project and was likely to be affected by the decision. In retrospect, I ought to have recognised that at the time and raised an objection on those grounds. I failed to do so.

The outside sources of advice, however, are not very reliable. I think that on the basis of information supplied to the Opposition by people in the industry or by propagandists acting on behalf of people in the industry Mr Howard claimed that the tax, in its original form, would have yielded $400m. Senator Chaney modified that to $250m. I think the more correct figure was about $180m. So the outside source is not very reliable. I turn now to the article in the Northern Territory News. Perhaps Senator Chaney can indicate the date of that article.

TALK.START.PARA: —30 September.

—I have some recollection of making or authorising a comment over the telephone to the Northern Territory News. I am not sure whether it is quoted correctly. I do note, for the record, that the Northern Territory News is certainly not a very reliable newspaper in this respect. I have in front of me an extract from the Northern Territory News of 2 March this year. The headline states: 'Reeves, Walsh differ on uranium'. Referring to the then Opposition spokesman on resources and energy, it stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . was today contradicted by Mr John Reeves.
It reports a radio talkback program in Darwin. The article states:
The caller:
the caller was not even named-
Senator Peter Walsh said only last week he would not expect that uranium mining would continue and that is what everybody else is saying except John Reeves.

On the basis of an anonymous telephone call and without bothering to contact me or anyone else in the Australian Labor Party the Northern Territory News saw fit to print that as fact. Of course, no such statement was ever made. Indeed, in my judgment that is a matter which may well have gone to the Australian Press Council.

TALK.START.PARA: —They probably take the view that if you prove they are wrong they will retract it.

—If I prove they are wrong? I certainly made no such statement. An anonymous telephone call does not seem to me to be a very authoritative source, at least without having made some attempt to check it elsewhere. With respect to Nabalco Pty Ltd, I do not stand by the detail of what Senator Chaney read, especially considering the source from which it came, but I did make a statement along those lines. It was made, as I recall, without the benefit of departmental advice. It was made on what seemed to me to be the common sense conclusion that if anyone involved in the aluminium industry at any point of the chain were able to continue operations when prices were at a very depressed level, when prices for aluminium-I have taken the point about aluminium being the final product-had increased by, I think the figure was something like 60 per cent or 70 per cent from their trough, even those further down the marketing chain ought to be able to secure prices which would enable them to absorb the quite small additional cost which would be imposed by the fuel tax as modified.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Further to the answer which the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh) gave in general terms to my earlier questions about comparative costs of nuclear electricity generation and alternative forms, I ask: Will he elaborate a little further, using perhaps the example of Belgium, France and Britain-all of which are sitting on substantial coal deposits and have coal-fired thermal power stations using that coal-when he explains why in Australia we could not look at nuclear power stations at this stage of our development because we have cheap coal available? Whilst I acknowledge that in parts of Australia we do have cheap coal readily available, particularly that which does not have to be mined underground, I wonder where the distinction lies.

SPEECH.PARA: The second part of my question relates to hydroelectricity. I asked the Minister earlier whether he was able to indicate in any way at all why it is that in Japan hydroelectricity is an extremely high-cost electricity generating method. It is nearly twice as expensive as nuclear-generated electricity in Japan. I would like to ask a question about electricity pricing in Australia and the importance of interest rates, to which the Minister has referred, but I think it is better that I ask my question in two parts.

TALK.START.PARA: —I follow Senator Peter Rae's line of inquiry. In my short speech earlier I mentioned the cost escalation of coal- fired power stations in France. I demonstrated in that speech how in France electricity produced by nuclear power cost 26 per cent less than did coal-fired electricity in 1982. I want to know whether the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh) can provide us with information concerning the escalation of costs in Australia, State by State, of coal-fired power stations generating electricity through hydrocarbon generation.
—The cost of a new station?

—Yes. If the Minister can do that I think it would be very interesting to compare the costs. I said earlier that the Electricity Trust of South Australia is concerned about the cost increases in coal-fired power stations. I think that sort of information would be most useful. I was called out of the chamber after I spoke earlier and I am not sure whether the minister answered my question about research into air pollution through carbon dioxide liberated as a consequence of burning coal in conventional power stations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think I can say any more about Senator Peter Rae's first point on comparative costs. I have no idea why hydroelectric power vis-a-vis nuclear power is so much higher in Japan than it seems to be in most other places. One possibility which presents itself is that they have very poor dam sites with low total impoundment or a low head relative to the cost of constructing a wall. I do not know; I will see whether the Department has any information on why the cost of hydro-power seems to be unusually high in Japan. I just offer that as one possible reason.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Jessop asked a question about the escalation of costs over the last 10 years, I think it was, in power produced from new thermal power stations. Departmental officers have indicated that no information is on hand specifically about that. It would have to be derived from information supplied by the States. We will see what can be obtained and put together. However, again, I think the rider should be added that uniform practices are not adopted by State governments in estimating the cost of power from new stations because they make differing assumptions about interest rates and the real rate of return which they expect. Of course, that is a lack of uniformity caused by decisions of the electricity authorities or governments concerned. Obviously the costs are affected also by the distance over which the power must be delivered and the quality and production cost of the coal which feeds the power stations-coal is normally used-and also whether the coal is taken into the stations at the cost of digging it out of the ground or at opportunity cost. The Department of the Treasury some time ago argued that opportunity cost pricing ought to be adopted for coal that is fed into thermal stations owned by State electricity commissions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should like to question the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh) further about small nuclear power stations, small reactors-that is, those of less than 500 megawatt or 600 megawatt capacity . I suggest to the Minister by way of interjection that there were 140 nuclear reactors of less than 600 megawatt capacity operating both reliably and economically in various countries, to which he responded that he believed that that may be because they were built some time ago and not at current costs. Does he not agree that cost in relation to nuclear power stations in most countries of the world-let us leave the United States aside for the moment-has escalated in a way somewhat comparable to that for hydro-electricity, which is a long term , high capital investment and therefore very reflective in its final cost of what has happened in interest rates, that so too some of the other forms of power generation-coal and oil-are subject to considerable cost increases because of what has happened in relation to interest rates and the lead time that is involved, although not as much as is the case with nuclear and hydro generation?

SPEECH.PARA: The second part of my question about small nuclear reactors is whether the Minister can explain why, if small reactors are no longer an economic proposition, the Federal Republic of Germany, France and Japan are all developing 200 megawatt to 300 megawatt reactors in what is regarded apparently, by some at least, as a major growth area in the market, particularly for some of the developing countries which do not have the capacity to consume or apply larger reactors at this stage. Does not the Minister agree that the technology for the smaller nuclear reactors is very much to the fore now, whereas a few years ago it may have been more questionable?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Peter Rae has said, by definition any capital intensive source of producing power relative to some other source of producing power must be more susceptible to higher interest rates. Nuclear power stations and, generally speaking, hydro power stations are both capital intensive. Therefore, their comparative or relative disadvantage, whatever it may be, suffers unfavourably as compared with less capital intensive means of producing power, other things remaining equal. That is just a true statement.

SPEECH.PARA: As to the second point that Senator Peter Rae has raised, on the use of small nuclear power stations-small being defined as something considerably below 500 megawatts-again it is conceivable that there may be situations in which a power station of that size might be the lowest cost alternative, although one could quibble about that sort of conclusion on the grounds of the assumptions that have been built into making that final calculation. I do not have any relevant information with me, but I will see what information the Department can supply on the actual construction, or firm proposals to construct, nuclear power stations of that size, their location, and the estimated cost of power from them .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for that answer. In obtaining the information, I ask that he be conscious of my earlier request that we leave aside the United States of America, as being in an exceptional situation, in trying to arrive at any of the developments in relation to nuclear power generation around the world. Or, if the United States position is shown, I ask that it be shown separately, because I think that most people would agree that the situation in the United States has been exceptional in regard to nuclear power generation costs.

SPEECH.PARA: What does the Minister believe has caused the exceptionally, dramatically high increases, sometimes at several times the rate of inflation, in the electricity charges being made Australia-wide by the various electricity authorities? Would he relate that in any way to the pricing policies and the policies by which the financial statements of the electricity authorities have been prepared and, therefore, the pricing policies determined? Does he agree that we are now reaping the 'reward' of profligate under-pricing which has taken place for too many years, to the degree that we now have a substantial and serious problem in curtailing the rate of increase in energy prices and, therefore, Australia's capacity to be internationally competitive in production in which electricity energy is involved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I make two brief comments. I do not want this to be taken as my definitive statement on this subject or necessarily the last word on it. I was asked why I think that electricity prices have been escalating at rates greatly in excess of the increase in the consumer price index. That probably varies from State to State. In at least one State, I believe that a significant factor has been the extension of the grid and the policy of State-wide uniform pricing. The more that the grid is extended, the higher is the cost of actually supplying. The marginal cost is above the average cost of supplying electricity because of extensions to the grid into areas where total demand for power is low. That is one factor. I suspect, however, that a more important and general factor is that in recent years electricity authorities-as Senator Peter Rae would know very well because he has made a deep study of it-have been turning over loans raised many years ago at rates of interest of 5 per cent or 7 per cent and replacing them with loans at anything up to 16 per cent. Their capital servicing costs have therefore increased enormously.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not have any trouble in accepting what I think was Senator Peter Rae's proposition, that a more realistic account ought to have been taken in the past by electricity authorities of the true cost of capital. In the period when real interest rates were negative, the electricity authorities, to varying degrees-I think that the record of the South Australian Trust, as I remember it, is probably better in this respect than most others-appeared to assume that negative real interest rates were a permanent feature of the economy. That, of course, proved ultimately to be wrong. Any reasonable person would have expected that ultimately that assumption would prove to be wrong. These effects have snowballed and have caught up very severely with electricity authorities throughout the country.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take it that the Minister would agree that the greater the exposure in the gearing ratio of the authority, that is, the greater the debt in relation to equity, the greater the exposure of risk to this factor of conversion from negative to positive interest rates and the impact of that on the necessary pricing policies. In supplementation of that question, I ask the Minister whether he accepts the figure which is generally given and was given at the energy symposium at the Australian National University a little earlier this year and has been published many other times. That is, that last year the figure was 97c in every dollar of surplus operating return before payment of interest, and that significant roll-overs of debt are still taking place as a result of conversion from low rates of interest to high. So one can imagine that what we are looking at in Australia is a situation in which the taxpayer will have to provide a subsidy, or we shall have to continue, as has happened, leasing and selling off capital assets, reducing the value of capital investment already made, or will have to have further substantial increases in the rate of charges for electricity supply. Really, it cannot be anything other than one of those three if there is to be a continuing roll-over of low interest loan to higher interest loan.

—I was not aware of the figure of 97c in the dollar that was quoted but on the other propositions, other things being equal, I can only agree. They are tautologies. Any electricity commission with a higher debt to equity ratio-that term might not be quite applicable in this case-obviously is in more trouble if real interest rates increase and remain at those higher levels. Ultimately loans have to be turned over. An authority in that situation, unless it receives a subsidy from the general taxpayer or it increases charges or efficiency, is faced with one or a mixture of all those three things.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the Canberra Times today there is a heading 'Government abolishes uranium body'. It refers to the abolition of the Uranium Advisory Council. I think it is regrettable that the Government has had to take this action. The Council consisted of 12 members, representing the Aboriginal people, environmentalists, the uranium industry and others with interest and expertise in the area. Having seen this particular body work for some years now, I believe that it was bringing considerable expertise to advice on the industry. Such a composite body would have brought many varied views and advice to government, which surely must have been of considerable value to it.

SPEECH.PARA: I think I have read in media reports that the Government considers that this body has not directed its energies to non-proliferation and waste disposal issues. As far as I know, the Council's principal role was to investigate matters on which the Government sought advice. As far as I can see it depended on the references it was given. Although given many references, it may not have been given this particular one. Perhaps the Government only obliquely sought advice on waste disposal and never sought advice on proliferation. Therefore, as I understand it, the Council did not pay much attention to these areas. However, in the later stages the Council did investigate these matters briefly, but it did not report on them. I am told that there is limited coverage of waste disposal and proliferation in the annual report, the first draft of which is now at the printers. While I think it would be a very good thing for the Government, if it so desires, to receive advice from other sources, it should think a second time before it loses the services of this body that it intends to abolish.

As the Caucus has now made up its mind that uranium will be developed in a limited way at Roxby Downs, once again I think it is a pity that the Government has decided to have no further co-operation with the Uranium Enrichment Group of Australia. This decision must surely be only to the Government's loss and to Australia's loss. I do not see that it costs the Government or the people of Australia anything to have the advice of this professional body which must keep a tab on the situation. Eventually, if it is the opinion of an Australian government that we should go into enrichment, we would be that much further ahead. I would have thought that the very responsible and informative advice given by Senator Sir John Carrick before the suspension of the sitting for lunch would have carried some weight.

Yesterday I asked a question in several parts of the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh). He did not answer that part of my question which related to compensation. He has answered it today. I thank him for his answer this morning in which he indicated, as I understood him, that compensation would be discussed by Cabinet next week. That is well and good. But I wonder where the Government will start in assessing compensation. I note too that the Minister has said that the Government sees no legal basis for compensation. As the uranium industry has progressed over the last few years, very great requirements have been placed on various companies. For instance, Pancontinental Mining Ltd has invested something like $50m so far at Jabiluka. One of the requirements was that it should have an environmental research station. I have seen this station in operation, as, perhaps, has the Minister. It was a million dollar investment. The company has been checking on the environment for several years. This very fine project, which has cost a lot of money, is down the drain. There has been an investment of $100m in Koongarra. All these things have come a long way. It has been estimated that there is something like $16 billion worth of ore in the ground at Jabiluka. That has been ascertained as a result of a very comprehensive drilling program over the years. By the end of the century, the year 2000, some $9 billion worth of ore would have been extracted, with a gold content, so it is estimated, of some $154m or $155m. These vast sums of money have been estimated after very many years of research carried out along the lines of government requirements.

The Aboriginal people also are concerned. In the last week Galarrwuy Yunupingu, the new chairman of the Northern Land Council, and Wesley Lanhupuy, its director , indicated their extreme disappointment that uranium development in what is known as the uranium province, Arnhem Land, is not to go forward. It is to be noted that Wesley Lanhupuy has said that the Aboriginal people looked forward to receiving the royalties. No doubt they would, because the royalties are estimated at something like $200m over the life of the present field, what has been found up to now. They are disappointed at this bitter pill. They felt that at last they would be off the Government's back, that they would not have to live on handouts. The Aboriginal people wish to live along different lines, with money coming forward not from Government handouts but from royalties from mining on their land. This could have been of considerable advantage to the development of the Aboriginal people.

There is the question not only of compensation to the Aboriginal people, but also to the town of Jabiru. As far as population is concerned, one could say that Jabiru is a half finished town. The people from the Ranger mine live there, not those from Nabarlek. Nabarlek people live on the Nabarlek mine site when they are working, and are flown to and from Darwin after a few days on the job. With Ranger, of course, all the technical people, the Supervising Scientist and all the public servants, whether Commonwealth or Territory, reside in Jabiru. The town and commercial facilities developed in Jabiru were designed to cope with the much larger population envisaged. When one visists Jabiru one sees a very nice, modern town, but with only half the population that was originally expected. Commerce is geared to the population of a larger town. How do we start considering compensation in a situation like that? One can go further and refer to the infrastructure that would have been developed to support Jabiluka and Koongarra. The lack of that infrastructure will have an effect on northern development. The fact is that many people would have come to the Territory because of the many jobs there, so the area would have been more populated and very real development would have taken place. It is a vast disappointment to all those who are concerned. So where does the Government start to assess what is required in compensation? Some compensation was paid in the cases of Fraser Island and the dam in Tasmania. One would think that, following the way in which the uranium industry has been encouraged in the Northern Territory and after so many years of research have been carried out, there is a very real case for compensation.

So it is with bitter regret that the Territory sees that this additional uranium mining is not to proceed. As it is, of course, the contracts for Ranger and for Queensland Mines Ltd at Nabarlek are being given a continuing lease of life. But, as I understand it, the Government has indicated that the life of the mines might continue only while the contracts now being negotiated-those negotiations have been confirmed by the Government-are filled over the next few years. As I understand it, the companies should not take it for granted that there will be any contracts after that. What will happen to the development of this area? How will the Government look at compensation? What will happen as far as shareholders are concerned, after hundreds of millions of dollars have been spent along the lines that the Commonwealth Government has directed? How can the whole of the north of Australia be assisted when what was to be one of its major industries will have to be discontinued, so halting that tremendous northern development? Of course, it would have assisted in defence, too, because of the increased population. How will the Government recompense the Northern Territory?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: — Senator Kilgariff seems to have made an assumption that the Government is going to pay compensation. That is an assumption he is not entitled to make. The Government will consider the question of whether any compensation ought to be paid, while recognising that there is no legal liability to do so. The Northern Territory, in fact, gets very little benefit from the uranium mines located there. They employ a few hundred people. There might well be greater regional benefits from using that same area for an alternative use associated with tourism rather than for uranium mining. The other question he raised was the Government's decision to disband the Uranium Advisory Council. Insofar as the Council provided technical advice, and it was not essentially a technical body, we saw it as being superflous because technical advice was already available from an adequate range of sources-the Australian Safeguards Office, the Office of the Supervising Scientist and the Australian Ionising Radiation Advisory Council. To the extent it provided non-technical advice, there was no need for the existence of such a body because advice and opinion on the non-technical aspects of nuclear related activities is available to the Government from within its own ranks, from the relevant policy-making departments and the community in general. Last but not least, it did cost $360,000 a year to maintain the Uranium Advisory Council and we believed that expenditure was not justified.

SPEECH.PARA: I have a response to questions asked earlier today about the Prices Surveillance Authority and the old Petroleum Products Pricing Authority which adds a little to information that I supplied earlier. In particular, it deals with the intention of the Government regarding the relationship between the Prices Surveillance Authority and the various State bodies which are involved in petroleum price setting. I seek leave to incorporate that document in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN PRICES SURVEILLANCE AUTHORITY, PETROLEUM PRODUCTS PRICING AUTHORITY STATES' PRICING COMMISSION
The Prices Surveillance Authority (PSA) is to absorb the Petroleum Products Pricing Authority (PPPA) which will be abolished. Like the PPPA, the PSA will not have statutory powers to control prices.

The States do have statutory powers to control prices and their pricing authorities may set (and do in the case of New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia) wholesale and retail prices at levels other than those approved by the PPPA. There is nothing in the PSA legislation which would change this situation.
The relationship between the PSA and States' pricing authorities is an issue of some concern, but the matter is to be taken up in future discussions with the States:
the intention is to achieve a situation where the States' pricing commission are acting in a manner, consistent with that of the PSA;
in particular, the undercutting of PSA approved price levels is seen as unsatisfactory and to be avoided;
the emphasis to date has been to get the PSA established first, and to initiate discussions with the States subsequently.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to discuss only one further point. I note the points the Minister for Resources and Energy has just made. I now come to the overall question of the future of this area. The Government has indicated that Koongarra and Jabiluka are not to proceed, and there is no indication now that the mines will ever produce under a Labor Administration. What, then, is to be the future of the surrounding area and, for that matter, the lease at Jabiluka? I speak of the area known as Kakadu II which is, as I understand it, not yet committeed. Is the Government going to declare Kakadu II in its entirety as a national park, locking in once and for all the many minerals in this highly mineralised area, or will it accede to the Northern Territory request that a conservation area of not more than 50 per cent be declared, say for a pre-determined period, to allow a stocktake of the resources of the area? Does the Government expect that if this action is not taken uranium and other minerals such as gold and copper-present in large quantities, as I understand it-will be locked in permanently?

SPEECH.PARA: The whole situation is most complex. In Western Arnhem Land some time ago either the Bureau of Mineral Resources or a Northern Territory Government agency such as the Department of Mines and Energy undertook an aerial survey which was financed by interested mining companies. The maps produced which made available to all those who were interested, indicate the anomalies of the area. It was indicated that there were quite a lot of interesting places to be explored. It was agreed that the Aboriginal people should also have an opportunity to review the situation there. There was the thought that there should be an anthropological survey taken but the Northern Land Council said that it did not have sufficient money. It was estimated to cost some $300,000. It was suggested by the mining companies, in an endeavour to get the whole matter resolved in one way or another, that in the interests of finding out what is in the ground in that area they would finance a stocktake, but the Northern Land Council felt that that was not the right thing to do. I tend to agree. We now lack the money for an anthropological survey to be carried out on behalf of the Aboriginal people.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Temporary Chairman. —I wish to speak to the point of order, Mr Temporary Chairman. It does not fit precisely into the estimates for the Department of Aboriginal Affairs or of the Department of Resources and Energy. I think the honourable senator has been trying to relate to the procedures necessary before the exploration or extraction of some resources can proceed.
—It seems more like a filibuster to me.

—I inform the honourable senator that I am waiting patiently for the Committee to deal with the estimates which are of concern to me. Having had the Aboriginal Affairs portfolio, I can see clearly how the matter does relate to a resources issue.

—I have heard the debate on the point of order. I do not uphold the point of order. I am sure that in due course Senator Kilgariff will relate his remarks to the estimates. I call Senator Kilgariff.

Is this the end of those projects? Are they now finished, wiped out?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairman, I think that the discussion of these estimates has gone very wide of the mark. Senator Kilgariff asked questions which have already been answered. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Leader of the Opposition, Senator Chaney, is unable to be present. He asked me to request of the Minister for Resources and Energy that the questions which he asked relating to the appropriations of the Department of Resources and Energy, which the Minister said were more properly addressed to the Department of Trade, be taken on board and that the Minister, in due course, provide the answers to those questions. I so ask.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to speak on that aspect. Throughout the debate on uranium it has been implicit-indeed it was implicit in the decision-making of the Australian Labor Party on Monday-that the Government has made a decision based on very expert evidence that the world market for uranium is rigidly limited and will remain so , and that there is an upper ceiling that can be very clearly defined for Australia and, therefore, the Government must intervene and decide which mines shall operate and which mines shall not.

If that is so, quite clearly the Government must have in its possession precise projections as to what the accepted projection of world demand is for uranium, year by year, for the next 10 or 20 years. The Government must be able to indicate precisely what the demands of individual countries will be and precisely what the supply to meet that demand from individual countries will be. Otherwise the argument falls flat. How can the Government argue that it knows that markets are limited? This afternoon the Minister indicated that the Government did have such expertise. I challenged that and said that commerce and industry has a wider expertise. If the Government has this expertise, and if it is so arguing, I ask the Minister to provide to the Committee, in the next day or two, the precise details as to the worlds projections of demand by individual countries over the next decade or two and the world projection of the directionalism of supply, indicating therefore how the Government reaches the decision it does, that there be nothing more than whatever is the forecast-some 3,000 tonnes extra availability for Australia. I believe this is fundamental.

As I interpret the Labor Party's decision on Monday-and the Minister has not argued against it; I have said this before-the Labor Party has said: 'In principle we find no objection to the export of yellow cake: in principle we approve the export of yellow cake'. The Labor Party is saying: 'There is a rigid market in the world. We want to create employment in Australia and therefore we are deciding whether we shall have the forces of commerce and industry competing or whether we will have government intervention. We are interviewing and we are saying that we will limit the output of existing mines and he will grant a new mine, that is, Roxby Downs, the right to operate, because it will be mixed mining quality and it will have an employability'. What is needed is for the Government to come forward and support that thesis. Incidentally, the thesis is one which, again, will have very great difficulty in the near future in terms of coal. I presume the Government will exhibit the same interventionist qualities in terms of coal, because no doubt it has assessed the world situation and has found that in terms of coking coal there is a gross oversupply and that in relation to steaming coal demand is falling away. Therefore, on that basis the Government would probably say: 'Let us be interventionist and let us decide that this mine is not to open and that mine is not to have more than a certain number of forward contracts'. I remind the Committee that, logically, the decision on uranium as a product was made purely on a commercial basis, that is, it is right to mine it, mill it and export it, but the limit is the available market.
