TALK.START.PARA: —I point out to Senator Foreman that it is against Standing Orders to leave the chamber while the bells are being rung for a quorum.

—Prior to the suspension of the sitting for dinner I was making the point that the Government had asserted that it had precise knowledge of the limitations of the market for uranium. I was inviting the Minister for Resources and Energy to provide particular statistics regarding that market. Since the discussion today has also involved uranium enrichment, I ask the Government also to include with that information its survey of what it regards in expert evidence as being the demand for enriched uranium for the next two decades, what the supply will be and from what directions.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators will recollect that earlier today I raised a question about the pursuit of uranium enrichment in Australia, both in terms of re-establishing the research at Lucas Heights and giving the Uranium Enrichment Group of Australia the go ahead to make its market survey. At that time I made assertions , a number of which the Minister refuted. I will now read to the Committee a public statement which was released today by the UEGA group through its Chairman . The document, which is headed 'Uranium Enrichment Group of Australia, News Release', states:

The Chairman of UEGA, Mr E. F. Herbert, today expressed disappointment at the Minister for Resources and Energy's announcement yesterday that the Australian Government had withdrawn its support for UEGA to continue its studies into the feasibility of establishing a uranium enrichment industry in Australia.
He said the members of UEGA accepted the Government's decision but wished to draw attention to the following facts:

1. Studies carried by UEGA, the Australian Atomic Energy Commission and Urenco- Centec and other organisations involved with the sale of enriched uranium indicated that markets for Australian enriched uranium were likely to be available in the 1990s sufficient to justify the commercial development of a profitable enriched uranium industry in Australia. UEGA had secured approval from the previous Government to carry out a detailed market study in conjunction with Urenco-Centec to test this assumption as a pre-condition to embarking on a detailed engineering and feasibility study, in association with Urenco-Centec.
UEGA had not commenced the market study pending clarification of the Government 's policy on uranium exports and will not now proceed with the study in view of the Government's decision.

2. Very long lead times are required to establish a uranium enrichment industry in Australia given the need for detailed feasibility studies, inter-governmental agreements, and the need for power utilities to commit for their enriched uranium supplies many years ahead of actual delivery date. To secure markets in the 1990s it was necessary that the UEGA studies proceed as planned. This is no longer possible and the potential 'market window' available in the 1990s for Australian enriched uranium could be lost.

3. The economic case for endeavouring to establish a uranium enrichment industry in Australia is encouraging. Construction of a uranium enrichment plant in the 1990s would involve capital expenditure on the plant and associated uranium conversion facilities of about $750 million and would provide direct employment for 600 persons in the construction phase and 500 persons in the operating phase. The export value of yellowcake is doubled by conversion and enrichment. Components for the very high technology plant could be manufactured in Australia and and such a plant would be in line with the policy of up-grading Australian mineral exports wherever possible.
4. UEGA has spent over $1 million on its investigations to date. These investigations were com- menced in 1979 at the request of the Australian Government.
5. UEGA hopes that it will have the opportunity of presenting its views to the inquiry--

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a point of order, Mr Chairman. Standing Orders forbid honourable senators reading their speeches. Surely the reading of an extensive extract amounts to the same thing as reading a speech. I think the honourable senator is out of order.
—There is no point of order on that matter. The honourable senator is entitled to read a lengthy extract. Senator Sir John Carrick is in order.
—Just you wait.
—I take a point of order, Mr Chairman. I ask Senator Walters to withdraw that remark. She made the remark: 'Just you wait'. I think that is an inappropriate remark in this chamber.
—There is no point of order on that matter.

—I think that the Labor senator picks a wrong target because I say: 'Physician cure thyself'. As he knows, I never read my speeches, nor do I in fact refer to copious notes in this chamber. I will now continue. I fully understand why the Labor Party would want to interrupt my reading this news release. Every paragraph of this news release confirms what I said today, refutes what the Minister said today and makes a mockery now of the policies of the Labor Party. The final paragraph of the news release states:

SPEECH.PARA: 5. UEGA hopes that it will have the opportunity of presenting its views to the inquiry foreshadowed by the Government into the future of uranium mining and processing in Australia.

Let me remind the honourable senator what the news release says. Today I said that if in fact the Government's policy last Monday-that is, the 55 per cent of the Labor Party's policy on Monday-were 'we agree with the mining, milling and export of uranium; the only obstacle is the lack of markets and therefore we will ration the industries', it ought to be looking for new markets. Uranium enrichment offers just such a new market. Uranium enrichment does two things: It offers the opportunity of taking the nuclear cycle further in Australia under full safeguards and it offers additional opportunities for uranium sales from Australia as well as additional employment. I think the Minister had some doubt as to whether the Government had withdrawn its support. UEGA says that the Government had withdrawn its support from UEGA.

The Minister challenged my statement-indeed, he challenged them all-that UEGA in its first report said that there were likely to be markets for Australia for uranium enrichment of a significant kind in the 1990s. I draw attention to the fact that this statement says that emphatically. The Minister said he had never heard it from UEGA. One of his duties should have been to read the reports of UEGA that had been submitted to the previous Government and obviously they ought to be the basis for his either continuing or stopping the research. In any case, he has now heard it. It is on public record that what UEGA is saying is that it was proceeding on the likelihood that there was just such a market. It goes further and says, as I have said, that it was doing this in partnership with Urenco-Centec--

TALK.START.PARA: —Likelihood! You said it was likely that Rundle would be producing 50,000 barrels of oil by 1985.

—One of the lovely deflections that the Minister tries when he is cornered is to turn the issue away from anything but the subject matter. He has tried this all day today. He has made direct misrepresentations of what I said. I have looked at the Hansard. It was quite outrageous. He has a grin like a cheshire cat now as though he has done something clever. Let him now eat his statements of today because one by one they are bowled over. UEGA has said quite clearly, as the world now knows, that in its judgment and in the judgment of Urenco-Centec, the biggest of the enrichment industries around the world, experts themselves-but of course the Hawke Government knows better, we have heard that-there is likely to be a market. They have decided that the Urenco-Centec centrifuge technique is the right one but want to check the market and to firm it up before they go further. They are in the business of checking the market but have been stopped from doing that. What a nonsensical situation it is that the Minister is saying in the Senate that he knows what the market is , he knows that mines should be opened or closed, yet UEGA and Urenco-Centec are saying: 'We believe there is a market for the 1990s and we want to go ahead but you have stopped us'. Pending clarification, the market study had not been commenced. Now it will not go ahead. The news release goes on to talk about the long lead times and the need, if we are going to have an enrichment market, to get busy now. It concludes, in that paragraph: 'But if we do not start now the Australian market'-in other words, the potential market window available in the 1990s for Australian enriched uranium-'could be lost'. That is on the Minister's head, for the decision he made yesterday. They go on to point out the advantages to Australia in capital investment, in employment and of course they have quite clearly-

—Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order. I thought Senator Carrick had spoken for about ten minutes before the suspension of the sitting. He has now spoken for another ten minutes and I think his time has expired.
—In Committee, Senator Sir John Carrick may speak twice in succession. He rose and no one else did. He is entitled to a second speech.

—I can fully understand this second attempt to try to stop me speaking. But let me make it perfectly clear to the Minister that no device will stop me, I assure him of that-short of the Government applying a gag -from bringing before the people of Australia the heinous act of which the Australian Labor Party and he, as the responsible Minister, have been guilty. We have before us tonight a very simple situation. It is quite clear now that UEGA was to have embarked upon a market study and has been stopped. So it is not a question of limitation of markets and, bear in mind, I have asked the Minister to produce his survey of facts on the markets for yellowcake and enriched uranium.

SPEECH.PARA: But let me come to the next silly season situation. Anybody who understands mining knows that the capital investment in a mine is based upon the economic use of the mine over a lifetime, that is, over a predicted development of the whole or body. To say to any kind of mining undertaking, 'Having been given approval, you cannot go on, with all your capital investment, with all your employment, to develop the whole of the ore body; you might be stopped at any time; you will get a contract perhaps, and maybe another but you may be stopped' , is of course to cripple enterprise in Australia. That is what is happening in the uranium province in the Northern Territory. That is what is happening to Energy Resources of Australia Ltd, to Ranger itself. It is inconceivable that a Minister or a Government responsible for the development of mines would believe that it could say to any mining venture: 'You can be stopped at any point of the development of your ore body, when we like to stop you'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us what you did to Fraser Island. Tell us what you did to Murphyores.

—All day today, when he has been asked questions, this Minister has created diversions. I think listeners to this debate should understand that we are debating the Appropriation Bill and that the object of an Appropriation Bill debate is to enable honourable senators to ask the Minister responsible to respond in a factual way to questions posed. Instead of that, what he has done all day is to try to create diversions. The fact is that the Australian Labor Party and the Minister himself have been vocal in saying: 'We are going to have a limited development of uranium in Australia, not because it is a noxious industry or because it might be radioactive at all, because we are prepared for it to be radioactive in South Australia'-of course, that is nonsense-'at Roxby Downs or in the uranium province, but because the world market is rigid and we decide who shall mine and who shall not'. Suddenly it has all fallen to the ground because UEGA has said, 'We, the expert commercial people, in terms of the Urenco-Centec experts of the world say that there is likely to be a market-
—Likely! You said you would be pushing 50,000 barrels of oil out of Rundle next year.

—I point out to the listening public that once again the Minister tries a diversion. That is the only thing he can do. We all know the old plea: 'When you are strong on facts and weak on law, pound the facts; if you are strong on law and weak on facts, pound the law; when you are weak on both, pound the blooming table'-and, by golly, that is what he is doing tonight. Let me conclude this section of the debate by saying that the UEGA public statement today has totally demolished the whole framework of the Labor Party's uranium policy and of the responses that the Minister made yesterday and today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have sat here for some time and listened to one of the most remarkable farragos of nonsense that I have ever heard in this place from Senator Sir John Carrick. What we have heard is apparently a most determined attempt in this place by the Liberal Party to push the barrow of a multinational company which wants to get into the uranium enrichment business in Australia. I do not really think that that is a matter that should go out on a broadcast to the public without comment. The centrifuge method of enriching uranium is one of increasing the amount of uranium 235 so that the material can become either a fuel for a peaceful nuclear reactor or it can become a fuel for a nuclear weapon. I asked the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh) a question earlier today, to which he has not yet given me a reply, probably because there have been so many questions that it has slipped his mind. I asked whether he would tell me whether it was not a fact that whether uranium is enriched to weapons grade or to reactor grade is a matter of technique. In other words, the centrifuge process progressively increases the amount of uranium 235 and the stage is reached where that product becomes an explosive mixture, not in the sense of a controlled fission reaction, as in a reactor, but an explosive reaction in a bomb.

—Order! Senator Mason, the Committee is discussing not the Department of Resources and Energy but the Department of Trade. I am aware that they overlap as far as uranium exports are concerned. Nevertheless, you should confine your remarks to the areas of concern to the Department of Trade.

—Mr Chairman, with all respect to you, I have sat in this place and in my office for 20 minutes and listened to the previous speaker range broadly, without comment from you. I thought I was speaking to matters which he had raised and which had been raised throughout this debate.

—There have been several debates but the earlier debate was relevant to the Department of Resources and Energy. We are now discussing the Department of Trade. Senator Sir John Carrick in fact was dealing with matters concerned with the Department of Trade. You are perfectly entitled to do so. I ask you to confine your remarks to that department.

—I wish only to deal with these matters that Senator Sir John Carrick has raised. He has raised the point that there is a useful and viable export industry for this country in enriched uranium. I am merely making the point that this is a very dangerous industry. It is not something that is as innocent and as purely commercial as the honourable senator has given us reason to believe. It is a fact that any unscrupulous group which has access to an enrichment plant can use that enrichment plant to make weapons grade material at any time. I suggest that that is not a matter which Australia wishes to be concerned with purely from a safety and proliferation basis alone. To revert to the trade aspects, there is no market for enriched uranium. All over the world, in the United States and other places, the major utilities are selling off their supplies of enriched uranium to each other at increasingly lower prices.

SPEECH.PARA: It is possible that there will be a recovery in the uranium market. If there is it will not be because nuclear power is on the increase. In fact, reactors are being cancelled all over the world, as Senator Sir John Carrick knows full well. It will be because there is an increasing interest on the part of a large number of countries-not democracies, not the Western countries, but the autocracies of the world with military ambitions-to acquire reactors so they can obtain from then the spent full rods, the plutonium, to make nuclear weapons. They might also feel at some stage, once they have nuclear technology that they should have an enrichment plant. The same comments would apply to such an enrichment plant as to the one which Senator Sir John Carrick is proposing for Australia. It is a dangerous, unnecessary technology which belongs to an industry which is on its way out, which is being replaced by other industries. We, properly, should have no part of it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that the policy relative to the sale of uranium was hinged around the fact that the Roxby Downs mine contains a combination of various metals. Besides uranium I understand it will produce copper, gold and silver. I understand that the decision was made in favour of Roxby Downs on the basis that to add the extra uranium from the other mines may tend to flood the market to some extent and make the value drop.
—No. There was no room for the uranium produced from them.

—Right. If that was the basis on which the decision was made, can we be given the figures which demonstrate what the added supply of copper will do to the markets in Australia and to other producers of copper. In view of their capital expenditure, their existing markets and their long history of involvement in this industry, I guess that they received the same consideration that the Australian Labor Party gave to the uranium question. I would be pleased to be given this information so that we may be able to put those producers at some ease.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will try to be brief. Senator Mason has said a number of things which ought to be refuted because they are quite non-factual. First of all, he referred several times today to the idea that centrifuge uranium enrichment was old fashioned and going out. I can only say that the Uranium Enrichment Group of Australia is a highly expert body.
—With big investments in centrifuges.

—None at all in terms of centrifuges. The group comprises a sugar company and a mining company and it has no interests at all in centrifuges. Nothing could be sillier than that. The situation is that there are three methods of uranium enrichment known to mankind at this moment, two of them proven and one still on the drawing board. The centriuge method is proven and operating throughout the world. Gaseous diffusion is proven and operating. The chemex, or chemical exchange method, is a theory; it has not been proven either at a pilot stage or a market stage. Those are the three.
—What about laser tech- nology?

—I have heard of laser technology. It is not even at the drawing board stage. Senator Mason must know that the diffusion process is so heavy on electric power that in France four nuclear reactors are feeding one enrichment plant. It would be absolute nonsense to suggest that we should have a diffusion plant. We cannot have a chemex plant. The biggest of the enrichment organisations in the world, Urenco-Centec, uses the centrifuge method and so do the Americans. It is not on the way out. The experts say it is the right method. That is the first thing. Secondly, it is labour-intensive. Thirdly, it is absolutely non-radioactive. It is of no threat to the health of the people. I repeat that the situation for uranium enrichment is two-fold; that is, to take yellowcake and to apply it to flourine gas and get uranium hexaflouride, U206. In other words, to get uranium hexaflouride and to seperate the two different weight elements or atoms, U235 and U238, in this case by swinging them or swirling them around as one would a billycan. The fact is that it is entirely a chemical factory and not a radioactive factory. There is less radioactivity in that process than there is at Ranger mine.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Mason seems to think he knows more than others. The Fox Ranger Uranium Environmental Inquiry looked at this matter and said that a uranium enrichment industry was an acceptable industry with the normal safeguards. Of course, Senator Mason would do it with solar or laser energy. It is absolute nonsense to talk like that. The uranium enrichment industries throughout the world are situated in areas of quite dense population. There has never been a suggestion of there being any kind of harm done to the public from such a plant.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't you read the newspapers? Windscale was a reprocessing plant .

—Do I not read the newspapers? It seems Senator Mason wants the public to believe that reprocessing and uranium enrichment are the same thing. They are at the absolute opposite ends of the nuclear cycle. Senator Mason could not be confusing the public more. The second thing Senator Mason keeps doing is inferring that if we had a uranium enrichment plant there would be a threat that products from it could be used to make bombs. The fact is that Australia is a signatory to the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons. Australia would be supervised not only by its own Australian Safeguards Office, which is under the command of this Government and the Minister sitting in the chamber tonight, the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh), but is also under the supervision of the International Atomic Energy Agency, an agency with which I have worked and for which I have respect. Any industry in Australia, including our research reactor at Lucas Heights, is inspected regularly and at irregular intervals by the International Energy Agency and by ourselves. Everybody knows that to enrich uranium for peacetime purposes involves enriching it from 0.7 per cent to about 3.7 per cent. Does anyone believe that in Australia, under secrecy, any government would allow a plant to be altered in all its configuration and in the whole of its cascades? This plant would cover many acres and would have something like half a million centrifuges. Does anyone believe that, without the Safeguards Office knowing, without the Government knowing, without any Australian worker letting the world know and without the International Atomic Energy Agency knowing, somehow this plant could be upgraded to the weapons standard of 90 per cent? This is the kind of nonsense --
—It could be done deliberately under a future government. You cannot guarantee that it will not be done.

—Done deliberately! The Safeguards Office and decent Australians would all contribute to the conspiracy, would they? I only raise this matter because time and again this issue has been corrupted by the kind of things that Senator Mason has said. To put this matter into perspective, if there is a uranium enrichment industry in Australia-the Government now having agreed to export yellowcake-we will be able to enrich yellowcake, to supervise it and to monitor it over so much more of its journey in absolute detail. There will be no chance of that yellowcake being turned into weapon-enriched uranium; none at all. In fact, the very thing we are advocating would be a safeguard built into the system. But of course equally it would create an industry absolutely non-radioactive, asbolutely safe in itself, an industry that would provide jobs and provide high technology.

—Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order. I refer you to standing order 421 where there is reference made to the calling of an honourable senator to order if he practices tedious repetition, and I suggest we are rapidly getting to that stage. It is listed in standing order 421, and I recommend that you make a ruling that way.
—Senator Sir John Carrick is not being tediously repetitious.

—I thought Senator Crowley was referring to Senator Mason. I did not believe she could be referring to me. I could not have believed that a senator with some scientific background would not want the Australian public to know the scientific facts, because if what I am saying is not factual let Senator Crowley get up on her feet and say that. Senator Mason is factual. Let her support him and say that what I am saying is wrong and let us have a debate on the factual things. What I am trying to do-I invite Senator Crowley to join me-is to try to get the facts on peacetime nuclear uses and the proper safeguards understood by the public. Senator Crowley is a member of the Government that has just decided that it is perfectly safe and perfectly proper to mine and to mill uranium and to export it from Australia. So in fact we are as one on that. Indeed there is only one person who is against that, and that is Senator Georges, because nobody else has spoken up. That being said, does she or anybody else refute the evidence that I have said about a uranium enrichment plant? Does she or anyone else refute what the Uranium Enrichment Group of Australia has said in its news release today? Why should honourable senators use the device of diversion when they know that the arguments being put up by their Government and their Minister have fallen to the ground? Last week the minister said that indeed if Australia does not export uranium two things are likely to happen. One is that the price will go up in the world, and secondly, that there will be marginally at least more danger that the world will use uranium for making nuclear weapons. That is what the Minister said on this subject. So in point of fact what was being implied by the Government was that the more Australian uranium that was bought and monitored, the less likelihood there would be of its going into nuclear arms. What I am now saying, what I have been saying today and what is now thoroughly supported by UEGA, is that the Government's arguments have fallen to the gound. As UEGA has said there is very likely a market and if we do not now move towards it we will probably miss out. Of course if we have the uranium enrichment industry it will not only create jobs and investment but also we will be able to monitor it. I have invited the Minister to respond on the UEGA message. I believe the very facts that UEGA has mentioned today have destroyed the Government's argument that there is a limited market in the world and it has to ration uranium.

SPEECH.PARA: In any case I raise two other matters. Let the Government produce those figures to support that and let it tell us how we can develop a mine unless there is a guarantee to the mining organisation that it can be viable until the whole of its ore body is worked. How can a mining organisation develop half way along the track not knowing whether it will get its head cut off? These are fundamental things and they need to be answered.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call the Minister I would like to say something about relevance in the Appropriation Bill discussions. I have allowed this discussion to proceed because there is in the Department of Trade estimates division 641 for Australian uranium export. I draw the attention of the Committee of the Whole to the fact that this provides a total of $285,200 for the facilitating of Australian uranium export. I think in view of the prolonged debate that the Committee had during the estimates for the Department of Resources and Energy it would be appropriate if this discussion were truncated and the Minister could answer the points raised and we might get on with some matters more relevant to the estimates for the Department of Trade.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, as you have very correctly pointed out most of what we have heard for the last 35 minutes and for the 30 minutes or so which preceded the dinner break was a rehash of what happened this afternoon. However, there are one or two additional points to which I will respond. Senator Sir John Carrick-I wrote the words down-said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has asserted that it had precise knowledge of the state of the uranium market.

The Government of course has asserted no such thing. The Government has made a judgment on evidence provided from a variety of sources, importantly from the interdepartmental committee report on the likely commercial global demand for yellowcake from Australian sources. The Government has taken account of an admission-if that appears to be a loaded term I shall use another one-or a statement by Mr Grey of all people, the Chairman of Pancontinental Mining Ltd, who acknowledged only last month that for the first time in very many years we were approaching a situation in which the production of yellowcake was likely to come to balance with consumption because for very many years production has been in excess of consumption and stockpiles have continued to accumulate. Mr Grey expressed the opinion that consumption and production were about to come into balance. We have also taken account of a statement by Mr Townsend of the Central Electricity Generating Board of the United Kingdom, that not until 1995 would the product of a new mine or new mines be required on the World market. But the Government has not asserted that it has precise knowledge. Senator Sir John Carrick might think that he has precise knowledge of these things but the Government makes no such assertion. The Government has made judgments on information which it has received from a number of sources-the Commonwealth bureaucracy and other sources-as to what the likely commercial demand for Australian uranium will be.

Concerning the other matter which Senator Sir John Carrick raised on behalf of Senator Chaney when he first commenced to speak at about quarter past six this evening, regarding the details of contracts, prices, quantities, delivery dates and so on which have been negotiated between Australian producers and overseas customers, I repeat what I said in the debate in the estimates for the Department of Resources and Energy, that I will refer those questions to the Minister for Trade (Mr Lionel Bowen) with the caveat-a very important caveat- that a good deal of that detail I expect would be regarded by the Minister, Mr Bowen, as being commercially confidential. But I will provide to the Committee- it cannot be done tonight-whatever detailed information Mr Bowen believes can be provided without breaching the commercial confidentiality of that information. Otherwise, what we have been through for the last hour of sitting time is a rehash of what happened this afternoon, and I concur entirely with what the Chairman said a while ago, that it is pointless to continue this discussion, and it is time that the Committee addressed itself to the question of the estimates for the Department of Trade per se.

TALK.START.PARA: —I asked Senator Walsh questions concerning the amount of consideration that had been given to the copper industry in particular as it affected the opening of a substantial uranium mine. I would like to get that advice from him as to exactly the sort of consideration that was given, who it was carried out by, what the future of the copper industry is seen to be and whether there is going to be any effect as a result of putting on to the market substantial amounts of copper, as I understand it. He may be able to tell us the actual amounts of copper we are talking about, what the prediction is for the price of copper at present and what it is likely to do to the world price and to the future of the other mines around Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The preliminary mining plan which the Roxby Downs venture has put out envisages the annual production of 150,000 tonnes of copper a year. The Government has not taken into account what the likely effect of that additional-assuming it is additional-supply of copper on world markets will have on price. That is a decision which the joint venturers will take. What the Government has done is to make a decision or a judgment-Senator Archer, of course, is at liberty either to concur with or to reject this judgment which the Government has made-that the Roxby Downs potential project and any other potential uranium producing project in Australia of comparable size are at least competitive and probably mutually exclusive for a considerable time into the future.

SPEECH.PARA: Having reached that judgment, the Government has made a decision that, given the very much larger net economic benefits to the nation which would accrue from the development of Roxby Downs as against any alternative purely or overwhelmingly uranium project, the national interest is best served by allowing Roxby Downs to proceed, incorporating in that, of course, the judgment that if any alternative source of uranium supply of the same magnitude were allowed to proceed, Roxby Downs would be made non-viable. But the question as to whether Roxby Downs is to proceed is to be decided by the companies involved. The present expectation is that those companies will make that decision before the end of next year. If the companies make a decision that Roxby Downs is non- viable on commercial grounds I expect that the position will be reviewed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairman, that answer still avoids the question concerning the viability of the existing copper mines. If viability was taken into account in regard to the question of whether there could be uranium mines and if the actions of the Government is selecting one is going to place the copper industry in Australia in jeopardy, I would like to know.

—I do not have the precise figures with me, but Australia's copper production potential in the context of the total world supply of copper is relatively small , compared to our potential as a uranium producer for that portion of potential uranium demand which is not tied up in long term contracts. One important point which probably should be made is that it is customary in regard to the supply of uranium oxide for contracts to be written over a very long period-that marketing practice does not normally apply to copper-so the amount of free or uncommitted potential uranium supply is quite small. Copper, if not sold on a completely spot or open market, is sold under circumstances which are very much closer to spot market, spot sales. Therefore, the marketing arrangements for the two commodities are not comparable. Even in the absolute sense Australia is a relatively small potential supplier of copper compared to its potential to supply uranium oxide. Indeed, that basic reality is reinforced when one looks at the uncommitted potential in regard to the supply of uranium oxide or of copper.

—Following Senator Sir John Carrick's notice to the Senate of the new release of the Uranium Enrichment Group of Australia, when the Minister for Resources and Energy was assessing the potential markets for uranium-he has come out and told us that Roxby Downs is the only mine that could possibly fulfil those-did his assessment and source of information include the companies that were mining uranium?
—I call Senator Tate.
—I would like to answer, but I will leave it to the Minister.
—The Minister has not risen yet.
—I asked the Minister for Resources and Energy a question. I wonder whether he is going to answer it. I want to know the source of his information for the marketing potential of uranium.
—I can call the Minister only if he rises.
—Obviously, the Minister does not intend to give us any answer.
—Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order. Senator Walters has resumed her seat. She is not entitled to speak again.
—Yes, she is. I call Senator Walters.
—Without an intervening speaker?
—Yes, without an intervening speaker. She is entitled to two calls. I call Senator Walters.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I again ask the Minister for Resources and Energy whether he will indeed answer the question. It seems to me to be a very reasonable question. He told the Committee that the market potential could be fully covered by uranium mining at Roxby Downs. We now have proof that that is not so. Other companies believe that they can seek and, indeed, have markets overseas. So I think it is quite reasonable for me to ask the Minister from where his source of information came and whether indeed he obtained his information from the uranium mining companies.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to raise a few matters as a result of the Estimates debates and subsequent matters. In particular, I would like to start by endeavouring to get some information on the matter of the Export Inspection Service. During the Estimates Committee hearings I asked a series of questions on how the Service operated, what changes were to be made and how the costing was arrived at. After quite a series of questions to Mr Miller, who was then answering, we were able to ascertain the fact that yes, it looked as though some changes were going to be made, but Mr Miller expressed some disappointment regarding the amount of assistance he had received from the industry. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is fair to say that most of the ideas that we have about saving costs in the Service have come from within the Department and were contained in the submission which we put to the Royal Commission. We put forward proposals then for a fundamental rebuilding of the Export Inspection Service, including such radical changes as passing over a substantial part of the responsibility to industry under a quality assurance program. We have to re-establish the integrity of the inspection system before we can get countries to go along with those radical transformations. A five-year plan laying out all of those points will be available for consideration by the industry within about a month.

Following that, we came up against the question of the enormous increases in charges being made. When I subsequently asked for details of how the charges were made up, I was told that I would be advised subsequently. I raised the question again when we debated the second reading of Appropriation Bill (No. 1). Again, the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh) was able to assure me that I would be advised. I demonstrated the reason for my request by producing the table of how the estimated costs for fish export inspection services had been arrived at. Again I was told that the information was not quite right and that I would receive it at a later stage.

When I did not hear any more about it I wrote to the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) on 23 September. He thanked me for reminding him that Senator Walsh was going to give me certain information. He replied on 24 September giving me another set of figures which told me nothing as well. Before I go on to other matters I would like to know whether we are going to get the figures which show how the cost of the Export Inspection Service is arrived at and, from that, how the cost that is charged is arrived at. The figures that were produced in relation to fisheries merely showed at the bottom of the page that there was a cost for salaries-it gave the various breakdowns-a cost for overtime, a cost for travel and a cost for laundry. Then there was an item which just said 'On-cost provision based on 50 per cent of salary component'. I want to know what that 50 per cent is? Is it an arbitrary figure? What does it cover? I suggested that it might cover long service leave and superannuation. I have not even received confirmation of that. I would like to know the various components of that figure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The basic Government policy, which I note was also the stated policy of the previous Government, is to recover by way of charges 50 per cent of the costs incurred for all export inspection services. On several occasions previously the individual components and the way in which that cost estimate, if you like, has been made has been supplied. But basically the formula, which is no longer applied, was that salary expenses were the basis of the cost estimate and a 50 per cent figure was added to that to cover superannuation obligations, long service leave, travelling expenses and so on. That was a quasi-arbitrary way, I suppose, of assessing the total cost. I am advised that that formula is no longer applicable and the current practice is to attempt to measure more directly and precisely the actual costs incurred.

SPEECH.PARA: I have just been advised that the direct costs include-this is not necessarily an exhaustive list-salaries, travelling expenses; protective clothing; I would assume laundry expenses; on-costs of superannuation, which are assessed as being 20 per cent of salary; long service leave, which is assessed at 2 1/2 per cent of salary; and a portion of the general administrative costs carried within the Department-I do not have a percentage figure for that. In time I would expect, if Senator Archer wants it, that a more detailed explanation of the way in which costs are currently assessed could be provided.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been waiting now since 12 September for that information. I would still appreciate receiving it. The people concerned in this matter would like to know what they are paying and the method that is adopted. I am pleased to hear that some change has been made which may let us get closer to finding out how that figure is arrived at. All the reports that I have read-reports of the Industries Assistance Commission, the report of the Kelly Committee of Inquiry to examine Commonwealth and State Meat Inspection Systems-and the comment of Mr Miller and others have indicated that we are working towards a system that will reduce costs. The only thing that has happened to costs since we started getting this information is that they have increased by 300 per cent. I think that everybody who is paying for this Export Inspection Service will find it very difficult to accept that fact. That will be even more difficult to accept if, in due course, we hear that costs are likely to go up. I think that these people have a lot to be frightened of. If costs have gone up 300 per cent while everybody is saying that they are coming down, that is a terrible situation.

SPEECH.PARA: I also understand that the meat industry still faces one or two problems in relation to the Export Inspection Service. I would like the Minister to advise how the arrangements are proceeding between the various States in relation to the single inspection service project. Will he indicate which States have entered the single inspection service, which States have not entered it and which States are contemplating entering it? I would also like some information about the expectations of a challenge being made through the High Court of Australia. I read in the newspapers yesterday that a challenge is likely to be taken against the Commonwealth Government and its powers to actually levy the amounts that have been charged. If the Minister provides that information for a start we can then proceed to deal with other matters I wish to raise.

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to the last question, I understand that suggestions have been made that the present export inspection charge, at least in regard to meat, may be defective on technical grounds as distinct from constitutional grounds. I, of course, will make no judgment on whether such a suggestion is valid. I will refer this to the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) for confirmation, but I would expect that if action before the courts should find that the charge which has been imposed-I would expect such a judgment would encompass charges which have been imposed for some considerable time-is technically defective, and moneys have been collected under technical conditions which are imperfect or fallible, the Government would take action to ensure that moneys which had been collected would be retained by the Government. The important distinction I make, which the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) has made from time to time, on some other matters I recall, is that there is a very substantial qualitative difference between a court ruling which overturns, on grounds of technical defects, a decision to impose any charge and a court action which overturns, on constitutional grounds, a policy which imposes a charge.

—Can the Minister for Resources and Energy ( Senator Walsh) also answer the first part of my question, in which I asked which States are currently in the system, which States will not come into the system and which States are contemplating entering it?

—New South Wales, as Senator Archer probably knows, has entered into the single inspection service arrangement for meat; I am advised that Victoria is prepared to enter into it; and South Australia has been in it for some time. Discussions at officer level are proceeding with the remaining States and the Northern Territory.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should like to ask a question or two about fishing. Over the last two or three years, I have asked a series of questions concerning the publication called Australian Fisheries. After the Estimates hearings this year, we were told that Australian Fisheries produced 7,200 copies per month. Of these, 2,800 are supplied to the Australian Government Publishing Service for distribution to subscribers and for shop sales. Of the balance of 4, 400 300 are for internal departmental use and the remainder are distributed free to parliamentarians, government departments, research institutes, media and advisers, foreign governments and, on a selective rotational list, to fishing organisations and fishermen. The report states:

SPEECH.PARA: In addition to the $100,000 provided under Item 490.2.04, Australian Fisheries- Printing and distribution costs, expenditure is incurred for salaries . . . $120 ,000, overtime . . . $2,000 and travel . . . $7,000. Therefore total estimated costs for 'Australian Fisheries' . . . is $229,000.
I understand that $70,000 was collected from the Department for paid subscriptions and $70,000 was raised by way of revenue from the sale of advertising. The report finished by saying:
Estimated shortfall of revenue when compared to costs in 1983-84 is $89,000 which will be a charge to consolidated revenue.

The report then goes on to say that as from November 9,491 copies will be distributed free to all Australian licensed fishermen, with the additional cost being met from the fishing industry research trust account.

I believe that to supply a free magazine at the cost of the fishing industry research trust account is something that probably the Public Accounts Committee, or some authority, ought to examine, because it must be a fairly marginal operation if a very substantial proportion of the advances to the account is spent in providing this magazine free to fishermen, particularly when we take into account the fact that another Australian journal, called the Professional Fisherman, is also on the market. That journal survives on very much a free enterprise arrangement without any subsidy from the Government and without free postage and delivery. I believe that, for instance, the alternative that this publication, the Australian Fisherman, should be looking at is the question of taking alternate space in the Professional Fisherman and paying accordingly.

It is ludicrous to have two first-class publications running parallel to each other and have one which is operating very successfully and one which is operating only by being propped up to the extent of well over $200,000 a year. I keep raising this matter because the answers that I get become less satisfactory from year to year. I should like there to be serious consideration of that matter.

While I am on the subject of fishing, I should mention that some months ago I also wrote to the Government concerning the arrangements for the catching of tuna in the southern waters. I have not yet received a reply. I am wondering, in view of the enormous financial involvement and the likely returns to the industry and to the Government as a result of these arrangements, what will be happening in the southern tuna waters, particularly as between Western Australia , South Australia and New South Wales. Representations have been made about the minimum size of allowable fish, as I understand it. I should like to know the result.

I should also like to know the present situation concerning two or three joint ventures which it seems to have taken a considerable time to sort out. Two of them concern squid fishing in Bass Strait, and one concerns gill netting in northern Australian waters. Again, there is considerable national and international interest in these ventures because of their nature. More recently, we have been making representations on behalf of the fishermen in the Gulf concerning the abolition of the safe anchorage situation. The northern prawn fishermen have done a tremendous amount of work in the last three or four years and have made every effort to try to get the northern prawn industry into reasonable shape.

It has depended very largely on them being able to maintain the safe anchorage status for the receipt of fuel and the price at which that enables them to get it. They have recently established and have become ready to institute a buy-back system to rationalise the number of boats in the Gulf and be able to do so without involving the Government in a heavy pay-out, but it involves fishermen's money to the extent of about $1m a year. As the latest information that they were given was that the loss of the safe anchorage and the increase in price accordingly would amount to a cost of about $5m, before doing anything about reducing the numbers of fishermen and only increasing the costs, it was appearing to be non-viable from their point of view and they would be unable to proceed unless they got more consideration.

On the day that we were discussing the problems of the Northern Territory fishermen in the Gulf, Senator Robertson was in the chamber saying: 'What more can we do to assist the industries in the Northern Territory, and how can we provide industries which will help?' I do not understand a matter that may allow us, on the one hand, nearly to wipe out the prawn industry and, on the other hand, to look for ways of providing additional assistance for the Territory and its people. To me, we would do far better to look after the industries that are successful and are standing on their own feet than to try to wipe out one lot and then look around to see what we can do to establish another. From that point of view alone, I trust that the proposition I have put forward will be considered. I should like the Minister's advice on it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Archer may be surprised that I am answering on this matter. That is because Senator Walsh was absent, briefly, while he was asking his questions. As to the question of Australian Fisheries, I am assured that the Fisheries Industry Research Council, and the trust account related thereto, are devoted to research and extension work. As Senator Archer will know, it is funded by both the State and the Commonwealth Government. It is the judgment of that organisation and, we understand, the fisheries organisation, that Australian Fisheries is a valuable publication, and one that they believe should be continued. When a charge is made, subscriptions go down. It is the judgment of the Government and of the industry that the publication should continue.

SPEECH.PARA: As for the tuna fisheries, Senator Archer seemed to be concerned about the fact that there were two different minimum size limits, one for east and one for the west of Australia. This takes into account the fact that the industry in the west is involved in fishing for smaller fish and that any attempt to increase the limit size there would have a very detrimental effect on the western fisheries industry. If Senator Archer wants that to happen, I suggest that he should justify it to those involved in the fishery in the west.

Senator Archer talked about three joint ventures. He mentioned one in the north , which I understand has been approved and announced. He also mentioned two squid fisheries in the south. The finalisation of those agreements is now in process between the companies and the authorities. I am led to understand that they will be finalsied in the near future. Those are all the questions that I can remember. If Senator Archer has not received answers to all of his questions , I shall seek the answers for him in the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could we be advised as to the present position with respect to the Australian National Animal Health Laboratory? The interest and controversy that has arisen of late over the unsatisfactory situation with ANAHL needs some explanation. Can we be assured of its purposes? How much money will be spent on it? How will it be manned? On which areas of research will it concentrate? Is it to be used for local purposes only or for international purposes as well? Exactly what is it expected to do for Australian primary industry? Recently I have had several letters from overseas about it from people who are aware of what is being proposed here in Australia. I need to be able to give them some answers as to the use and purpose of the Laboratory and how it will operate. I would be obliged if the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry (Senator Walsh) could provide me with those details.

SPEECH.PARA: At the same time, in view of the fact that the Industries Assistance Commission report on the dairy industry is in the semi-final stage, I would like to know how the industry and the Government are shaping up to the preliminary report and how the production forecasts for 1983-84 and the existing level of underwriting are matching up with the increased costs that have come to the industry this year. I would also like to know how the Government sees the effect of the apparent overproduction in Australia, which is, I understand, rating at about 20 per cent more than the domestic market. What effect will this have on the price when the industry will be competing with the surplus stocks that are going on the market from both the European Economic Community and the United States of America, which have big jettison arrangements at present?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: — Administratively the Australian National Animal Health Laboratory is actually within the Department of Science and Technology rather than the Department of Primary Industry. I am advised that a ministerial committee is reviewing ANAHL. The committee has appointed an advisory committee chaired by Professor Frank Fenner to report on the extent to which ANAHL should undertake research work on endemic diseases and vaccine production, and act as an overseas reference centre . The future of ANAHL should not be clouded or confused by the emotional issues surrounding the importation of live foot and mouth virus. This matter has now been decided by the Government. It has been decided that the live virus will not be imported. The decision was made in response to opposition which surfaced about 1981 in the form of concern by some scientists and producers about aspects of the project. In 1982 the Australian Science and Technology Council and the Academy of Science reported to the Government on ANAHL and the use of live exotic viruses. As I recall it, there was very considerable concern about the importation of live foot and mouth virus which was officially expressed by the National Farmers Federation. The official farming organisations on balance, at least, came down against it. The Academy of Science and the Australian Science and Technology Council recommended against the importation of live foot and mouth disease virus and recommended a review in 1987. That recommendation has been accepted by the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Archer also referred to dairy underwriting. The way in which he framed his question implied that the level of underwriting would be determined by costs , however costs are to be determined. That has not been the practice in the past . By a mechanism not formally established but, I think, related to reasonable market expectations for a number of years, a level of underwriting has been fixed. As far as I know, that general approach has been continued by this Government. The Industries Assistance Commission's report on the question has yet to be received. However, the Government will respond when that report is received.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also asked about the likely effects of the oversupply sitution on price and the marketing of the Australian surplus overseas in competition with the European Economic Community and the United States of America, which are in a major dispersal phase at the moment.

—I have just sought comfirmation of my own assessment of the situation, which I do not monitor as closely as I once did. My expectations have been confirmed. In general, the overseas price of dairy products is lower than the domestic price. Therefore, the larger the proportion of total production which has to be exported, the lower will be the average return to Australian producers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —If the Minister cannot answer that question I will finish up with a couple of easy ones. I would like to know whether there has been any approach to the Government by the lamb producers in South Australia or other States asking for the development of a lamb marketing scheme. I understand that it has been discussed in some States. I understand that there has been a poll on the matter again in Western Australia, as there has been in New South Wales. In view of the various decisions that are coming through, I wondered whether there had been an approach to the Federal Government for it to be involved in any way or whether it would remain a State matter.

SPEECH.PARA: The other matter I wish to raise is plant variety rights. I have been led to believe that the report of the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources on this subject will probably come down in the next week or so. Has the Government taken any stance on this matter in view of the great importance of breeders being able to obtain some of the new species from overseas, such as those in a variety of grasses, fruit, small fruit, pome fruit and decorative plants? Many of the plant breeders in Australia, of whom there are not too many, are also looking for some protection for their plant breeding programs with a view to being able to increase their export market. They are looking forward very anxiously to the protection that plant variety rights legislation will offer. Can the Minister advise us of the Government's likely attitude and how quickly we can get on with the appropriate legislation when the report comes through?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

—Senator Archer tells me that the referendum was positive. I did not know that. I am advised that no formal request has been received for the Commonwealth to become involved in this question. SPEECH.PARA: I am afraid that I am not able to respond to the question on plant variety rights at this time, but I will refer it to the Minister fo Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) who, I hope, will satisfy Senator Archer with a reply in writing some time in the not too distant future although, as Senator Archer probably knows, the Minister is currently overseas, and will be for some time into the future. TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to ask some questions in relation to the Primary Industry Bank of Australia Ltd. I hope the Minister for Resources and Energy has someone here who can advise in relation to these matters. The annual report of the Primary Industry Bank of Australia for 1983 shows that loans to authorised dealers in the Australian short term money market totalled $14.275m and bills of exchange and other short term investments totalled $50.721m, a total of about $65m in round figures which is close enough to 10 per cent of the total investable funds-$657.696m-of the Primary Industry Bank. Is it policy that approxi- mately 10 per cent be invested in short term securities of various forms as opposed to investing it in primary industry. I understood that was the basic reason for the Bank's formation. If that is so, why is it the Bank's policy, when it can operate with the sort of guarantees which I imagine a lender of last resort has as well as the other sorts of facilities which might be available to it. I do want to ask other questions but it may be easier to take them one at a time.

—I am afraid I am not able to respond to that. I accept the facts as stated by Senator Rae; I am sure they are correct. Strictly speaking, I think the Primary Industry Bank of Australia is administered by the Treasury anyway, not the Department of Primary Industry.

—I thought there was some liaison between the two departments. The questions I want to ask are really much more related to the Department of Primary Industry than they are to Treasury because the point I want to come to is this: Is it not a fact that the most expensive money a farmer can borrow in Australia today is through the Primary Industry Bank of Australia and, if that is the case, is it not failing in the primary purpose for which it was established? When I say it is the most expensive money, it is the most expensive other than money obtained through, for example, a hire purchase or leasing arrangement. I imagine it would be the most expensive first mortgage money that one could borrow.

—I think it is correct that the current Primary Industry Bank of Australia interest rate is above that generally available from trading banks, certainly on mortgages below $100,000. The interest rate on pastoral finance is probably higher than that currently charged by PIBA. The finance companies to which Senator Rae referred are very likely to charge higher rates again. As far as I am aware-we do not have any advisers present who are specialists on this-PIBA has not yet followed the general downward trend in interest rates that has been going on in the banking system for the last six months. I will seek in explanation a response from the appropriate Minister, either the Treasurer (Mr Keating) or the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin), and I will also seek information on whether it is PIBA policy to invest about 10 per cent of its total funds in the short term money market and comparable securities. I am afraid I am just not able to respond to that definitively now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for his co-operative answer. As of 4 November-the interest rate is notified daily-the current primary rate was 12.75 per cent for a four year term. However, the rate does fluctuate and that is part of the attraction for small investors.

SPEECH.PARA: A significant part of the Bank's borrowings is Commonwealth money at, as is stated at page 4 of its annual report, 10.2 per cent and a significant further part of its borrowings is in Eurodollar certificates of deposit, totalling $38m. I will not go through the rest of the figures, but a significant amount is made up from international borrowings which certainly would not be at a higher interest rate than the 10.2 per cent for Commonwealth money. Bearing in mind those points, one wonders why it is that the interest rate is so extremely high in comparison with virtually any other rate, and has been up to I think 17.5 per cent, certainly 17.25 per cent, in the past six months, when a large part of the borrowings are at a very much lower rate and yet the profit declared for 30 June 1983 is a very modest one. The sort of conclusion one reaches is that the Bank borrowed some money at an inordinately high rate of interest which is not disclosed in the annual report. TALK.START.PARA: —I will ask the Minister or Ministers responsible whether they can provide a satisfactory explanation for the apparent incongruity to which Senator Rae has drawn attention.
