SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my remarks to division 490, subdivision 3, item 08, wine research. I draw the Committee's attention to the very considerable problems arising in South Australia as a result of the Government's decision to introduce a wine excise which is to be applied to spirit. People who know something of the industry in South Australia will understand how widespread this problem is and what kinds of difficulties it will cause for grape growers right throughout the State. It will have a particular regional effect in the Riverland area of South Australia. Of course it is not only in South Australia that this problem will manifest itself as you, Mr Temporary Chairman, would well know. It will affect the Riverina district and the Murrumbidgee Irrigation Area in New South Wales, the Rutherglen area of Victoria, the Barossa and Southern Vales regions of South Australia and other areas of Western Australia as well.

SPEECH.PARA: Although the Government has denied that this is any kind of excise or tax on wine and has claimed that it is merely a tax on grape spirit, the fact is that it has a regional effect right across the board because the industry, in good times, does take in the surplus grapes from small grape growers, makes it into spirit and then stores it until it is used later. This has the effect of levelling out the effects of surplus and/or shortage between production from year to year. This is meant to provide-as has been evidenced very strongly by previous measures in respect of the brandy industry-a means by which the industry has been able to look after itself.

The Government, by choosing to apply a tax on grape spirit in the way it has, has imposed a tax of $1.50 per litre of alcohol payable seven days after the time at which the grape spirit is blended with any other product. That means that the tax has to be paid perhaps seven to 15 years in advance of the final sales realisation of that product. In other words, there will be a very considerable time-maybe up to 15 years in the case of very good quality ports- before the cash that is outlayed seven days after the time of blending can be recovered and used by the company for a regeneration of its investment in the industry. Mr Temporary Chairman, as a Victorian, you would understand that this is a very significant problem, particularly in the Rutherglen area of your State .

The point I want to make is that quite apart from the effects that this impost will have on the individual grape growers in the community, it will have a widespread regional effect on the suppliers and all those in the grape growing areas who rely upon the product for their income. I instance service machinery operators, motor suppliers and farm manufacturers in various areas, all of whom rely very greatly upon the income that will be realised from the sale of the grape product. It is pretty clear that the Government has no interest at all in this matter. Honourable senators opposite are content to laugh the matter off even though they know it is so important.

One of the things that is most disconcerting about this whole approach on the part of the Government is that it is prepared to levy a tax on an industry that is otherwise self-sufficient. Obviously people will be put out of work. I see Senator Foreman, who is from South Australia, giggling. Apparently he has absolutely no interest in the concerns of his own State. In the Riverland area of South Australia grape growers are being forced off their properties. Senator Elstob is attempting to chime in. At least he acknowledges the problem. It is a very significant problem which will force more people on to the social security benefit which is payable by this Government. It makes absolutely no sense to levy a tax in the way in which this Government has chosen to do, turning an industry into one that will rely on support from the Government in the future. For sure, more people will be drawing on the unemployment benefit. The social security budget will rise in such a way that it will cost this Government more money.

I wonder whether, in the same way as the Government has failed to address itself to other problems of this kind-as has already been acknowledged by the Minister for Resources and Energy, Sentor Walsh, in regard to the fuel excise and the mining industry-it ever thought through the effects of its Budget decisions on other parts of the Australian economy. Obviously the Minister for Social Security, Senator Grimes, will not attempt to answer these questions, simply because he does not understand the industry at all. Clearly, the Government has made a major blunder in this area, as has already been acknowledged. It has sought to cover its mistake by reducing the excise from $2. 60 a litre of alcohol to $1.50 a litre. Clearly, the future of the industry is in doubt. It is clearly a problem which this Government will have to face up to in the future.

The main point that I want to make in regard to this matter is quite different. The industry has been unable to determine, from those who will administer this new tax regime, how it will operate. Clearly the industry is most concerned about the way in which records will be kept, they way in which it will have to keep very faithful records to determine to what extent claims can be made against the revenue when export sales are made and where redistillation of the product occurs in any one year. I would like to hear the Minister's comments on the detailed situation in the various departments that are administering this scheme as to how they can get this detail into the hands of industry as quickly as possible.

All the inquiries that are coming from industry to the Government about this matter reveal that as yet no basic system has been outlined and no attempt has been made on the part of the Government to satisfy industry queries. Yet we are well into a situation in which this tax is required to be paid. The industry is going ahead with its arrangements about redistilling product throughout the year and processing it in the normal way, yet no basic administrative framework has been established. What kind of government would introduce that kind of measure without thinking through those kinds of implications? It is quite possible, as a result of the review of those complications and difficulties which the industry is facing, that the Government may well have to rethink altogether the whole basis of the proposition. Clearly the industry is most disturbed about this matter. It is prepared to co-operate but the problem stems directly from the administrative difficulties introduced by this Government in its offhand announcement in the August Budget. I hope that the Minister will be able to help us with some advice about this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —If people are bothering to listen to the broadcast of these proceedings they will probably be astounded to know that in the 10 minute harangue we have just heard from Senator Messner matters were raised under the pretext of wine research which is an item in the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1983-84. They would be equally amazed to know that an excise on fortified spirit was applied for at least a couple of decades until 1970. They would be amazed to know that the levying of an excise on fortified spirit is not something that appeared without precedent on 22 August this year.

SPEECH.PARA: I will give a quantative analysis of the excise which existed right up until 1970 and that which applies now. In 1970 the excise was $2 a litre of alcohol; it is currently $1.50. Some $2 in 1970 is equal, in present day values, to between $7 and $8. The excise which currently applies is very much less; it is less by a factor of about five or 20 per cent of the level of excise in real terms which applied in 1970. The administration of the excise is a matter for the Australian Customs Service or the Department of Industry and Commerce, not a matter for the Department of Primary Industry. It is a reasonable assumption that if it was possible to administer an excise in 1970 it is still possible to administer an excise in 1983.

A sense of deja vu swept over me, at least when Senator Messner gave us his harangue about his question, because I have heard it at least twice before in the chamber and nothing has changed much. Of course, no industry likes to have a tax imposed on it when no tax existed previously or have an existing tax increased. There have been complaints from the industry because an excise, presently standing at $1.50 per litre of alcohol, on fortifying spirit applies. To translate that into terms which are probably more commonly understood, if we assume that 10 per cent of fortifying spirit by volume is added to port or sherry-which is about the normal amount of fortifying spirit added-the effect of the excise is less than 15c per 750 millimetre bottle. Senator Messner referred to the cash flow position of the producers. I would expect that the cost of the excise would be added on to the selling price or existing stocks held by producers.

Some people may have been misled by Senator Messner's harangue into believing that all was well with the wine and the grape producing industries until suddenly this fairly insignificant tax of $1.50 per litre of alcohol appeared. That, of course, is very far from the truth. Way back in 1976 I sat on a Senate committee which looked at the wine industry and the same sorts of problems to which attention is drawn today were identified and talked about then and much the same sorts of complaints were made. In fact, of course-I am sure that if Senator Messner were not playing politics tonight he would readily acknowledge this-the real problem of the wine industry, particularly in the Riverland, are very much deeper than the existence of a relatively small excise charge on fortifying spirit, and those problems will not be redressed or overcome by changes in or the abolition of a relatively small excise charge such as that.

I know that the Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Kerin, has been holding some discussions and has a longer term plan for the restructuring of the industry in a way which will not involve band-aid solutions which at best excise changes could be regarded as, but a solution to the industry's problems which will be of a much more enduring and fundamental kind. However, the industry, particularly in the Riverland, at least since 1976 when I first became directly aware of the problem, has been in a state of less than complete health. Regardless of excise charges, the industry is likely to continue to have very serious problems until the sort of fundamental restructuring which Mr Kerin is seeking is actually achieved.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Resources and Energy ( Senator Walsh) has now drawn our attention to a new approach. He mentions a restructuring of the industry. He mentions the name of the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) in that regard. I think that that is something of a new move . It is not something that has been put forward in such a forthright manner by the Government before now. Therefore, I ask the Minister when the Minister for Primary Industry will be in a position to make a public announcement that can be relied upon in this regard?
—I cannot put a date on that. I just know that the Minister for Primary Industry ( Mr Kerin) has been holding some discussions on this question for, I understand, two or three months.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope that the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh) appreciates that that is a most significant statement which he has made. It is something which ought at least to be clarified as soon as possible in the minds of the public who are interested in this industry. This relates to an initiative which the people in general have not been aware of for some time. I hope that he will urge the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) to take all speed in making some public statement about it. Clearly this matter goes to the root of the problem, and I believe that his statement tonight will draw the industry's attention to this with a great deal of concern, and the sooner it is clarified the better.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to mention just one other point, and that is that the Minister did say, rightly, that this area of taxation is administered by the Department of Industry and Commerce. It is not administered by the Department of Primary Industry. I ask him whether he will ensure that proper liaison is being undertaken between that Department and the industry generally in order to establish the answers to the questions which I have raised. Although he can wave his hand at the problem and assure us that although this applied before 1970 it will be easily introduced now, the fact is that we are well into the time when this tax is to apply. Consequently, I believe that the preparation phase for the industry has not been properly regarded by the Government. Certainly the Government has not taken the kind of interest which demands detailed thinking and which ought to be sorted out between the industry and the Department at very close levels. For that reason, I ask the Minister to refer that matter to the Minister for Industry and Commerce and to ensure that proper measures are undertaken to establish a proper liaison between the Government and the industry .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I expect that the sort of co-ordination which Senator Messner seeks already takes place, but I am sure that the honourable senator's suggestion will be taken on board by the Ministers concerned, if my assumption is wrong. I want to make one very brief comment, since Senator Messner has sought further illumination on restructuring. I am surprised that he is at all surprised that this should be referred to. What the Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Kerin, and this Government are seeking is not illusory pseudo solutions to a problem, but solutions which will endure. In particular, if the honourable senator really knows anything about the Riverland area and other particular wine producing areas in Australia he ought to know that one of the problems is that a very substantial portion of the area currently planted to grapes is planted for varieties for which the commercial demand is at best limited or, at the margin, probably non-existent.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the solutions-indeed, I thought this was an objective of the previous Government, even with its record of negligence and inertia-is to encourage the replanting of grape varieties which had become unfashionable, and for which at least at the margin there is little or no commercial demand, with grape varieties for which there is a strong and probably expanding commercial demand. That is an important element of the type of restructuring which the Minister has in mind. As for the honourable senator's other request that the Minister make a formal statement on this matter, I will pass it on to the Minister when he returns to the country. As far as I know, he has no intention of doing so, in the very near future anyway. I understand he has been holding some preliminary discussions on this question aimed at achieving, probably among other things, the sort of specifics to which I referred, and that is replacing obsolete or inappropriate grape varieties with those for which there is a commercial demand. I would have thought that that is an objective which wine producers, grape growers and even the Opposition would have supported.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to thank the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh) for his comments and to say that in his first remarks on this matter he indicated a somewhat broader restructuring. I thank him for drawing our attention to the kind of things he had in mind.

—I have just one other question. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question to the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh) relates to the $10m part payment of compensation to Tasmania promised by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) following his decision to stop construction of the dam in the South West. On 1 July the Prime Minister wrote to the Premier of my State. I quote part of that letter which states:

SPEECH.PARA: At this stage--
Honourable senators should remember that this was in the early stages following the Prime Minister's decision to stop the dam-

the prime concern of both governments must undoubtedly be the livelihood of those persons who have been directly employed on the project. The Commonwealth is therefore prepared to reimburse the State, for a period of one month from cessation of work, in respect of payments made to persons presently engaged in the project area for wages and other award costs attributable to their continued employment. Payments to individuals under this element of the Commonwealth's proposals would of course cease as soon as they had been placed in alternative employment.

Many other aspects of compensation were to be taken into account. But the Prime Minister indicated to the Premier of Tasmania that he would be prepared immediately to start paying out some money. The Premier's reply, dated 21 July, states in part:

The State will have to reimburse the Hydro-Electric Commission almost immediately and, as it is beyond our ability to do this for more than a few weeks, early reimbursement by the Commonwealth is essential.
The letter goes on:
Based on the Hydro-Electric Commission's current expenditure on the Crotty Road --
This was, of course, the area in which the Prime Minister suggested works should go on-
. . . an appropriate advance for the month of July would be $4m and I hereby claim this amount on behalf of the State.

Back in July the Premier of my State claimed $4m for that month in response to the Prime Minister's decision that the Commonwealth would be responsible for the payment of compensation. I find it very difficult to understand then why payment of the $10m has been delayed.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is because Gray would not sign the agreement.

—I thought the Minister would answer me when I finished, not halfway through my speech. I would appreciate it if he listens to the question before he tries to answer it. If he does he may be able to grasp in full the question I am asking him. As I indicated, the Prime Minister said on 1 July that he expected to be making interim payments. On 21 July Mr Gray replied asking for $4m. No money was paid at that stage. The request was not even answered. The interim agreement was signed by Mr Gray on 7 October. Mr Hawke, in his letter to the Premier, indicated that as soon as an interim agreement was signed-this was part of the agreement that was sent to Mr Gray for his signature-payments would start flowing. That agreement was signed on 7 October. No payments were made on 7 October or following that date. The final agreement-do not forget that at this stage Mr Hawke had promised that as soon as the interim agreement was signed money would start flowing-was signed on 20 October by both the Prime Minister and the Premier. Still no money was made available. It was not until 1 November that Mr Dawkins made that shocking announcement that he could no longer stand idly by and watch the Tasmanian Government jeopardise the lives and well being of thousands of ordinary Tasmanians and, ultimately, the economic health of the State.
—Ken Wriedt had to get it.

—Of course, in the interim, a very large advertisement was placed in the newspaper pointing out to the Tasmanian people that an interim agreement had been signed, that a request for $4m had been made and that the final agreement had been signed on 20 October. But still no money was forthcoming from the Commonwealth. It was because of this pressure finally put on the Minister for Finance, Mr Dawkins, that money came across. It had nothing to do with Mr Wriedt asking for it.
—Of course it did.

—If Senator Tate is going to interject he had better sit in his place. It is about time Senator Tate started looking after his State. At the moment he would not have a chance of getting back in if another election were held, not a chance in the world. He would not get in even if he were placed at the No. 1 position on the ballot paper. He has deserted his State completely and the people of Tasmania recognise that. The Minister for Finance, Mr Dawkins, claimed that he had been waiting for a request from Mr Gray before making payment and that he had finally responded to a request from the State Leader of the Opposition, Mr Wriedt. That is absolutely untrue.

SPEECH.PARA: I have just read to the Senate part of a letter of 21 July from the Premier to the Prime Minister requesting $4m. That was the first request. No payment was forthcoming. Mr Dawkins was not telling the truth when he said he was waiting for a request. As I have already stated, the interim agreement was signed on 7 October. Again no payment was made. Again Mr Dawkins was not telling the truth. The final agreement was made on 20 October and still no money was forthcoming. The first request was made well back in July. I wonder whether the Minister could let me know what caused the delay. Was it complete incompetence on the part of Mr Dawkins, as has been suggested by the editorial in the Mercury? It stated:
The Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, would do well to remove the area of compensation payments from Mr Dawkins' responsibility and take complete charge of the matter himself.
It appears to me to be complete incompetence on the part of the Minister for Finance and his Department.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I can certainly answer that question. I would have thought that even Senator Walters would know or even the editorial writer of the Mercury would know that moneys can be paid by the Commonwealth only for lawful purposes. In this context that means that moneys can be paid only after an agreement has been signed between the Commonwealth and the State. On 31 August the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) handed directly to the Premier of Tasmania a draft agreement which would have lawfully authorised the payment of moneys to which the Commonwealth had committed itself and for which an appropriation of $30m in total had been made in this Budget. This is an example of the great haste or the speed with which the Premier of Tasmania responds to these matters. Five weeks later, on 7 October, the Premier of Tasmania signed that agreement, with some conditional alterations. Thirteen days later, after seeking legal advice on those alterations which the Premier of Tasmania had inserted, the Prime Minister also signed the agreement. Note the very much shorter time span. Still no formal request pursuant to that agreement for finance was received from the Premier of Tasmania by the Minister for Finance (Mr Dawkins). On 29 October, if not gratuitously then certainly generously and following an approach from the State Leader of the Opposition, Mr Wriedt, who is clearly much more on the ball on these matters than the Premier, the Minister for Finance authorised an interim payment of $10m to Tasmania pursuant to the agreement which was, as from 20 October, authorised by law.

SPEECH.PARA: If Senator Walters wants a bit more of the history of this matter, I draw her attention to the fact that from the middle of May the Commonwealth had sought discussions with the Government of Tasmania in regard to alternative employment and, related to that, compensation should the High Court of Australia rule that the Commonwealth legislation was constitutionally valid. For six weeks the Premier of Tasmania did nothing, until he finally got the message towards the end of June that he was going to lose the High Court case. Then very belatedly, because of that tardiness, and to the disadvantage of his own citizens and electors, he commenced discussions with the Commonwealth. He then poured out a series of statements in Hobart and in other places alleging it was because of Commonwealth negligence that no funds had actually been paid to Tasmania. That statement, of course, was the reverse of the truth. The negligence was entirely on his side, and it continued to be until the end of last month.

The essential proposition which the Premier of Tasmania was putting forward was that he wanted $500m in used $50 notes in a brown paper bag with no strings attached and no legal infrastructure enabling the payment of that money. This Government does not do business in that way. This Government pays money only according to law, and moneys could not be paid according to law until the interim agreement was finally signed, initially by the Premier of Tasmania on 7 October and then by the Prime Minister on 20 October. I have no doubt that Senator Walters will babble on for as long as she is allowed to babble on on this question. I have absolutely no intention of replying to her again. I have put the facts on the record, and the facts speak for themselves.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, the Minister has just said that the Premier wanted $500m delivered in a paper bag in used-what was it?
—In used $50 notes. Essentially that was his proposition.
—In used $50 notes.

—Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order. I draw attention to the fact that this is a reflection on a member in another Parliament. I should not have to rise in my place to remind the Committee that a standing order exists concerning this and it should be enforced. If other standing orders are being enforced it should have been enforced by now.
—Standing order 418 prohibits reflections of improper motives on members of State Parliament on this Parliament. The Minister should withdraw that remark.

—I was just saying that Senator Walsh stated that my Premier wanted $500m in used $50 notes in a brown paper bag and he said that his Government does not do business that way. That was where the Minister for Finance (Mr Dawkins), if he were not prepared to give an interim payment on a request in July, could have and indeed should have- the day the agreement was signed-made the payment of the $10m. The fact that he did not is still to me quite unanswered by the Government. It has not obviously got an answer. As Senator Walsh has already indicated he has no intention of answering the questions put to him. I put questions to him this evening, both of which he has arrogantly refused to acknowledge. TALK.START.PARA: —I have a number of matters I wish to raise. Most of them have arisen or have been brought to my attention since the Estimates or they are matters upon which responses have not been received to representations which I had made on behalf of people. I ask the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan) again about the school to work transition program and its place in the participation and equity program. During the Estimates Committee examination I asked the Minister whether any part of the school to work transition would not be suitable for funding under the new guidelines. I said to the Minister that if it would all be suitable that was fine. The Minister said: 'That is not the answer'. The Hansard for the Estimates Committee hearing suggests that all the parts of the school to work transition program would not be suitable for continued funding. In order to be able to advise my constituents, I need to know which parts are not suitable for continued funding. The answer that was supplied to Estimates Committee D did not really help me very much. The answer was: 'There is not sufficient information on each transition program'. I accept that. But if the Minister was able to say that not all of them would be suitable for funding, I ask: Which ones would not be suitable?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Education and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —A complete response to Senator Baume's interest in this matter will be available shortly. As I have told him, and as I have told the Senate, the transition program-not in its entirety, but aspects of it-will be subsumed within the participation and equity program. I have just received today the report from the Commonwealth Schools Commission after consultation with the States and non-government schools authorities about the implementation of the participation and equity program and, of course, those parts of the transition program which will be subsumed. As soon as possible I will table that report and it will provide a comprehensive answer to Senator Baume's question.

SPEECH.PARA: The matter of which transition programs will continue and which will not continue will essentially be a matter for the States via the new State advisory committees. As Senator Baume will be aware, the transition program was a decentralised program operated by States. They were given money to pursue the objectives of the program, and States determined which programs were funded and which programs were not. Similarly, the participation and equity program will be decentralised and the question of which particular programs will continue will be a matter for determintion by the States via their State advisory coucils.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister. Does that mean that if the State advisory committees recommended that all components of the school to work transition programs should continue to be funded-that that was the advice from each State-would they continue to be funded?

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Education and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Essentially that would be the case, since the Commonwealth will not be directing or determining programs unilaterally, but only in consultation with the State committees. I expect that we will accept the advice of the committees. If they choose in their State to fund all existing transition programs, I see no reason why that advice would not be accepted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to comment upon and ask some questions on that part of the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1983-84 relating to the Commonwealth Schools Commission. I had made mention previously that a study of the recommendations of the Schools Commission to the Government and the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan) shows that it received a very cavalier response from the Minister and the Government. Some 57 recommendations were made. Against the background of the months and years in which the Australian Labor Party when in opposition lectured the Fraser Government that it was the duty of the Government to accept the recommendations of the Schools Commission, one wonders why nine of the 57 recommendations were rejected. There was no response to 12 of the recommendations, not even the courtesy of a Government acceptance, rejection or modification. Two were reviewed for the future, three were deferred and 11 were modified. So 37 of 57 recommendations received a dusty answer. Only 20 recommendations were clearly accepted. I repeat that in this place we have been subjected over the years to lectures from the Labor Party and its spokesmen that the Schools Commission, being an expert body, must be taken notice of and its recommendations endorsed. That is a pretty dusty matter.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to comment upon the change in the policy of the Government in terms of its funding of different categories of schools. I want to underline the effect, the impact, of this upon the community. I have been looking at the report of the Commonwealth Schools Commission and at other statistics and doing some calculations. I have taken as a basis a parent who has a child in a government school from year one to year 11-the normal situation. On average costs at the moment, if a parent were to have one child in a government school, $18,405 of taxpayers' money would be paid over 11 years. Given the average family, of course, of two children, the figure would be $36,810, that being taxpayers' money recycled. On the other hand, if we look at the case of children in independent schools, including, very significantly, those in categories 2 and 3- those that the Government says it is aiming at-we find the following situation. We shall take as a basis a parent with two children-that is easier because that is the average family-at an independent category one school. The Government will pay $13,462 and the parent will pay $23,350. In other words, that parent, paying the same taxes as any parent with children in a government school, has a means test applied to him. Parents with children in government schools have no means test applied at all; there is no decision as to whether the government school is a category one, category 2 or category 3 school.

We should bear in mind, of course, that the report of the Karmel Interim Committee for the Australian Schools Commission showed that the quality of government schools far exceeded that of independent schools. In fact, government schools reached and passed their targets ahead of time. A parent with two children in a category 2 school would receive a $16,800 subsidy and pay $20,000 out of his own pocket. Are these category 2 schools supposed to be wealthy? A parent with two children in a category 3 school would get $19,500 by way of subsidies and pay $17,300. We are now dealing with 90 per cent of people, the people whom the Minister says are the needy, those who are in the disadvantaged class. They, in fact, will pay $17,300.

The Minister revealed in her speeches recently that she thought she had discovered the concept of needs support. I want to point out that the Fraser Government was strong in its insistence that there should be support for the needy. The simple fact of the matter is that it is not a question of the people in government schools subsidising, as taxpayers, the people in independent schools. There is an enormous benefit to the government schools by the payment of fees in the way they are paid in the independent schools. My calculation is that if, indeed, one were to have to pay the full, average amount for a child in an independent school, the cost to the Commonwealth and State Governments in any year by way of taxation would be in the order of $630m. That is the freedom from expenditure available to State and Commonwealth governments that occurs within the independent system, whether it involves the parent of a child at a category one, category 2 or category 3 school.

Indeed, the Government has a good argument to put, which is that if one does not apply a means test or a wealth test to government schools or to category one , 2 or 3 schools, if one does not, in fact, insist when one passes one's money out from the Commonwealth that one will put a differential insistence to the States that the money should go preferentially to the others, quite apart from the disadvantaged schools program, where is the logic? Where is the logic in saying that a government school can have the highest possible category? Being the product of a government school and having served on parents and citizens associations for years, I am all for the highest standards for government schools. But where is the logic in saying: 'Any parent, wealthy or otherwise, can choose any government school and any government school can have any standard it wants. We will not differentiate when we pass the money back but we will make punitive arrangements with regard to independent schools'?

Bearing in mind that there is no test by which one can measure these things, the Minister has said that the test is not on assets but on fees-the money coming to the schools. How does one measure the wealth of a family when it can be demonstrated time and again that the only way in which the parents of children attending category one schools can pay the fees is by the wife deliberately going to work and using the whole of her income for that purpose? I looked in the report of the Schools Commission and in speeches by the Minister to find whether some kind of survey had been done as to the number of one spouse or two spouse working families with children attending such schools, because when the Government decides to penalise schools it is arbitrarily, with a scatter gun, shooting at parents irrespective of their capacity to pay. That is a most astonishing situation. I have not entered this debate in the past. There is nothing more punitive, more irrational, than the argument the Minister has put up.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yours is not much good either.

—I thank the honourable senator for listening. The fact is that my arguments are based entirely on facts. The Labor Party is fond of pointing to the fact that it will observe the United Nations conventions when it suits it with respect to Sex Discrimination Bills or the Franklin Dam. Under the United Nations Charter it is the right of every child within the community to full freedom of choice in education. That freedom of choice should be available to the poor as well as to those who are not poor and the distribution of funds should be absolutely fair. If we are consistent we should look at that.

SPEECH.PARA: I simply wish to make two points. The Labor Party in opposition was good at giving sermons about following what the Schools Commission recommended. Its record in following this course is disastrous. In fact, it has been contemptuous and ignored most of the Commission's recommendations. The burden upon parents whose children attend schools in categories one, 2 and 3 is enormous, with no test at all as to whether parents whose children attend schools in categories one or 2 are the parents who struggle most in the community. The schools are able to tell us that many parents send their children to such schools with the maximum sacrifice to themselves. I find it odious that there should be such a distinction.

With the abolition of the basic grant and the breaking of the percentage link between the average cost of a State school and an independent school, there is no way in which any independent school, whether in category 3 or any other category, can be sure more than one year ahead that it will have funds. Once that link is broken, no matter how many nods, winks and promises are given, there is no certainty of funding for a school. Now the Minister and her Government have put fear into the hearts of parents and students at all schools.

It is wrong for the Minister to be so contemptuous that she talks of the 5,000 people who turned up in Sydney as being rich parents. The fact is that those people will be irate because they represent schools in poor areas. I invite the Minister to go and tell Mrs Monica Turner, who is the president of her group and who was one of the leading speakers at that meeting, that she or any of the parents in her group are rich and send their children to rich schools. I cannot think of anything that is more savage or wrong than to try to suggest that a gathering of 5,000 people is a gathering of the elite.

I know some of the organisers from those schools. As a former Minister for Education I dealt with them. They are people on average to low incomes. They attend the meeting for two reasons: The first is that they knew that the breaking of the percentage link is putting all schools in jeopardy; the other is that even if there were a toffee apple for them in the immediate future it would be a bad thing, an odious thing, if funding for other schools were cut in order that more funds could be granted to their schools. I want to make it perfectly clear that that meeting comprised many thousands of parents who themselves make great sacrifices. They would find the Minister's remarks utterly insulting.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Education and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will make a brief response to Senator Sir John Carrick's comments. It would be clear to Senator Carrick that the recommendations of the Commonwealth Schools Commission were formulated prior to the change of government. When we came to government we had made priorities and commitments which we had to address, as well as the recommendations of the Commission. We gave higher priority to some commitments that we had made as an opposition seeking government than we did some of the recommendations of the Schools Commission. There were recommendations of the Schools Commission that I and the Government would very much have liked to have adopted but, because of the $9 1/2 billion deficit that the Fraser Administration bequeathed to us, it was not possible to--
—Come on! Even Senator Walsh has deserted that one.

—Senator Sir John Carrick, having been a Minister in the former Government, does not like to be reminded of the $9 1/2 billion deficit which was the outcome of seven years of Liberal rule in this country. That is a fact and because of it we were not able to accept all of the recommendations of the Schools Commission, as indeed we were not able to implement immediately all of our own commitments. However, we implemented as many of the Schools Commission recommendations as we were able to implement responsibly within the fiscal limitations imposed on us by the dreadful deficit we had inherited. Other recommendations, of course, will be met as budgetary conditions improve.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Sir John Carrick has done some calculations on figures that he has derived from some source or another. I do not know what he is talking about when he talks about the contribution of parents as a fact because the range of fees charged in non-government schools is enormously wide. Even within a particular school there is a range of fees. Some private schools, to my knowledge-this is practice which I very much commend and encourage-have a range of fees to meet the capacity to pay of parents whose children attend those schools. I do not really know how he has derived a figure which he can claim is a factual account of parents' contributions. He has made his point about that. I think that I will leave that matter there.

I simply say though, in response to Senator Sir John Carrick's comments that we do not differentiate in our funding of the government school sector, that that claim is quite wrong. The disadvantaged schools program directs funds and resources specifically to the poorer government and also, of course, to the poorer non-government schools. A portion of the capital increase that I have made available to the government school sector-the first increase in capital expenditure in a number of years-has been earmarked for the neediest government schools, as indeed a portion of the money has been earmarked for schools serving predominantly Aboriginal communities. I will not go on at length, but it is quite clear that of course we recognise that some government schools are needier than others and make appropriate funding arrangements.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise a matter brought to me by some male higher school certificate pupils in the Australian Capital Territory who feel that they are being discriminated against by Senator Ryan on the grounds of sex. Senator Ryan has made a decision to mark girls up this year in the final Year 12 assessment. I have received complaints from some of the boys that they fear that this will have an adverse effect upon their performance and their chances. They say that their marks will go down simply on the basis that they are males. They believe that it is a case of sex discrimination and they are very concerned about the action that Senator Ryan has taken.

SPEECH.PARA: To be fair to Senator Ryan, I inform the Committee that Senator Ryan has received advice on this matter. I will outline the problem. I just think the response has been premature, and this is my concern. The situation-Senator Ryan is aware of this but I will just set it out briefly-is that for some years the final result at the end of Year 12, because of the Australian scholastic aptitude test, has been different for boys and girls. The boys have been scoring higher marks. I simply ask: Why is this happening? Is it due to some factor within the assessment system which is acting to the detriment of women? I think it is quite correct that Senator Ryan has taken action to investigate these matters. We know already that one of the factors which has emerged to explain this is the fact that there is greater retentivity for girls, and probably some less able girl students are retained. I believe that the committee that Senator Ryan appointed has attributed all of it to that factor. It suggests two other factors. Perhaps different subjects are studied by males and females and perhaps there may be some bias in the test. But it has not found any other factors such as bias. It has not found that the difference is due to different curriculum factors. The committee has recommended to Senator Ryan, properly, that the matter be investigated further.

I think the decision that has been taken-Senator Ryan will correct me if I am wrong-is that one-third of the observed difference will be written in so that girls' marks will be increased across the board by that amount. At the margin, at the borderline for entry into higher education, that adjustment, while it could advantage some girls, could displace some boys. I thought the correction might be of the order of 2.8 points. I did not realise just how significant that might be until I asked the student who called on me, concerned about where it may leave him, what the range of marks was with which we were dealing. He said that the ASAT mark is out of 100 and is then standardised to give an average of 65. If all girls marks are to be increased by, say, 2.8 marks where the average is 65, something like a 3 or 4 per cent advantage will be given. That mark is then used to moderate the marks the students gained in their subjects. I understand that the students take for their tertiary education tests three major subjects, each of which is worth 100 marks, and one minor subject which is worth 60 marks, and that the mark they obtain out of those subjects is moderated by the ASAT score as between schools.

Several aspects concern me. The first is that I have no argument with the procedure that Senator Ryan has followed in setting up the committee and no argument with the finding of the committee that further study needs to be done. What I cannot see is the justification for action at this stage, because the committee has not been able to identify a factor of bias. The findings in the report which has been submitted do not enable one to say that there is a bias in the test, or that it is due to different curriculum patterns. We do not know what it is due to; further work must be done.

Secondly, some consultations took place after the material came in, and it was reported that these included consultations with some non-government schools. But my correspondents tell me that no boys schools were included. That is fine if the only non-government schools that were consulted were girls schools, but this will introduce its own systematic bias into marking in the Australian Capital Territory. The Minister may shake her head, but if we are to mark boys down or mark girls up, we will be introducing a systematic change in the examination marks. It is premature to take that very serious step. I have no objection to the Minister investigating this matter with all the resources that she wishes, but until she has an answer which shows where the bias lies or what the factor is, to mark up all girls' scores is something which many people have complained about to me. As I say, a number of male students have complained to me that they think that they will be disadvantaged in a systematic way in the Australian Capital Territory in the name of equal treatment between the sexes. They think that it is unequal treatment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —As one small addition to Senator Peter Baume's analysis of this problem, I would add that the matriculation students of the Australian Capital Territory are all in danger of having their results undervalued by people in other States if confidence is lost in the objective criteria, the integrity, of the matriculation marking system, the higher school certificate, or whatever it may now be called, in the Australian Capital Territory. If girls' scores are to be given extra amounts to overcome some alleged bias, and if this is seen to be lacking in integrity by assessors, whether they be employers or those who govern entrance standards to higher education in other States, all students graduating from the Australian Capital Territory will be looked at more carefully when they go along to seek employment or higher education entry. The assessors will say, 'But your matriculation results have been manipulated behind the scenes. We shall need to discount your results'.

SPEECH.PARA: Some of the students who otherwise would have been highly regarded for employment or higher education entry in other States may unfairly, inappropriately, suffer as a result of the general view that employers and others will take of the assessment system in the Australian Capital Territory. I add further to Senator Peter Baume's remarks only by saying that it is imperative that the Minister ensure that there be, throughout the whole of Australia, an assessment of the Australian Capital Territory assessment system as having integrity, or else all students in the Australian Capital Territory will suffer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Education and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Peter Baume has offered an interpretation of the problems that have been identified with the application of the Australian scholastic aptitude test in the Australian Capital Territory. I should correct him on a couple of matters that he has raised. First, he referred to ASAT as being a part of the higher school certificate. It is not. It is part of the tertiary entrance assessment. The HSC is done in the Australian Capital Territory by one school, the Canberra Boys Grammar School. But all other students in the Australian Capital Territory have a tertiary entrance score of which the ASAT is a part.

SPEECH.PARA: The Schools Authority, which is responsible for assessment of students, set up an outside committee following the discovery by the Australian Council for Educational Research that a bias existed. It is not correct for Senator Baume to say that it does not know whether there is a bias. It has established that there is a bias. What it has not established precisely is how the bias has come about, although it has suggested the matters that Senator Baume has referred to, such as the wider ability ranges of girls who are staying on to the end of secondary schooling and subject choice. If much higher scores are attributed to one set of subjects compared with another set and if there is a gender division between the choice of those subjects, I believe that can contribute to the bias which has been established. However, such is the expertise of the people who advise the authority on this matter that they have concluded that it was not fair to female students in the Australian Capital Territory to leave them susceptible to the bias which has been established so they have taken what all experts in this area agree is a very conservative step of adjusting the scores of girl students by one-third of the difference. I do not believe that that will constitute any bias in reverse towards girls. Male students who have expressed their concern to Senator Baume can be reassured that in such a conservative response there will be no disadvantage to them. Of course, the adjustment of girls scores does not mean that boys scores will be reduced. It certainly means that more students will achieve a certain level of scores and that may or may not mean competition at a certain point for certain places. But once the bias had been established I believe the Schools Authority acted responsibility. It was a decision of the Authority; it was not a decision of mine, but, nonetheless, I am confident in the expertise and responsibility of the authority in this matter. As far as Senator Teague's interjection is concerned--

TALK.START.PARA: —It was not an interjection.

—I apologise to Senator Teague; I refer to his comment. The acceptance of the Australian Capital Territory accreditation by tertiary institutions throughout Australia has been very successfully established and I am quite sure that the adjustment that is being made will in no way undermine that acceptance. Indeed, we will see even more Australian Capital Territory students because more girls will be qualifying and gaining acceptance in a wide range of higher education institutions throughout Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan). This is a very serious subject so I will return to it and say that I have in front of me the report of the Australian scholastic aptitude test review panel. As the honourable senator knows, it was compiled by Dr Beryl Rawson, Dean of the Faculty of Arts at the Australian National University, Ms Helen Williams, Deputy Secretary of the Department of Education and Youth Affairs, Professor Don Spearritt, member of the New South Wales Board of Senior School Studies and Mr Ian Knight, Assistant Principal of Narrabundah College. I think Dr Keeves of the Australian Council for Educational Research was also involved. I have the report in front of me and I do not believe it establishes bias. I have just been reading it again and I think the Minister is wrong in fact, I would be grateful for her to show me in the report where that conclusion is reached. I quote from the conclusions in paragraph 9 which state:

SPEECH.PARA: As mentioned in paragraph 1 above, the panel has not been able to conduct an extensive study in the time and with the resources available. It has, however, concluded that there is a gender difference not related to retentivity which should be dealt with on an interim basis in 1983.
It does not say what it is due to. It continues:
As further work is required in this area, its recommendations for 1983 are conservative.
We can go back to preceding paragraphs to try to see where a bias was established. For example, paragraph 5 states:

In a preliminary and more detailed study of 'Sex Differences in ASAT and Retentivity', the ACER has estimated that one-third of the differences in male/ female mean scores could be attributed to differences in the retention rates of males and females in Year 12, and two-thirds to other factors.
It goes on to say in paragraph 6:

In view of the evidence that a male/female difference in the mean ASAT total scores persists after differences in retention rates of female and male students are taken into account, and given the need for a more thorough study of gender differences on ASAT, the Panel believes that an interim adjustment should be applied . . .

The panel did not establish that there was any bias. It simply said that there is a difference which it cannot explain. The fact that there is a difference does not establish that there is a bias. Unless the Schools Authority has established that bias is present, no case exists for this adjustment to be made. I say to the Minister that I cannot see from the report of the review panel how she could possibly reach the conclusion that bias can be demonstrated. It is on that basis that I have raised the concern of students who have come to me and who are worried about the detriment that might flow to them from the action the Minister has taken.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to raise the same subject. I have had constituents raise this matter with me. Some of them are parents who have both sons and daughters. To an extent their confidence in the system has been undermined. From the information the Minister gave me previously , I could not find an adequate explanation to point out the bias to constituents . I cannot say: 'Your daughters will be better off under this and your sons will not be disadvantaged from the position they were in previously'. The Minister referred to one set of subjects as having a certain value and another set of subjects that more girls seem to do which has a different value. What happens to boys who do that other set of subjects which has the lower value? What happens to boys who are in co-educational classes? Will they finish up in a typing pool simply because of this? It seems to me very clear indeed that any boy in a co- educational situation doing the subjects of lower value must be seriously disadvantaged from the position he was in previously.

SPEECH.PARA: The situation, as it appears to me, is that a school looks at a child and if it is decided that that child ought to be doing medicine, the child is given a mark that will get him or her into a medical faculty. If the school decides that a child ought to be in the Commonwealth Public Service typing pool, that child will be given a mark that will put him or her there. I have serious reservations about the whole system and I have had them for some time. But after this fiasco, as I would call it, I think all parents are very right to be concerned about what is happening to their children and what chance they have of finishing up in the right place. What guarantee is there that any child who perhaps is not particularly liked, particularly popular or regarded as particularly co- operative or the like will finish up with a mark that really represents that child's ability, male or female? I think that the community is entitled to be concerned. Without an adequate explanation of the bias there is quite a lot of trouble and concern in the community. If there is an explanation that makes sense, I think we should hear about it.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Education and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Both Senator Peter Baume and Senator Reid have challenged the report done by those expert people who have made the recommendation. The Schools Authority--
—A point of order, Mr Chairman. We have not challenged the report; we are asking for an explanation.
—There is no point of order.
—We have not chal- lenged the report, Minister.

—Senator Baume has said that he does not believe that the report has established the existence of bias, and he cannot understand why an interim adjustment has been recommended. Obviously, the Committee has recommended the interim adjustment to accommodate the existence of bias. There would be no other reason for its doing it. If the honourable senators have a view that is different from the people who made that report, they are entitled to it. The Schools Authority has accepted the report that I have accepted the assessment of the Schools Authority. On Senator Reid's very strange suggestion that individual children in individual classes will be penalised, I remind her that the ASAT score is used to moderate class scores. It is used to moderate a whole class; it does not pick out individual students. So, if it is a co-educational class there will not be any effect on individual students. The whole class, made up of boys and girls, will have its scores moderated by the ASAT and not individual students.

—In that case, where is the benefit to the girls in the class? At what point does that occur? That answer does not make sense, according to what is apparently happening. I have not said that I have a different view. I am merely seeking an explanation of where the bias is so that it can be explained simply to parents who are concerned. I am not asserting a view of my own on this matter. I merely want in words what the bias is so that people can understand it.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Education and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Girls in single sex classes and single sex schools will get the benefit of the adjustment to the moderating score.
—In fact, a girl has to be in a single sex school before she can get the benefit of the adjustment to the moderating score. Is that the Minister's answer? I want an assurance that that is correct.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Education and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the technical complexity of the way in which a score is applied does not allow me to provide a yes or no answer to that question. I refer Senator Reid to the report of the Committee.

—At this point we are asking questions of the Minister and we expect to hear a logical and coherent answer for any proposal the Minister is endorsing, even if it has gained some acceptance by the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority. I suspect that all of us, not only those on the Opposition benches but also representatives in the chamber from Western Australia, New South Wales, South Australia, Queensland, the Australian Capital Territory and Victoria, feel that there is no logic in the Minister's answers and explanations in the last 20 minutes. We are not convinced . How can the public be convinced by these half-baked explanations? I urge the Minister to have the whole proposal deferred completely until a paper is presented by her or even by the Schools Authority so that there is an explanation which has some logic to it, which establishes some primary concern and which suggests some remedies that are legitimate. I hope that that explanation takes into account all of the alternative reasons that could lead to an outcome in which girls have different end of school results to boys. I say to the Minister that it is not sufficient to give a series of sentences that add up to some self-justifying circular argument about some proposal that has something to do with bias between boys and girls in the Australian Capital Territory. The explanation needs to have substance and logic to it. I ask the Minister whether the whole proposal can be completely deferred until a proper, logical explanation can be given to the Committee and to the public.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Education and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The whole proposal will not be deferred. However, because the operation of the Australian scholastic aptitude test is a very complex and technical matter I have asked officers of the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority to have available for tabling by lunch time tomorrow a complete explanation of how it works.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to advise Senator Ryan that I think she has been wrong in an answer she has given. This matter relates to Senator Reid's question about what happens in co-educational classes. I will read the recommendation, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: An adjustment should be made to the ASAT total scores of all female students to reduce the size of any difference-
The panel goes on further:
The Panel also considered the possible application of an adjustment to the Girls' Schools only. This would ignore the problems in co-educational schools . . .

It seems that the Minister was incorrect. In fact, the recommendation is that the adjustment be made to the scores of all girl students if, in fact, the recommendations are accepted. I am grateful to the Minister for offering to make more information available to us. This matter is a mess, and a decision is premature. I would prefer the Minister to wait until she has the results of her further study and we know what is going on. We know that there was, in fact, a case of bias which warranted this interference with the grading system in the Australian Capital Territory.
Consideration interrupted.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 24 August 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has cell therapy been successful in assisting the development of brain- damaged children.
(2) Are there any dangers or side effects associated with this form of treatment.
(3) Is cell therapy practised in Australia; if so, where and by whom.
(4) Is the importation of sterile animal cells into Australia for purposes of cell therapy prohibited; if so, why.

(5) Has the Department of Health, or the National Health and Medical Research Council, or any other body undertaken investigations into the effectiveness of cell therapy; if so, where and when were the results published.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No evidence from properly controlled scientific studies has been presented to my Department which shows that cell therapy has been successful in assisting the development of brain-damaged children.

(2) In the absence of properly controlled studies and patient monitoring or even a full knowledge of the composition and manufacturing processes of these products it is not possible to state whether there are any dangers or side effects associated with this form of therapy. Some adverse effects have however been reported in the literature.
(3) No, not to my knowledge; although I am aware of one doctor in particular who is endeavouring to promote this form of treatment.

(4) Yes. These products are regarded as new therapeutic substances and as such their importation into Australia may not be permitted until such time as data have been presented to my Department for evaluation which establishes the quality, safety and efficacy of the goods in question.

(5) All available (published) references to this form of treatment were obtained by my Department and evaluated. These reports were then referred to the Australian Drug Evaluation Committee-ADEC-for its comment in 1981. This Committee which is independent of my Department was established to ensure the availability of expert practical advice from a panel whose members have a distinguished reputation in medical research and clinical practice.

The ADEC found the available information quite inadequate to allow clinical use of these products in Australia. This view was endorsed by the National Health and Medical Research Council-NH and MRC-following its investigation into the use of these products and also by a independent expert working with Down's syndrome children.

In 1982 departmental officers met with Professor Schmid, the West German promoter of cell therapy treatment. Following these discussions I have written personally to Professor Schmid and to the West German health authorities seeking their co-operation in providing the necessary data for evaluation. This they are endeavouring to do.
In its report of the 91st session held in Brisbane in 1981 the NH and MRC made the following statement regarding foetal cell therapy for Down's syndrome:
Following consultation with the Australian Drug Evaluation Committee, the Council concluded that this method of therapy has no beneficial effect.
The Council stressed that appropriate and optimal management of Down's syndrome includes early and continuing educational, psychological and medical support for the children and their families.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 4 October 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Australian Radiation Laboratory responsible for monitoring general levels of radioactivity arising from weapons test fallout.
(2) Where is this monitoring carried out.
(3) Are the results published; if so, will the Minister for Health make the results of these monitorings available.

(4) Does the Australian Radiation Laboratory compare the results of their monitoring with the findings of monitoring studies carried out by the Australian Atomic Energy Commission Research Establishment at Lucas Heights.

(5) Does the Australian Radiation Laboratory carry out monitoring of all radiation emissions within Australia, including those from the Australian Atomic Energy Commission Research Establishment at Lucas Heights.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes, the Australian Radiation Laboratory is responsible for monitoring general levels of radioactivity arising from weapons test fallout.

(2) The monitoring is carried out at a number of sites around Australia. Filters from large volume air samplers in six major cities (weekly), milk samples from all State capital cities (monthly) and resin columns which concentrate impurities from rain water in eight major cities (quarterly) are provided to the Australian Radiation Laboratory where they are processed for subsequent analysis for radioactivity. Current levels of long-lived fallout products strontium-90 and caesium-137 are extremely low and in many cases are below the limits of detection.

(3) The data, which have been published widely in Australia, are also summarised and published in collated form by the World Health Organization, the United Nations Scientific Committee on Effects of Atomic Radiation and the United States Environmental Measurements Laboratory. A list of publications relating specifically to nuclear fallout is provided in Appendix (1).
(4) The Australian Atomic Energy Commission does not carry out monitoring studies of this type.

(5) The Australian Radiation Laboratory carries out general monitoring of all radiation emissions within Australia whenever circumstances warrant it. A representative list of monitoring studies covering nuclear fallout, nuclear test sites, visiting nuclear powered warships, uranium, sand mining operations, X- rays in medicine, radio frequency radiation in industry and emissions from video display terminals is provided in Appendix (2).

With respect to the Australian Atomic Energy Commission research establishment at Lucas Heights, the Australian Radiation Laboratory analyses soil, water and effluent samples provided by the Commission and reports its findings both to the Commission and the New South Wales Health Commission.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 15 September 1983 (Hansard, page 733) Senator Chaney asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Trade, the following question without notice:

QUESTION.PARA: Is it a fact as reported in today's Australian Financial Review that a consultant retained by the Department of Trade was endeavouring to encourage Australian manufacturers to 'close their operations in Australia and go to Singapore'? Has any inquiry been made to ascertain the truth or otherwise of the claim made by the secretary of the New South Wales Branch of the Vehicle Builders Employees Federation, Mr Thompson, that he has documentary proof of the situation? If it is a fact, how does that square with the stance on protection that has been adopted by the Minister for Trade? I refer in particular to Mr Lionel Bowen's rejection of public statements advocating freer trade which were made by the Minister for Foreign Affairs at a book launching on Monday. Can the Minister confirm that the Department of Trade is acting in a way which was advocated by Mr Thompson, and how does that square with the position of the responsible Minister?
The Minister for Trade has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The Government recognises that investment overseas is a natural and often necessary commercial step for Australian companies in order to expand, or even maintain, their existing overseas markets. Australian direct investment overseas is quite significant. It is generating substantial foreign exchange earnings for Australia and jobs in Australia for Australians. Nevertheless, some investment can have detrimental effects on Australian industry and employment and it is obviously not this Government's intention to encourage such investments.

The Department of Trade offers an information service to Australian investors, just as it does for Australian exporters, to assist businessmen in ensuring that their commercial decisions are as well-founded and fully informed as possible.

The Department of Trade also administers some aspects of the Australian Development Assistance Bureau's program which is aimed at assisting the social and economic development of countries in our immediate region. Under this program, the Department facilitates exchanges of information between Australian businessmen and those of neighbouring countries, on mutually beneficial opportunities for trade and investment. Consultants are engaged from time to time, under this program, to assist in the identification of such opportunities.
In the case in question, a consultant has been engaged to examine whether opportunities exist for mutually beneficial joint ventures in Singapore.

Insofar as the protection issue is concerned, it is the Government's clear and determined policy intention to ensure that Australian industry receives adequate and effective assistance to enable it to survive and to grow and develop on a sound footing. Our approach must take into account the realities of world trade and the advantages enjoyed by many of our competitors. Some restructuring of manufacturing industry is inevitable and desirable but there must be recognition of what the community can be expected to cope with against a backdrop of economic recession. The Government is responsive to the needs of industry either when it is experiencing difficulties from imports or, within budgetary constraints, when it requires assistance to increase investment, stimulate innovation, promote exports and so on. In this way, Australia can move to the development of a healthy manufacturing sector which provides increased permanent job opportunities.
